1.content:
You had just arrived back home from your year away, training at Cauldron Academy, all girls boarding school to learn magic. You were very proud to be named the top of your class and honored to be given the right to teach at the academy someday. You walked through the front door with your two bags of luggage and stepped into the entryway of your house.

"Mom!" Cheerfully, you called. "I'm home!"

Mom entered the room, smiling. She was a tall and slender woman with long forest brown hair and emerald green eyes. She wore her favorite long black dress to mark the occasion of you graduating. "Welcome home, sweetie!" Hugging you, she said. "I am so proud of your accomplishments!"

"Thanks, mom." Blushing, you said. "Where are Joe, Ina, and Tia?"

"Ina and Tia are still at ballet, I will be picking them up soon." Lightly, mom replied. "Joe, well..."

"What happened?" Sighing, you asked.

Mom gave you a pained look. "Your father stopped by." Almost whispering, she said. "He told me that Joe has come of age and will soon discover his spark, his talent for chaotic energy and recruiters will soon be coming to him."

"You mean those mad scientists?" Ice in your voice, you asked.

"Your father is one of them, young lady." Scolding, mom said. She sighed. "The point is Joe is also close to discovering the magic within him."

"So it is a race." Sighing, you said. "Where is he?"

Mom winced before replying....
1.title: It begins

11.content:
You gasped, hearing mom's response. "You turned him into a little girl?!"

"Would you rather I allow your father take him away on a weekend excursion?" Frowning, mom countered. "We both know he would likely try to convince Joe to enroll into Eliete Scientiam all boys boarding school for mad science or worse, enroll him there behind our backs."

You frowned. Eliete Scientiam was Latin for elite science. Dad had spoke highly of the school, stating it was not quite as good as Eligere Sententia, the school in his home world. Still, as much as you disapproved of dad rarely being around, you doubted he would stoop so low as to do such a thing to the family. "That's a bit harsh, mom." Wincing, you said.

"Perhaps." Her face softening, mom admitted. "Still, that fear was there so I took the safer path and gave Joeanna a magical experience."

"How did she take it?" Curious, you asked.

Mom sighed. "Well, 'she' was mad enough to chew nails but she agreed to play along in exchange for some answers after practice."

"How much do you plan to tell him, err her?" Wincing at the end, you asked.

"Mom smiled. "It all depends upon the questions she asks." Bemused, mom replied. She sighed seeing your face harden. "I will tell him enough to satisfy him and ease his bruised ego."

You sighed, worried for your brother. "I just hope Ina and Tia have the sense not to tease their new sister too much." Softly, you said. "Joe is very nice and has a lot of patience but even that has its limits."

Mom glanced at her watch. "Well, we are about to find out." Calmly, she said. "It's time to pick the girls up from ballet."

The drive to the ballet school was quiet and uncomfortable. You knew it was only a matter of time before Joe was transformed into a girl. Still, you also knew that Joe had a huge decision ahead of him and any good or bad experience could sway his final decision. Upon arriving at the ballet school, you found Ina and Tia but Joeanna was nowhere to be seen.

"Where is your sister?" Serious, mom demanded.

Ina and Tia both shrugged then replied...
11.title: With Ina and Tia.

112.content:
"What do mean 'we don't know'?" Annoyed, you demanded. "You know better not to leave your sister alone the way she is right now!"

"We're only seven." Defending herself, Ina fired back.

"She was just here." Frowning, Tia added. "maybe she went to the bathroom or something."

"You just lost a week of allowance." Irritated, mom said. "I told you both not to let her out of your sight for an instant. Your attitude is completely unacceptable."

Ina and Tia both gasped as if they had been slapped. "But mommy...!" Whining, they protested.

You huffed before hurrying into the ballet school to find Joeanna sitting in a corner on the far end of the dance floor. She sounded as if she were weeping. Coming closer, you saw that she was wearing a pink girls' ballet costume with white flats and her now long auburn hair in a neat bun on the top of her head. You winced, thinking Ina and Tia might have gone a bit too far in teasing their new sister. "Joe..." Gently, you called. "Joe, you okay?"

"I want to go home..." Sniffing, Joe demanded.

"We're here to take you home, Joe." Slowly approaching, you said. "I'm sure you have a lot of questions to ask about what happened today."

Joe turned to you, a glint of anger in her hazel eyes. "You think? It was bad enough what mom did to me this morning! Ina and Tia wanting me to dance at their recital didn't help much!" She sniffed. "I have until tomorrow to give the instructor Miss Franz my decision."

"Please, Joe." Whispering, you said. "We'll talk about this when we get home."

Joe pouted then...
112.title: We don't know.

1122.content:
You were relieved to see Joe reluctantly nod and slowly rise to her feet. You ushered her out of the ballet school and caught her giving Ina and Tia death glares. The two girls merely shrugged, throwing her an innocent smile. Those smiles vanished when you whispered, "We'll talk later."

The ride home was quiet and uncomfortable. You sat next to Joe more to keep an eye on her and to make certain Ina or Tia don't make anything worse. You knew that a little girl experience with one or two ballet lessons would not harm Joe in the least. Once turned back to normal, you were certain he would eventually get over it and laugh it off. It was dad you were worried about; he would take advantage of the rough first experience to show him the wonders of his mad science.

"Dad wants to pass on his knowledge, I get that." Frowning, you thought. "Only he is so rarely around that mom almost literally had to raise us all by herself."

To you, dad did not deserve to teach Joe anything unless he did something grand to make up for all the years he was never around. Sure, he lived at the house but he would leave for weeks or even months at a time, only home long enough to explain his absence in private to mom then stay for maybe the weekend and then be gone again. Mom promised to explain dad's long 'business trips' to you when she felt you were ready but that time had not yet come. You turned to Joe to see her pouting in silence and sighed. You feared she would raise the roof with her screams the second the front door was closed.

Mom, you noticed, was very quiet. You caught a glimpse of her eyes in the rear view mirror; they were filled with worry and concern. There was no doubt in your mind that she was thinking along the same lines as you were. Upon reaching the house, mom calmly escorted everyone inside then set up a privacy spell the second the door was closed. You turned to Joe and immediately sighed upon seeing....
1122.title: An argument saved for later.

choices: You can show Ina and Tia that tomorrow.
She already did at Cauldron Academy.
Would you prefer to be a teen girl?
11222.content:
Dad placed a light hand on Joe's shoulder, startling her and she spun around to face him who then gave a patient smile. "The first transformation is always the hardest to endure, dear boy." Calmly, dad said. "However, with each one, it becomes harder for a witch to change you."

Joe teared up. "Ina and Tia..."

"Are only seven, Joe." Calmly, dad interrupted. "They do not yet fully understand the possible consequences their actions might bring them." He chuckled. "Patience is a necessary trait when learning the wonders of chaotic science."

Joe tilted her head to the side. "Chaotic... what?"

"The power that you have as opposed to your mother's and sister's magic." patiently, dad explained. "When you begin to show more patience, I will take you under my wing and show you the world you are destined to conquer and rule."

He then turned and walked away, chuckling to himself before vanishing at the doorway. Joe shivered then turned to you. "That was creepy." Disturbed, she said. "Can you change me back to normal, if there is a normal here anymore?"

"I can change you back to normal, Joe." Serious, mom said. "However, there is the issue of the recital, thanks to your little sisters." She sighed, seeing Joe tearing up more.

She wanted to tell her that changing her back and forth from boy to girl with so little time in between carried a certain risk but she knew Joe was not in the mood to listen. She turned to you, hoping for some help.

"The twins did not give you a good girl experience." Eying Ina and Tia, you said. "You are going to be stuck as you are at least until tomorrow, thanks to them. Why don't I show you some good points about being a girl."

"Why don't I show you some good points about being a boy?" Irritated, Joe countered.

You sighed at that only mom smiled and replied...
11222.title: A creepy pep talk from dad.

choices: Okay but I have some demands.
Do I really have a choice.
112222.content:
Joe jumped upon hearing mom's response. "She what?!"

"It's all a part of the training, Joeanna." Calmly, mom said. "Ina and Tia will also get their turn to be boys for a short while during their training."

"Don't call me that!" Irritable, Joe snapped.

"We're going to be turned into boys?!" Turning pale, Ina asked. "Ew!"

"You are not going to do that now, are you?!" Taking a step back, Tia demanded.

"I am tempted." Serious, mom said. "There are laws behind the use of magic."

"I was turned into a boy for a week during my one year of training, Joe." Serious, you explained. "It is to teach young witches what it is like to be transformed so they will think twice before toying with their male sibling on a whim."

"It does deeper than that though." Sitting down, mom said. "Witch born boys have impressive physical attributes, making them quite formidable if pushed." Turning to Ina and Tia, she added, "Joe is arguably the strongest boy in the state; add to that his chaotic blood and you get a person no witch would wish to see angry more than once."

Ina and Tia gulped, realizing what trouble they might be in with their new sister. "You wouldn't pummel us, would you, sis?" Worried, Ina asked.

"We're only seven." shaking, Tina added.

"The only crime you have committed is threatening to use magic in public." Sternly, mom said. "I am explaining this to you now to stop you from getting any bolder."

"The point is there is a balance in this household, Joe." Calmly, you said. "You are not the only one who will get transformed and made to do things suited for the opposite gender." You smiled then asked, "What do you say? Want to explore the life of a girl for a while?"

After a pause, Joe replied....
112222.title: She already did at Cauldron Academy.

1122223.content:
You smiled at that. "It's better than moping around the house all day. Plus no one will know its really you."

Joe frowned. "What would we do?" Irritated, she demanded. "Go to the salon to get our hair and makeup done, buy a new wardrobe..."

"We could." Teasing, you said. "Or we could just hang out in the arcade or visit the new malt shop."

"What new malt shop?" Curious, Joe asked. "I was just in there yesterday and I didn't notice any new stores."

You and mom giggled. "Only witches can see some of the stores the mall offers, sis." Bemused, you explained. "The mall is an entirely new world to explore now that you are a witch yourself."

Joe raised a single eyebrow. "Okay... you got my attention." Softly, she said.

Twenty minutes later, you were leading Joe through the mall passed a number of stores she had never seen before. You were bemused to see her looking all around as if it were her first time going there. "How can all of these large shops exist?" Wide eyed, she asked. "The doors are literally in the walls of the other stores."

You giggled. "The shops are physically under the mall itself." Calmly, you explained. "The doorways are teleports into those shops but only those with magic can see or even enter them as a precaution."

"Where do we go first?" Curious, Joe asked. "We could be all day exploring."

You smiled. "Well, we could go to..."
1122223.title: Do I really have a choice.

choices: Joe wants to explore the witch mall.
11222231.content:
Right next to your favorite dress shop was a malt shop you did not know existed until your magic came to the surface. Mom had taken you there before shipping you off to Cauldron Academy and now you had the pleasure of showing it to your temporary, perhaps permanent new sister, Joeanna. "No magic mischief is permitted inside so you have nothing to worry about." Smiling, you said. "It is strictly a place for those with magical talent to relax and just be themselves."

Although Joe was still uncertain, she nodded and followed you inside where you were greeted by Rina Bewit, the daughter of the owner of the malt shop. She was near your age with long black hair and blue eyes. She smiled upon catching your eye. "Welcome back, Gina." Cheerful, she said. "How was your year of learning magic?"

"It was incredible." Beaming, you said. "I came here today to show my temporary little sister, Joeanna a better girl experience."

Rina winced. "A rough beginning?"

You sighed. "Ballet with mischievous seven year old witches." Ruefully, you replied. "Plus dad gave her a creepy pep talk."

"Mad scientists are like that." Shaking her head, Rina said. She then smiled. "Enough about your worries, here you get to relax and unwind. Find a seat and I'll bring you some menus to look at."

You nodded and lead Joe to a seat who looked out a window at the people walking about in the mall. "It's hard to imagine this place being underground." Softly, she said. "Is this an enchanted window?"

You smiled. "I asked that too." Bemused, you said. "It's a normal window. What you are seeing are people walking about the witch run mall under the normal's mall."

Joe raised a single eyebrow as she always did when she was intrigued. "So, the door we walked through is just a surface access port?" Curious, she asked. You nodded. "Interesting... do we have time to explore?"

You giggled. "Maybe another time." Smiling, you said. "We are just here to help you unwind and relax a little."

Shortly after, Rina returned with two menus which she gave you and Joe. "How is your sister coping so far?" Curious, she asked.

"She's curious about the witch mall." Smiling, you replied.

Rina giggled as well. "It's best to wait with exploring that until you gain a little resistance to magic." Calmly, she said. "Magical mischief is forbidden here but not in too many other places, especially not in the witch mall."

Joe moaned at that, making you smile. "Patience, sis." Bemused, you said. "All in good time." She then turned to Rina. "I'll have a calming tea and a root leaf salad."

Rina nodded then turned to Joe who seemed perplexed by the menu. "I think you gave me a menu in Chinese." Wincing, she said.

You laughed at that. "It's witch writing, Joe." Amused, you said. "Here, I'll help."

Getting up from your seat, you touched Joe's shoulder. A harmless flame ignited in her right hand, making her scream slightly. You quickly urged her to close her hand, the flame went out. "You should be able to read it now." Softly, you said.

Shaken, Joe looked at the menu and sighed. "These are some strange names for what you offer." Softly, she said. "I'm glad you posted pictures."

"There is a lot to get used to in the witching world, Joeanna." Smiling, Rina said. "Take it in slowly, it will be easier that way."

"Would you like me to order for you, Joe?" Kindly, you asked.

Joe nodded. "A burger and fries with a tall glass of milk would be nice."

You smiled. "The vegan burger with potato slices and milk."

Rina nodded. "I'll put that in right away." Smiling, she said. With that, she left.
11222231.title: the malt shop.

choices: A girl walked in with a nervous boy.
112222311.content:
"A Vegan burger?" Wincing, Joe asked. "That means no meat, right?"

"It's not as bad as you might think." Bemused, you replied. "We witches tend to try to avoid too much meat in our diet though we do eat some."

Joe nodded but did not press the issue. She seemed far more interested in what might lie waiting to be discovered in the witch mall. "Is there a mad science mall?" Curious, he asked. "Maybe a little deeper?"

"They have something similar just outside of town." Grinning, you said. "They sell their gadgets and serums and what not only they prefer their shops to be more secluded from normal people."

"I wonder why." Wincing, Joe said. "Normal people are good for the most part."

"Mad scientists are, by nature solitary people." Serious, you explained. "Many have families but they often distance themselves from their children until they come of age." pausing, you added, "Sound familiar?"

Joe sighed. "Will I be like that if I become a mad scientist?"

"I honestly don't know, sis." Softly, you said. "No one knows what the future will hold."

Joe nodded then turned back to the window. "I wish I could explore..."

You giggled. "You are supposed to be relaxing..."

"You can't blame me for being curious." Pouting, Joe said.

"Being curious is one thing." Serious, you said. "Being reckless is another. Your chances of choosing your gender goes way down if you step out there." Your smile returned. "Dad made certain you were famous among witches, just don't let that fame get to your head."

You both stopped talking as...
112222311.title: You and Joe talk more.

choices: Joe talks to dad about the 'other' mall.
1122223111.content:
You both stopped talking as Rina returned with two large trays carrying your orders, smiling politely. "Here is your calming tea and a root leaf salad, Gina." Calmly, she said. "And here is your vegan burger with potato slices and milk, Joe." She took a step back and asked, "Will there be anything else?"

"Not now, thank you." politely, you said. "How long are you working till?"

"I'm actually off now." smiling, Rina replied. "I just wanted to make certain you got your meals in a timely manner."

"We appreciate that." Shyly, Joe said. As if sensing Rina's awkwardness, she asked, "Care to join us?"

"You don't mind?" Surprised, Rina asked.

"I heard mom tell Gina that there is safety in numbers." Blushing, Joe said.

You and Rina giggled as she then sat down between you two. "Have you discovered anything new since becoming a girl?" Curious, Rina asked.

Joe winced. "I feel weak, near deaf and blind." Softly, she replied. "That alone makes me feel vulnerable." She sighed. "On the other hand, I feel strangely energized and I have never felt so flexible or nimble."

"That energy you are feeling is your magic, Joeanna." Bemused, you explained. "Also, witch boys have certain advantages over witches that even things out."

"A witch boy's magic manifests itself in his physical attributes and senses." Calmly, Rina explained. "A witch turned into a boy would be stunned as everything would seem far louder and brighter..."

"Also, a witch turned boy would not know his own strength as he would be several times stronger as well." Ruefully, you added. "This is partially why witches get a taste of being transformed."

"Why aren't witch boys trained in special schools?" Curious, Joe asked.

"Those who are not of chaotic blood are." Serious, Rina replied. "They must learn to control their physical prowess so they do not unintentionally injure someone."

"You have this strength and more as a boy, Joe." Serious, you replied. "However, you also have dad's mad science, a different school is needed if you travel that path."

Joe moaned then took a bite out of his burger. "It's pretty good." After swallowing, she complimented. "It tastes like its made out of at least seven different beans."

"Eight, actually." Smiling, Rina replied. "Good guess, though."

You began working on your salad while Rina talked with you and Joe about everything and nothing until it was time to return home. "Come back any time." Politely, Rina said. "thank you for the lovely conversation."

"We might be back soon." Blushing, Joe said.

"You are still curious about the witch mall." Bemused, Rina said. "Just remember what we said, get some magic resistance first."

On the way home, Joe was thoughtful and quiet. You wondered what she could have been planning or plotting.
1122223111.title: Rina returned with your orders.

11222231112.content:
Upon returning home, Joe walked straight to mom's study with you following. You were curious as to what he was thinking and from the look on mom's face, so was she. "I know that look all too well, young lady." Bemused, she said. "You are bound and determined to get your way with whatever is on your mind." She sighed. "Let's hear it."

Joe took a breath. "What is the best way to gain the most out of my magic resistance?" Serious, she asked. "I found a new world I want to explore."

You giggled as mom turned to you. "She is curious about the witch mall." Bemused, you said. "She wants to take a look around but that is not wise without magic resistance."

Mom's bemusement grew. "You never could resist the urge to explore." Smiling, she said. "Well, to answer your question, just wishing yourself to be a boy again is not enough. You need to meditate, use your mental strengths to demand the change to come."

"Sometimes, even that is not enough." Serious, you added. "an understanding of how magic works will also be beneficial to you gaining resistance to its effects."

"Normally, as a girl, a witch boy can safely walk through the witch mall with an escort." Turning serious, mom said. "However, you are the heir to the throne of all mad scientists. That said, there will be many witches who will be tempted to make your transformation permanent."

"Why?" Worried, Joe asked. "Aren't witches and mad scientists friends?"

"Well, both sides do not consider the other enemies but not friends either." Wincing, you said. sighing, you added, "There are those on both sides who do not get along."

"Hence the two malls are separated to avoid any major confrontations." Serious, mom said. "There are a few shops within the normal mall that are magic and mad science but they are all carefully monitored."

"How much magic resistance would I need to explore the witch mall?" Still determined, Joe asked. "This is what I want to know."

Mom smiled, her bemusement returning. "You should be safe enough with me if you are so very curious of what you will find." Smiling, she said. "Only you need to understand that walking through the witch mall will send the clear signal that you are curious about magic and interested in learning it."

"Well... I am, sort of." Honestly, Joe said. "But I'm also curious about dad's mad science."

You shared a smile with mom who nodded. "We will go to the witch mall as a family tomorrow after school." Bemused, she said. "I doubt your father would care to tag along..."

"No but I would be honored to show my ever curious offspring the chaotic science mall the following day to show her all the options before her... or him." His voice echoing, dad said.

You shuddered as dad gave a short laugh before his voice silenced. "He creeps me out when he does that." Frowning, you said.

Mom sighed. "Although he seems to be gone for weeks at a time, he is always watching over us all." Softly, she said. "It takes some getting used to."

"I'd rather talk about this face to face, dad." Serious, Joe called out.

She jumped as dad suddenly appeared in the room, grinning. "As you wish."
11222231112.title: continue.

112222311121.content:
"Do I have to be a seven year old?" Pouting, Joe asked.

Dad grinned. "Your mother and sister are being kind and considerate in this regard." Calmly, he explained. "Do you really want to deal with an age where female hormones dominate your body, mind and emotions?"

Joe shuddered before shaking her head. "When you put it that way... no."

Dad chuckled kindly. "As I said, patience is key." Softly, he said. "One cannot fight off the effects of magic or chaotic science when their mind and or body are in distress."

"A clear mind and a body at peace is essential to strengthening your resistance to either power." Calmly, mom said. "Some witch families maintain a stressful environment to prolong their fun, not knowing such a tactic could lead to the point of rage."

"The what...?" Startled, Joe asked.

"The point where a witch boy or chaotic girl's anger and distress shatters the spells that have changed them, leaving the boy or girl murderously furious." Serious, dad replied. "This is a parent's worst nightmare of either power as the child becomes temporarily completely immune and on the rampage."

"A witch boy during the point of rage has been known to cripple their siblings and parents before they calm down." Sadly, mom said.

Dad nodded. "The same is with a chaotic girl with the same results." Darkly, he said. "Strict supervision is required when leading a child through resistance training." He then smiled. "However, outside interference is frowned upon and swiftly dealt with if any should dare try."
112222311121.title: A talk with dad.

1122223111212.content:
After another mundane day at school, you and mom escorted Joe into the witch mall to take a look around. As expected, Joe was looking around wide eyed with curiosity and wonder. Ina and Tia were not happy having to stay with aunt Viva and her two children but mom promised to take them exploring another day.

"Stay close to us, Joeanna." Firmly but kindly, mom said. "Do not enter any store or talk to any one without us near you."

Many of the women and girls wandering about the witch mall turned to you and Joe with a curious eye before smiling as they recognized you. "Good afternoon, Mrs Mage." Kindly, one woman said. "What brings you and your family to the witch mall?"

"Good afternoon, Wanda Rune." Patiently, mom said. "My temporary daughter, Joeanna, is having her first feminine experience and is curious about the witch mall."

Wanda Rune giggled. She was tall and slender with long blond hair and emerald green eyes. She sported a figure most models would kill for as did her daughter, Lydia Rune who was your greatest rival in school and magic.

"How does Joeanna Mage like magic so far?" Loudly, she asked.

You winced seeing many witches turning in Joe's direction before smiling. "So much for keeping a low profile." Annoyed, you thought.

"I really haven't tried any magic yet." Shyly, Joe replied. "I'm just exploring right now."

Wanda beamed. "You will find wonders beyond your expectations... young lady." Giggling at the end, she said. "I know of a few shops you may be interested in."

She motioned to the many shops but her smile faltered as Joe replied, "Thank you but, like my mother, I prefer to explore on my own terms."

You held back a giggle as did mom. "Where would you like to start, Joeanna?" Smiling, mom asked. "This is your opportunity to explore."

Joe looked about then said, "I'd like to start with..."
1122223111212.title: Skip to the witch mall.

11222231112123.content:
Joe looked about then said, "I'd like to start with a book store."

"Interesting choice." Smiling, you said. "Why there?"

"Mom and dad both said that knowledge is power." Serious, Joe replied. "So I think my safest option is to buy books on magic and study them before trying it."

"So you are curious about magic." Grinning, Wanda said.

"Curious but cautious." Firmly, Joe countered. "I want to fully understand what I am about to jump into before taking a swim, so to speak."

"I suggest Cauldron Books." Kindly, you said. "It's where I bought all of my books needed for witch school. I'm certain they have books for the curious witch boy."

Joe looked around again and stepped into the book store you had suggested and walked in with you and mom following. Wanda, fortunately, walked on though you had the feeling you had not seen the last of her.

"Welcome back, Gina." Politely, a teenage girl said. "I see you have brought your curious brother." she giggled. "Will she be attending witch school soon?"

"Maybe... if I like what I find." Surprising, you and mom, Joe said. "Mom practically raised me on her own so she gets first try to convince me of her preferred path."

The teenage girl beamed. "My name is Kelly Wand." politely, she said. "We have nearly every book you can imagine on magic, it's uses and laws."

"Nearly every book...?" Raising an eyebrow, Joe asked.

"Well, we do not sell the more advanced books." Blushing slightly, Kelly explained. "I'm still a little too young to get that kind of magic license."

Joe nodded. "I can understand that." Kindly, he said. "Do you have any books on magic's history, basic laws... powers witch boys may have?"

You and mom shared a smile while Kelly giggled. "We certainly do." Smiling, she said. "Do you prefer regular or witch writing?"

"Um... regular." Softly, Joe replied. "I still have to give my father a chance."

Kelly nodded. "My father is a mad scientist too." Kindly, she said. "I have similar power sets to that of a witch boy and similar rights." After a pause, she added, "You may want to get some books on that subject in case you decide to become a witch as you would also become the daughter of a mad scientist."

Joe nodded back. "I will, thank you."

After making his purchases, Joe left the store on good terms then looked about for his next destination. You and mom were both smiling. although Joe was being cautious, he is willing to keep the possibility of going to witch school on the table.

"Where to next?" Smiling, you asked.

Joe blushed slightly before pointing at a clothing store. "I might as well see what I would be wearing if I choose witch school."

You stifled a giggle. "You may not like the school uniform, sis." Bemused, you said. "Still, if you want to take a look..."
11222231112123.title: Knowledge is power.

112222311121231.content:
Upon entering the clothing store, you smiled seeing a fellow classmate, Kaylee Jinx who smiled upon seeing you. She was your age and height, light build, with bob cut hair and green eyes. "Gina, what a surprise!" Hugging you, Kaylee said. "Are you considering the teacher's aide classes too?"

"Maybe next year." Smiling, you replied. "Right now, my transformed brother, Joeanna is having her first female experience and is curious about the witch mall."

Kaylee looked at Joe then giggled. "I take it his father is less than pleased."

"It will be his turn to show Joe the mad science mall tomorrow." Wincing, you replied. "Still, Joe is willing to keep all option on the table for the moment."

Kaylee nodded then turned to Joe. "Just don't touch anything." Bemused, she said. "Some magical clothing have a way of getting attached to you."

Joe gulped then nodded, looking around. "I was curious what I would wear if I decided to go to witch school." Softly, he said. He paused as a number of girls and women turned in his direction before smiling. "What did I say...?"

"You are the son of the head mad scientist." Whispering, you said. "If you were to become a girl and a witch, many in the witching community would see it as a victory."

"No pressure..." Pouting, Joe whispered back.

You shrugged. "You asked..."

"Well, to answer your question, you would be wearing this." Calmly, Kaylee said. "It is a dark blue pleated skirt with a light blue shirt, dark blue sleeveless blazer and black flats with stockings, if weather demands it."

"I am the owner of the Witch Garbs clothing store." She motioned to the witch school uniform. "This particular uniform is not magically influenced but the one you purchase will sign a contract the moment you put it on."

Firmly but kindly, Joe said. "I'm not making any promises at this time but I'm not rejecting everything either."

The women's smiles faltered at the first part of Joe's statement but returned at the second part. "Cautious and wise." Smiling, Miss Gretchen said. "I am pleased you are taking things with an open mind."

"Two new worlds?" Curious, you asked.

Joe nodded, blushing more. "Magic and girlhood."

"Just be yourself and the rest will follow." Kindly, you added. "What are you curious to see next?"

Joe looked around then sighed. "I'm curious about it all." Softly, she said. "Only I have to keep an open mind with dad too."

"You need to calm down, Joe." Serious, you said. "Strong emotions augment magic. You don't want to spark a permanent change over a temper tantrum."

"You promised me some answers, mom." Furious, Joe said. "You also promised to change me back after ballet practice."

"I did promise you answers and to change you back." Calmly, mom said. "However, I would prefer to answer your questions first."

"I'm waiting..." Again tapping one foot, Joe said.

Mom sighed. "All of the girls in this family are witches with the power of magic." Patiently, she explained. "However, only girls have this power. A boy born into a family like ours have magic within them but they must be turned into a girl to be able to use it."

"For you to even detect magic, it has to be used against you at least once." Chiming in, you said. "For you to gain a resistance to it, you will need to have it used against you for a time." You winced, adding, "How long depends upon the boy's will to fight the magic off."

"Why ballet?" His anger ebbing, Joe demanded.

"I was hoping it would spark your athletic interests." Serious, mom said. "However, I did not count on Ina and Tia trying to push you into staying on the ballet team longer than planned." Mom eyed the twin girls as she said that, making them cringe slightly.

"How long did you plan to keep me a girl, going to ballet?" Worried, Joe demanded.

"Just a few days." Honestly, mom replied. "It was more because of your father..." She stopped herself short then turned to you, hoping for some help.

"This was dad's idea?" Horrified, you asked.

"No; it was not his idea." Firmly, you said. "He had other plans for you."

Joe gulped, taking a step back. "What did he want to do with me?!" Hurt, he asked. "What did I do to deserve any of this?!"

"It's not what you think, sweetie." Gently, mom said. "You are a valued member of this family."

"Then change me back!" Tearing up, Joe wailed. "I had enough of being a little girl!"

"We still need one more ballerina for the recital!" Whining, Ina protested. "Joeanna has to give her decision to Miss Franz in person tomorrow!"

"Besides, I think Joe is way cuter as a little girl." Grinning, Tia added.

"You are not helping!" Hissing, you whispered.

Mom gave Joe a pained look. "I will change you back tomorrow after you tell Miss Franz you can't dance at the recital." Softly, she said. "After that..."

"Joeanna thought she was smelly with your perfume." Raising an eyebrow, mom countered. "It's all about what you are used to. Turning him into a little girl was hard on him as it was!"

"Joe is not used to being a girl and you two seem to think that you can just force her into doing everything you two do on a daily basis." Frowning, you added.

Reluctantly, you walked towards Joe's room while mom continued her rant on Ina and Tia. "Did you seriously think I would not figure out that you two told her you were witches too?!" Angrily, mom demanded. "I sent Joeanna to ballet to give her an experience, show her being a girl is not so bad! It was not to give you two an excuse to manipulate her into doing whatever you want!"

"We didn't say we would change him into a girl any time we wanted." Pouting, Tia countered. "We just said that we could change him."

Mom shook her head, fuming. "Do you have any idea how hard it is going to be to pull Joeanna out of ballet now because of the stunt you two pulled?!" Now screaming, she demanded. She took a breath as both Ina and Tia backed into the wall, quivering. "I am about to pass down your punishments for your reckless actions and threats to use magic on your sister..."

You winced, hearing both Ina and Tia screaming before two boys ran for their rooms in tears and slamming the doors behind them. She answered a moment later by opening the door a crack, just enough to peer out.

"What do you want?" Grumpily, she demanded.

"Is mom or the twins with you?" Her eyes narrowed, Joe asked.

Sighing, Joe opened the door and allowed you in before closing the door and locking it. "Would you like something to drink? A snack?" Irritable, she asked.

She had a miniature fridge in her room which she bought herself with saved allowances along with a small book shelf full of snacks. "No, thank you." Politely, you replied. "They can't change me then?" Curious, you asked.

"Oh, they have the power to do so." Serious, you explained. "However, They are not allowed to because they are too young and inexperienced, accidents can happen all too easily."

"Are you allowed to change me?" Hopefully, you asked.

"I am allowed to do so under the right circumstances." Honestly, you said. "However, 'Joeanna' still needs to tell Miss Franz that she is not interested in sticking with ballet. That she will be moving on but might return at a later time."

"Much, much later." Pouting, Joe said.

After a thought, you asked, "How about I show you how we girls relax?"

1122312.content:
"Let me take you to the mall." Kindly, you offered. "I think a little shopping spree will help you get your mind off of your bad day."

"A shopping spree for what?" Pouting, Joe demanded. "Girl's fashions?"

"You can't tell me you were never curious what you would look like as a girl." Smiling, you said. "This is a chance for you to really satisfy that curiosity."

"I'll admit I was curious about how girl's clothes would look on me but that was back when I was six or seven." Blushing slightly, Joe argued. She became irritated, seeing you grin and quickly added, "The first time around!"

"No one is going to know its you, bro." Gently, you assured him. "All they will see is a cute, pouting little girl who does not like shopping."

"Ha Ha." Frowning, Joe said. "I'm guessing you really want me to go shopping with you."

"It will get you away from mom and the 'boys' for a while." Grinning, you said. "That and I promise none of your friends will know about it unless you tell them."

With a bit of further convincing, Joe agreed to go shopping and you took him to the mall by means of the bus. Ten minutes later, you were leading Joe through the girls clothing department, showing her the latest styles in girl's clothing.

"Mom has a no tomboy rule, as you know." Firmly but kindly, you said. "So you will have to limit your choices to skirts and or dresses for your small wardrobe."

Joe turned pale. "You're making me buy a wardrobe of girls clothing?!" Stunned, she asked.

You hushed her quiet. "Just enough to give you something to wear of your choice in case this happens again in the near future." Whispering, you countered. "That is unless you want Ina, Tia, or mom picking out your next outfit."

Joe huffed, irritated then looked out of the store to another across the hall. "What's with the Intriguing Look Clothing store, sis?" Curious, Joe demanded. "Mom is always telling me never to set foot in there."

"That store is run by a witch named Nora Malign." Serious, you explained. "She is reportedly the granddaughter of one of the rogue witches who had a part in opening the portal that had stranded hundreds of mad scientists in this world."

"What does that have to do with me?" Shrugging, Joe asked.

You sighed. "Nora sees all mad scientists, including you, as invaders and works to change all young boys with 'chaotic blood' into girls and witches." Frowning, you said. "That clothing store she runs is filled with enchanted outfits that will slowly and permanently transform you into a girl and a witch so it will appear to be a natural phenomenon. She can change her appearance and age to lure mad scientists of all ages and walks of life to her store."

"So she's a rogue witch?" Guessing, Joe asked.

"A quasi rogue." Calmly, you corrected. "She is not yet considered a criminal as she barely stays within the law and occasionally helps the D.D.M.C., Department of Dark Magic Control catch some real criminal witches."

"Are they like the police or something?" Raising an eyebrow, Joe asked.

"Something like that." Bemused, you replied. "Those who enforce magical law are called Soothsayers." You then frowned slightly, adding, "The entity who enforces the laws of mad science is called the Failure Oversight Department. Their agents are called 'Correction Officers'."

Joe seemed to sense that you were feeling uncomfortable and changed the subject. "Um... What color do you think is, as you say, me?"

You sighed, relieved that Joe decided to move back to clothing and fashion. "I'd stick with neutral colors, Joe." Honestly, you said. "Why don't you pick out a nice dress and try it on." Joe pouted to which you said, "You will be Joe again eventually. Just humor me for now."

With a sigh, Joe took the white dress with the pink sash and trimmings into the change room to try it on. "I better not have to wear a slip with this." Irritated, she complained.

You giggled. "No, that one doesn't need a slip." Calmly, you said.

As you waited patiently for Joe to change, you heard a strange voice coming from a store near Nora Malign's store. "I see you are showing your brother the ways of feminine persuasion." Bemused, the dark male voice said.

"Who are you?" Whispering, you demanded. "Show yourself!"

A tall, slender man in a black tuxedo appeared at the entrance of the clothing store. You were startled to suddenly find it completely empty of other shoppers but you, Joe, and him. "I am known as Dante Delirium, mad scientist teacher and tutor." With a deep bow, he said. "Here, I have a humble shop where I tutor young witches such as yourself so you may understand your bother's and or father's chaotic science. My teaching methods bring families closer together and I am offering you a free class to attend at anytime you wish."

"Although I am certain you see your offer as very generous, I must decline." Politely, you said.

Mom had warned you about this Dante Delirium. She told you that he was obsessed with making mad science the dominate power.

"This self righteous madman works to recruit unsuspecting young witches to learn chaotic science so to better connect with their brothers and or fathers." Sternly, mom had warned you. "Those who take his offer he slowly reels in and brainwashes into wanting to become boys and mad scientists. That is when he strikes..."

Returning your mind to the present, you remembered the teachers at Cauldron Academy calling Dante Delirium a 'gender offender' who was a mad scientist who permanently switches a witch's gender against her will.

"May I offer you my card, in case you change your mind?" Smiling, Dante asked. "You never know when your curiosity will lead you to wanting to learn more..."

You sighed then...

11223123.content:
You sighed, hearing Joe calling from the changing booth. "Gina, I can't reach the zipper! Why do they put these things in the back?!"

"Excuse me." Politely, you said. "I must attend to my temporary new sister."

"Of course." Smiling, Dante said. "Another time, perhaps..."

"Perhaps..." Backing away, you said. "Good day to you."

You continued to walk backwards, keeping an eye on the mad scientist until someone pulled him out of view. As you turned to help Joe, you inwardly hoped it was a 'Correction Officer' who had pulled Dante aside. "The zipper is in the back so it would not be visible." Calmly, you explained. "May I come in to zip it up for you?"

"You'll help me get it off, right?" Nervous, Joe asked.

You giggled. "Of course. Unless you want to keep it."

"Not funny, sis." Sourly, Joe snapped.

"I'm just kidding!" Smiling, you said. "Let me help."

You entered the changing room and closed the zipper on the dress before leading Joe out to a full length mirror set up between the two booths. The white dress looked very flattering on her. With the right leggings and shoes, she would be breaking young hearts in grade school.

Seeing herself in the mirror, Joe blushed brightly. "Okay..." Reluctantly, she said. "The dress does look good on the girl in the mirror."

You laughed at that as Joe was not about to admit she looks great in the dress. "Do you think the girl in the mirror would like it added to her wardrobe?" Kindly, you asked. "You know; in case she might come back later on?"

Joe moaned at that. "I dunno." Uncertain, she said. "I suppose..."

You giggled. "Done. Now let's see if there are any nice skirts you... I mean the girl in the mirror would like to add."

Unknown to you, while Joe was reluctantly building a small wardrobe, Dante Delirium was having a chat with the quasi rogue, Nora Malign. "I was moments away from scoring a new client!" Irritated, Dante snapped. "How dare you interfere!"

"In that case, I am relieved I caught you just in time." Grinning, Nora countered. "You and your kind are invaders, an infestation."

"On the contrary, we are purity." Defiant, Dante replied. "We intend to cleanse this world of its research of ancient sciences and bring it into the light of the future."

"A futile effort, I assure you." Frowning, Nora said. "No doubt you were targeting a new unsuspecting young witch."

"I offered my services to a young witch foolishly showing her transformed brother feminine fashions." With disgust, Dante replied. "Such a waste of talent..."

"No, she is showing her new sister the light." Showing pride, Nora said. "She is to be greatly commended for her noble efforts." After a pause, she added, "Perhaps I can offer my expert assistance as I do specialize in, shall we say changing trends."

"Are you suggesting a wager, my dear spell weaving rival?" Grinning, Dante inquired.

"Only if you wish to lose badly." Grinning back, Nora replied. "Shall we agree that the one who fails to win over their target must close shop for say a month?"

"Such petty stakes." Shaking his head, Dante scoffed. "I say that the one who fails to win over their target must move shop to the opposite end of the mall where our desired crowd is less likely to mingle."

After a brief hesitation, Nora took Dante's hand and shook it; the wager had been made.

Inside the clothing store, Joe seemed pleased that her little shopping adventure was nearly over. Still, she was pouting at the selections; more due to the fact she had to admit they looked good on her as a girl. "Cheer up, Joe." Smiling, you said. "How about a little wager?"

"What do you mean?" Sensing a trap, Joe asked.

"I will pick out a stunning outfit for you to wear home, one I know you will like as a girl." Serious, you explained. "If you love the outfit, you be a girl for your birthday this coming weekend."

Joe moaned deeply at that thought but asked, "What if I don't love it?"

You smiled. "Then I will be a boy for your birthday this coming weekend. We can do all of the things you love to do as a boy together."

After a thought, Joe nodded. "I know I'm going to regret this somehow." Bemused, she said. "Still, you got yourself a wager."

You and Joe shook hands.

Outside, in the main hall, Dante grinned. "What a perfect set up for our wager." Amused, he said. "I will have that little girl hating anything her sister picks out."

"Not if I have anything to say or rather cast about it." Grinning back, Nora countered.

"Is there something you don't like about it?" Wincing, you asked.

Only Rita was the biggest tomboy witch you had ever met. She refused to wear skirts or dresses unless it was for special occasions.

"We could give her a call and ask." Shrugging, you said. "Any other options?" Mom grinned, making you shiver. "Other than making me the ballerina..."
