"He is with me in his proper male form." Serious, dad replied. "I shall return him home after we have some quality time together. Good day, my love."

With that, dad ended the call. Mom let out a half scream of anger before speaking. "When we get home, I will want some answers out of you, Ina and Tia!" Furious, she said. "When your father returns with Joe, I will need you to keep the twins out of the fray, Gina!"

You nodded, knowing that another heated argument was coming between mom and dad. "I just hope Joe will be okay." Softly, you said.

Mom's face softened. "So do I."

Upon reaching home, mom...
113.title: Dad intervenes.

choices: Mom calls dad, they had not returned yet.
1131.content:
"Unless you two have an air tight alibi, I will be denying you your ability to work magic until you reach thirteen!" Angrily, mom said. "You have one chance so I would make it count!"

Both Ina and Tia gulped, literally shaking with fear. "All we told him was that we could change him into a girl anytime we wanted, if he wanted us to." Tearfully, Ina protested.

"We were careful; no one around heard us and dad did not scold us when he came for Joe." Sobbing, Tia added. "We didn't do anything wrong..."

"Discussing magic in public places is frowned upon." Scolding, mom said. "Still, what you said to Joe was not a threat but it could have been perceived as one." She turned to the window, thinking before turning to you. "Joe must have taken the girls' words as a threat and hit the panic button, summoning your father."

"Dad gave Joe a panic button?" Surprised, you asked.

Mom nodded. "I can only guess that dad answered the call and, although he found it not to be serious, took advantage of the situation to talk to Joe about his chaotic science." Serious, she said. "Shifting the blame onto me was only a tactic to buy some time."

"I thought it was against a mad scientist's gentlemen code to lie." Frowning, you said.

"Technically, he did not lie." Frowning herself, mom replied. "There is a safeguard to prevent young witches from discussing magic in public places which I did not use as it is seen as somewhat extreme parenting." She then smiled. "Then again, technically, dad had no grounds to pull Joe from ballet as there was no real danger."

"I feel another argument coming." Wincing, you said.

Mom sighed. "I prefer to call them heated discussions."

You rolled your eyes at that. "Just don't make this feel like a tug of war over Joe." Serious, you warned. "You know he'd rather be an athlete; he may reject both powers if pushed."

Later on...
1131.title: Technicalities

11312.content:
It was nearly sundown when the front door opened and Joe walked in, looking drained and confused. You walked up to him, concerned with mom close behind. "Are you alright, bro?" Softly, you asked. "You look exhausted."

"Dad had a lot to show me." Sighing, Joe said. He winced. "I think ballet would have been less tiring than a long lecture on machinery and gadgetry."

Mom smiled at that then asked, "Where is your father now?"

"He said he'll be waiting for you in his study room." Suppressing a yawn, Joe replied. "He said something about having a Tit ready for your Tat."

"Tit for Tat..." Shaking her head, mom muttered. "Cute, Geo... real cute." She then forced a smile for Joe's sake. "Why don't you call it a day, sweetie. We can talk about the events of today tomorrow after breakfast."

"Goodnight, bro." Gently, you said.

Joe nodded but was too tired to respond and walked passed you, Ina and Tia to his bedroom, closing the door behind him. Once he was gone, mom turned to you and the twins. "No one disturbs him until after I can talk to him tomorrow, is that crystal clear?!" Forcefully, she demanded.

You and the twins nodded and mom vanished from the room to reappear inside a large office over looking a massive chamber filled with busing machines of every size and type. Inside the office, behind a desk was dad looking over a number of papers. "How shall we proceed, my beloved wife?" Flatly, he asked. "You should not be surprised by my actions nor annoyed. You have three daughters to pass on your magic and I have only one son."

"The choice should still be his or hers." Firmly, mom countered.

"The choice yes but I am still entitled first introductions." Equally as firm, dad said. "He is my son."

"Our son." Serious, mom countered. "Gina, Ina and Tia will have their choice as well."

"Of which you will claim first introductions." Firmly, dad said.

"They are my daughters." Eyes narrowing, mom argued.

"Our daughters." Serious, dad countered. "This is not a matter of convenience, Mona. There are boundaries and I will not tolerate you crossing them."

Mom sighed, frustrated.
11312.title: Joe returns alone.

choices: an unwelcome surprise in your room.
113122.content:
The following morning, you came down for breakfast to find mom making herself a cup of tea, her hands shaking slightly. "Rough night with dad?" Gently, you asked.

Mom sighed. "Your father insisted that I had violated certain boundaries but I shot that down quickly enough." Tiredly, she explained. "I finally got him to, albeit reluctantly, agree that Joe needs magic resistance training no matter what he decides."

"I already had my mad science resistance training." Shuddering, you said. "The twins are still too young despite having magic at an early age."

"Just don't be surprised if your father decides to test that resistance." Frowning, mom said. "He has made it clear that he intends to become more involved with the family now that I had made the first move."

You rolled your eyes. "Fantastic..." Sarcastically, you said.

Just then, Ina and Tia walked in for their breakfast. They teleported bowls from the cupboards then summoned a spoon for each of them then summoned their favorite cereal into the bowls before summoning the milk. Mom could only shake her head then turned to see Joe enter, looking refreshed.

"Good morning, Joe." Kindly, she said. "Ready for breakfast?"

"I woke up to find a banquet on my desk." Smiling slightly, Joe replied. "It was a nice surprise after the weirdness yesterday."

You turned to Ina and Tia who shrugged, confused then turned to mom who sighed. "Geo..." Whispering, she muttered. She then forced a smile. "That was your father."

Joe smiled. "It's good to see him taking a more active role." Calmly, he said. "He's so rarely around, you had to raise us pretty much on your own."

Mom smiled at that, glad that Joe appreciated her hard work to raise the family. "Your father still loves all of you deeply." Softly, she said. "He's just away because..."

"I am always closer than you realize." Entering the room, dad said. "Joe has seen my office and he knows where it is." He smiled at him. "The door is always open if you wish to talk about anything."

"As is mine." Smiling, mom said.

Joe chuckled. "I thought it was us kids who were supposed to fight for your attention." Bemused, he said. "It's ironic."

Mom and dad looked at each other for a moment, perplexed. You laughed, catching onto the irony of it all with Ina and Tia following though you suspected they really did not grasp what the joke was. Eventually, mom and dad laughed as well, albeit a bit nervously. Joe had caught on to part of their tension and called them out on it.

Shortly after breakfast, you found...
113122.title: the following morning.

1131221.content:
Inside your bedroom, you found a large faded book on your vanity. From the feeling you were getting just looking at it, you had a good idea what it was. Upon coming closer, your fears were confirmed. It was the book of Chaotic Science. You knew from your mad resistance training the compelling energy the book gave off to entice those who gaze upon it to open the cover to the first page. Only the energy coming from this book was far stronger than what you had experienced before.

"No!" Looking away, you yelled. "I am a witch, the top student at Cauldron Academy!" You closed your eyes. "I have no interest in mad science!"

"Chaotic science and magic are the same." A calm male voice replied. "Only one is geared for boys and the other is geared for girls."

"I was born a girl." Your eyes still closed, you argued.

"Joe was born a boy and you'd rather him learn magic." Remaining calm, the male voice said. "Perhaps your father prefers you learn chaotic science."

You turned, your eyes opening to find the book cover had opened and the male voice was coming from the pages! "What are you?!" Shaken, you demanded.

"I am a tutor and a guide, you may call me professor." Still calm, the male voice said. "I speak to potential students through their book. This book is yours... Greg."

You backed towards the door, not liking where this professor, as he called himself, was going with his reasoning. "I am not interested." Coldly, you said. "Go back to whomever sent you."

"I fear I cannot do that, Greg." Flatly, professor replied. "Please prepare yourself for lesson one, adapting to the male form."

Your heart skipped a beat as you saw a chair quickly moving towards you! You knew it's intent was to force you to sit in front of your vanity with the book! With only seconds to react, you...
1131221.title: an unwelcome surprise in your room.

11312211.content:
With only seconds to react, you disintegrated the wooden chair with a blast from your magic then turned to the book. "Unless you wish to share the fate of the chair, be gone!" Summoning a flame, you challenged. "I will not be threatened in my own bedroom!"

"There is no threat here, Greg." Calmly, professor said. "However, resistance is to be expected from any transformed girl as many do fear change."

A light shot from the book but you were ready with a magical shield. Having taken mad resistance training, you gulped knowing the shot of light was an event designed to change your gender. You fired back with an energy blast with the intent of throwing the book out the window. Only the book had defenses of its own and your magical blast was thrown back at you! A scream escaped your lips as your jumped aside to see your blast knock the door open! Your first instinct was to run for the hall or try to teleport away but you held your ground. Instead, you screamed for help while keeping your guard up against the book's attacks.

"Help!" Screaming, you repeated. "I'm being attacked!"

You heard hurried footfalls approaching your room to which professor stated, "All you have accomplished was to add another student to my class, Greg."

"Don't call me that!" Angry, you yelled.

Suddenly, a figure appeared and the book fired another shot of light. Only the figure dodged it and literally physically pushed the book closed before barking, "Get me something to tie this crazy thing closed!"

It was...
11312211.title: fought with your magic.

113122112.content:
You were surprised to see Joe move so quickly not to mention dodge the blast of light from the book. Still, you were quick to recover and grabbed a ribbon from your closet before casting a strength spell onto it to make the fabric stronger. Joe took it and quickly tied the book closed before placing a stack of other books on top of it.

"Dad told me that it is a father's duty and honor to give a chaotic science book to the one he wishes to teach." Catching his breath, Joe said. "If a book appears, it is not from him but from someone outside of the family."

"If dad didn't send it, who did?" Worried, you asked.

Joe knotted his jaws in decision. "One way to find out." Serious, he said. He then turned to your door. "Daddy, we need you!"

Instantly, dad appeared in the doorway with a look of concern. "What is the nature of your emergency?" Serious, he demanded.

"A chaotic science book appeared in my room and tried to force lessons onto me!" Shuddering, you explained. "Joe saved me by forcing it closed and tying it shut!"

Dad frowned upon spotting the book you told him about. He waved his hand and the book vanished with the pile of books neatly falling onto the table. "This was a violation of your inner sanctum, Gina." Darkly, he said. "The person or group responsible will receive an appropriate response."

He then stepped forward and gave you a warm hug, which surprised you but you gratefully hugged him in return. Upon breaking the hug, dad turned to Joe. "You have done well to protect your sister." Kindly, he said. "You will grow up to become a fine chaotic scientist."

With that, he vanished from the room as mom approached, looking concerned. "I was on the telephone with your grandmother." Softly, she said. "I thought I heard yelling up here, is everything okay?"

You and Joe briefly explained what had happened, causing mom to frown. "You better let me check your room before you go in there, young man." Serious, she said. She then turned to you. "Check up on the twins."

You gulped, hoping no one would send Ina or Tia a chaotic science book at their young age. Still, you knew that the terms off limits and keep out did not always apply to certain mad scientists.
113122112.title: Little brother to the rescue.

choices: a chaotic science book from your father.
1131221122.content:
You hurried to the twin's bedroom and immediately panicked as you heard them both let out a frightened scream. You threw open the door with your magic and charged in to see the twins jump at your sudden entrance. They were both looking fearful but also blushing as if they had got caught with their hands in the cookie jar. Upon seeing what they were doing, you sighed in relief then looked at them with a bit of annoyance.

"You both know better than to watch horror movies." Scolding, you said. You changed the channel to a more kid friendly station then asked. "Did either of you see a large faded book appear in your room?"

"You mean that one?" Pointing, Ina asked.

You looked to see an open chaotic science book giving lessons to a large number of stuffed animals the twins had teleported around it. Seeing it, you could not help but smile a little as Tia added, "It wanted to teach someone chaotic science so we gave it some students."

"Innocent mischief." Shaking your head, you thought. "They are going to be a handful when they become teenagers." You then pulled out your cellphone and called mom. "There is another book in the twin's bedroom but they have it occupied with stuffed animals."

Mom appeared behind you and gave a bemused grin. "Thank you Geo for give us sarcastic daughters." Ruefully, she whispered. She then waved her hand, causing the book to vanish. "I have sent the book back to its sender with a warning they have violated the royal household. The head witch will hear of this."

You nodded, knowing that your grandmother, Ella Mist was the head witch. "Was there any book inside Joe's bedroom?"

Mom sighed before replying. "We found..."
1131221122.title: Innocent mischief.

11312211223.content:
Mom sighed before replying. "We found nothing, for the moment."

"Who do you think sent the books?" Wincing, I asked.

"Your uncle, Maddox Mage." Appearing once again, dad replied. "Apparently, it was his wish to test this family's response to outside interference." He cracked a grin. "As the head mad scientist, I understand his needs to experiment so I accommodated him."

You remembered uncle Maddox being a hair shorter than dad with longish black hair and green eyes. He was what mom called the black sheep of the family due to a multitude of events that had placed him on the radar of the Correction Oversight Department, the police of the mad science world.

Mom grinned. "Was our reactions what he had anticipated?" Calmly, she asked.

Dad chuckled. "He was proud of his nephew's quick thinking and ability to take swift action in an emergency." Smiling, he replied. "He was surprised by Ina and Tia's ability to fool the book into giving lessons to inanimate objects." He then turned to you, his grin broadening into a goofy smile. "He was perplexed by your ability to fight off the book long enough to obtain assistance."

"Like mother, like daughter..." Proud, mom said. "Gina is a flower with thorns."

You blushed at that. "What response did you give uncle Maddox?"

Dad gave a mad grin before chuckling. "He now sports a rather dashing black eye to remind him of his failed experiment..."
11312211223.title: nothing.

113122112231.content:
Later on, you walked to Joe's room to find the door open. He turned, hearing you knock and waved you in. Joe was pouring over the literature offered by both Spellblossom and Witchbloom all girls boarding schools as well as Eliete Scientiam all boys boarding school. "Mom and dad gave them to me." Sighing, he said. "I guess I will be going to one or the other."

You sighed but managed a smile. "Which one speaks to you?"

"Well, other than the requirement of being a girl, Spellblossom and Witchbloom have a certain appeal." Serious, Joe replied. "However, Elite Scientiam has me intrigued with what it has to offer and I don't have to change my gender." He shook his head. "It's a coin toss, really... both have me curious but I can only pick one."

"I know your last girl experience wasn't the best foot forward." Softly, you said. "But... would you consider being a teenage girl and try magic?"

"I'm not sure." Wincing, Joe said. "Ina and Tia..."

"Will be kept out of this one." Firmly, you interrupted. "After you try magic for a few days, dad can show you more of his chaotic science."

"I'm not sure of that either." Wrinkling his nose, Joe replied. "Dad' lectures leave a lot to be desired."

"So it's being a girl and long lectures you are not comfortable with." Calmly, you said.

Joe nodded. "Basically... yes." Softly, he said. He bit his lip. "Any suggestions?"

You smiled. "If you had a way to change yourself back, would you consider becoming a girl and learn some magic?"

Joe looked at you, curious then...
113122112231.title: Later, you talk to Joe.

choices: mom arrives to join in the conversation
Joe insists on rejecting both science and magic
Dad leaves you to talk with your brother
12.content:
"... With his father" mom said.

Instinctively, you blurted out, "And you're okay with that?"

"Geo is still his father, Gina. True, I distrust his motives on this matter, but I made him promise that nothing underhanded happens" mom said in a slightly uncomfortable voice. You knew that she knew you own opinions on this matter; how this mad science has driven your family apart, and that she would sooner have Joanna fulfil her athletic dreams from a feminine perspective. "Besides, Gina, Joe with discover the truth soon. Maybe, after the twins little prank, the truth coming from your father is best."

You grimaced; last week Tia and Ina decided it would be a good idea to use their teleportation skills on an unsuspecting Joe, Using teleportation, they switched his athletic gear for yours, causing more than slight embarrassment. That episode came close to mom revealing the truth, Joe extremely puzzled, and the twins grounded.

"I suppose so" you said. "So where is dad?"

"Outside, in the back garden" mom said.

You gave a slight nod, as you wanted to say a few things of your own. Walking over, you caught the tail end of their conversation. "That's why you cannot escape your fate, Joe. You saw what that 'prank' did. Trust me. Now, I promised not to make an overt push, but you need to consider learning about the sciences so you can protect yourself. We... have company. Gina" dad said, as you walked outside. Dad appeared fairly normal and generally unchanged, but Joe understandably looked pale, almost sick.
12.title: With his father.

121.content:
"What your father failed to mention was that Ina and Tina were both punished for their little prank against you, Joe." Stepping out, mom said. "The only reason they got any training was because their powers developed at a very early age."

"Your own powers, though developing at a later age, are extraordinarily strong on an epic scale." Smiling, dad said. "Like father, like son."

"But why tell me now?" Wincing, Joe demanded. "Why all this when..."

"When you are so close to realizing your dreams?" Softly, mom asked. Joe nodded to which mom sighed. "Up until now, neither your father or I had any idea which power you would possess; magic or chaotic science."

"Unfortunately, you are the proverbial coin that lands on its side." Serious dad added. "Even now, when you could discover your power any minute, there is no telling which way you will fall."

"What does that mean for me?" Worried, Joe asked.

"It means you have the unique ability to choose which power you want; magic or mad science." Serious, you replied. "Most kids don't get that choice."

"I see..." Nervous, Joe said. "What would you suggest, mom?"

Mom sighed. "Personally, I would rather see you become my fourth daughter and a witch." Honestly, she said. "However, that choice is reserved for you alone. I can only guide you and hope you make the right choice."

Joe turned to dad, the same question in mind. Dad cleared his throat before smiling. "Your mother has three daughters, all with the power of magic." Calmly, he said. "By learning the sciences, you and I will establish a fair balance in the family. Also, it will enable you to protect the family from virtually any threat as my occupation requires much of my time."

"In other words, you will be shipped off to a boarding school to learn how to control those powers of science." Softly, mom said. "You will be away from the family for a full year."

"As was our dear daughter, Gina." Grinning, dad countered.

"This is beginning to feel like a tug of war." Wincing, Joe whispered.

You winced in return, wondering what you could do to help without getting caught in the middle of mom and dad's little love tiff. Reaching a decision you take advantage of mom and dad being focused on each other to...
121.title: caught in the middle.

choices: The matter is dropped for now.
1212.content:
"Joe, it is very rare for a witch or witch boy to have the power to choose if he or she wants to be a witch or a mad scientist." Serious, you explained. "On one side, dad has no one else to pass his knowledge to."

"On the other side, mom pretty much had to raise me on her own." Sighing, Joe said. He winced, hope in his eye. "Can't I just learn both?"

"Only girls can work real magic, Joe." Wincing, you said. "Only boys can work mad science."

"So its stay a boy and learn mad science from a father I barely know or literally lose my man card and learn magic from you and mom." Worried, Joe said. "No pressure there..."

"Normally, you would be learning mad science whether you liked it or not." Serious, you said. "Only because the choice is yours, mom and dad are pressing you to favor their power."

"What are the pros and the cons of each?" Curious, Joe asked.

You sighed. "Well, both can easily help you achieve your goal of entering the Olympics." Softly, you replied. "Other than the prerequisite of being a girl to learn magic, the two powers are almost identical with the exception of terms and procedures."

"Then its down to mom wanting another daughter and dad wanting to keep his son..." Tearing up, Joe muttered. "How petty can you get?"

"Its more complicated than that, Joe." Wincing, you said.

"If the two powers are nearly identical with the exception of gender and procedures, why all the hoopla over trying to get me to choose one over the other?!"

You sighed, trying to find a way to reach him.
1212.title: tell Joe your side.

choices: dad tries to open the secret door.
12121.content:
"Dad is the head mad scientist." Softly, you replied. "He is the leader of the secret world of super science and chaotic energy. As his son, you are next in line for the throne."

"Then its a matter of pride for him." Sighing, Joe said. "What about mom?"

"Only girls can work magic but it is customary for a boy turned girl to become head witch." Serious, you replied. "Right now, mom is the next in line but because you are her only son..."

"She would like to see me succeed her." Moping, Joe finished. He moaned, looking miserable. "What a mess!"

"That's why all the hoopla, as you put it." Frowning, you said. "Both will be proud of you no matter what you decide but they both want to be the one to take you under their wing."

Joe began to sob. "I don't want to break this family apart!" Crying, he shouted. "I rather be normal than have to decide!"

"Normal is a relative term, dear boy." Cutting in, dad said. "I believe what you need is the means to make a more educated decision."

Joe paused, looking up at dad and nodded. "That would help."

Dad smiled. "Splendid!" Cheerfully, he said. "Your mother shall show you her little private corner of the house and then I will show you mine."

"You are letting me go first?" Surprised, mom asked.

Dad grinned. "I'm merely saving the best for last."

Mom rolled her eyes at that then turned to you and Joe. "Gina, I want you to keep an eye on your brother while we are in there." Firmly but kindly, she said. "Don't let him touch anything."

You nodded then led Joe by the hand to the kitchen where mom turned the knobs on the stove to specific numbers then hit the cancel button. The stove slid into the wall, revealing a stairwell under the floor.

"Come on, bro." Smiling, you said. "You are going to love this."

Joe followed silently down the stairwell as the stove moved back into position above them...
12121.title: You explain further.

121211.content:
You lead Joe down the stone staircase into a massive cavern seemingly just below the house. Seeing your bother's worrisome expression, you giggled. "The doorway under the stove has a teleport enchantment on it." Bemused, you explained. "We are miles away from the house so no worries of it falling in."

"Anyone unaccompanied by a witch will find themselves teleported somewhere at random so don't you try to enter without me or Gina present." Smiling, mom added.

Upon reaching the cavern floor, Joe looked around in awe. The walls at the cavern's far ends seemed to have been lined with an endless number of books from the floor to the high ceiling. There was also a vast circular garden with a wide variety of plants growing and several table stations which were used for any number of reasons. You smiled as he gazed upon the various broomsticks hanging in a glass display and the seemingly endless shelves of vials and beakers filled with potions in another, both locked tight.

"This is just the main room of mom's lair." Smiling, you said. "There are several smaller caverns further in for more advanced forms of magic."

"One step at a time, Gina." Lightly scolding, mom said. "This cavern alone holds a lot for Joe to take in; it will take a while for him absorb it all."

"What do you do down here?" Curious, Joe asked.

"I come here for various reasons." Calmly, mom said. "I come here to practice my magic, learn new spells and potions, make potions for various reasons and..." She giggled before finishing. "And to get away from your father for a short while when he drives me crazy."

Joe chuckled at that then asked. "What did you want to show me first?"

Mom smiled. "What would you like to see first?"

After a moment of thought, Joe replied...
121211.title: Inside mom's lair.

choices: Joe manages to stay in the air for a while.
Joe turns into a girl while flying around.
1212111.content:
"That's an interesting choice." Bemused, mom said. "Are you curious if a witch can fly a broom of if you can fly one as a boy?"

"Both, actually." To your grin, Joe replied. "Gina said the two powers are very similar so..."

"Similar does not necessarily mean the same." Grinning, you said. "There are certain subtle differences between the two powers other than gender prerequisites."

"Still, if you really want to try, I can walk you through it." Smiling, mom said. "Just don't be surprised if the broom throws you off."

"The brooms have a mind of their own?" Surprised, Joe asked.

You and mom laughed. "Not exactly." Amused, mom replied. "The power of a mad scientist can charge a broom but it makes the spells and enchantments controlling it unstable."

"Oh; okay..." Pouting, Joe said. "Does that mean I can't ride one as a boy?"

"Well, a rare few mad scientists have managed to fly a broom for a short distance." Smiling, mom said. "Though they looked way out of place doing it." She giggled. "Your father was one of them; gave my mother and I quite the surprise."

"What happened?" Curious, Joe asked.

Mom smiled. "He crashed through my bedroom window." Ruefully, she replied. "That's actually how we first met."

Joe blushed, trying not to laugh. "That had to be awkward."

Mom smiled, blushing slightly herself. "You have no idea." She sighed. "Maybe someday I will tell you the entire story." She then motioned to the glass display case. "Do you want to try to fly a broom? I promise I won't let you crash too badly."

Joe blushed even more then replied, "Sure, I guess."

Both you and mom smiled as mom then opened the glass display and selected a broom. After giving Joe a brief number of instructions, he mounted the broom for his first try...
1212111.title: The broomsticks.

choices: After the tour, it's dad's turn.
12121114.content:
To both yours and mom's surprise, Joe almost instantly transformed into a girl after taking to the air on the broomstick. Joe squealed and giggled with delight, flying around the cavern; apparently unaware of his, or rather her transformation. When mom called Joe back, she landed a bit clumsily but managed; changing back into a boy almost instantly upon dismounting the broomstick.

"I did it!" Pleased with himself, Joe said. "That was fun!"

"I'm glad you liked it, kiddo." Smiling, mom said. "Let's move on with the rest of the tour."

"Can I try flying it again when we're done?" Eager, Joe asked.

Mom shook her head. "It's best we don't risk anything unfortunate happening by testing fate." Bemused, she said. "You were lucky this time, I think." After a thought, she handed Joe a small basket and pointed to a near by strawberry patch. "Do me a favor and pick a few strawberries from the garden there; we'll have them for dessert tonight."

Joe smiled and hurried over to the strawberries with the basket in hand as mom turned to you with a look of concern. "Joe is on a thin line between magic and mad science." Whispering, she said. "If he does not make a decision soon, his own body and power will make it for him."

"Can you sense which way his power is leaning?" Wincing, you asked.

Mom shook her head. "No; it's too early to tell just yet but I do know that he only has a few days before he will no longer have a choice of his own."

You sighed at that and the two of you continued the tour.
12121114.title: On a thin line.

choices: harmlessly blew up in Joe's face.
121211142.content:
After Joe had finished picking a good amount of strawberries, you and mom lead him to the potion display case. "This is where I store some of my more potent potions." Serious, mom said. "I keep them locked up and magically sealed to prevent accidents."

"Are they dangerous?" Wincing, Joe asked.

"Most of them will forever change your life." Cryptically, you replied.

"There are many potions that can also save your life." Motioning to the display case, mom added. "Still, toying with anything unknown to you has it dangers." She sighed. "Mad scientists can make their own version of potions only they call them serums."

"Can a chaotic born boy make a potion?" Curious, Joe asked.

Mom smiled. "Would you like to find out?" Bemused, she asked.

Joe nodded, making mom smile more. "Come with me into the garden, then. I will walk you through a simple spell from beginning to end."

You followed behind mom and Joe to a small table where mom walked Joe through the mixing of raw ingredients to the final mixing of his first potion. "Be certain you have exact amounts, Joe." Instructing him, mom said. "Too much or too little can greatly change both the strength and effectiveness of the potion."

You watched, bemused as Joe added the final ingredient to what would have been a simple gender potion then took a step back as the potion...
121211142.title: Mom shows Joe her potions.

1212111421.content:
... harmlessly blew up in Joe's face, covering it with a fine dark ash. You fought the urge to giggle as mom smiled in bemusement. "What happened?" Confused, Joe asked. "Did I mix the ingredients wrong?"

"Interesting..." Bemused, you thought. "He turns into a girl while flying the broom but making a potion blows up in his face. I wonder if the connection lies within his interests; chemistry was never his favorite subject."

"You did everything right only your magic power is dormant thus not strong enough to make a stable potion." Smiling, mom said. "Any normal boy or girl who attempts this would only have a mixture of plants and water which would do nothing more than upset their stomach."

"How do mad scientists make their serums then?" Curious, Joe asked.

Mom handed Joe a damp cloth to wipe off his face. "Mad scientists use different plants in their serums though they are of the same genera of plants witches use." Calmly, she explained.

"You mean of the same family of plants, right?" Tilting his head, Joe asked.

You nodded. "Exactly. Some plants are agreeable to magic while others are agreeable to chaotic energy but the ingredients are only part of what makes a potion or serum."

"We will get into that later." Serious, mom said. "Potion and serum making are both an exact art and will take much time to explain. The point behind this demonstration is not to meddle with what you do not understand."

Joe nodded and the tour continued with...
1212111421.title: harmlessly blew up in Joe's face.

choices: Is too powerful for your male form to hold.
too unstable to make you a witch.
is too weak to make you a witch.
12121114211.content:
"I want to try something, Joe." Softly, mom said. "Only I need your permission first."

"What did you want to try?" Curious, Joe asked.

"I want to try the flame test on you." Smiling, mom said.

Seeing Joe's hesitation, you gave him a kind smile of reassurance. "The flame test is a harmless flame in your hand that measures how much magic you have." Smiling, you explained. "Only you have to be a girl to summon it."

"Boys of chaotic blood summon what they call a spark or a small sphere of ball lightning to their hand as their measure of power." Calmly, mom added. "Only I want to see how much magic lies dormant within you."

"It won't trap me as a girl, will it?" Wincing, Joe asked.

"Normally, no." Calmly, you said.

"But there are exceptions." Nervous, Joe guessed.

"In very rare cases only." Soothingly, mom said. "Will you allow a temporary change to see how much magic you have?"

Joe sighed and, although reluctant, agreed. Mom smiled and cast the spell, painlessly changing Joe into his female equivalent in clothing closely matching what he had on. "Now then... Joanie." Grinning, mom said. "To summon your test flame, you must first find your center then focus your energy into your womb."

"Is that why boys can't work magic?" Curious, Joe, or rather, Joanie asked. "Because they don't have a womb?"

"Partially." Smiling, you replied. "Focus on your center then build your energy in your womb and imagine it igniting in your right hand as a harmless flame."

Although uncertain, Joanie closed her eyes and managed to summon a flame to her right hand. Both you and mom giggled as she jumped, letting out a yelp of fight seeing it. Only as you and mom examined the flame, you both sighed. "What?" Worried, Joanie asked.

Mom sighed then replied. "I'm sorry, Joanie but the flame test shows that your magic..."
12121114211.title: the flame test.

choices: Mom talks to Elle Mist, the head witch.
121211142111.content:
"What are you saying?" Unnerved, Joe demanded. "Am I going to be a girl and a witch no matter what anyone does?"

"I'm sorry, Joanie." Softly, mom said. "I am an expert in combat magic; I can read test flames and yours is more powerful than any I have seen in a teenager in years."

You winced, knowing mom was holding something back but reading test flames was not your strong suit. You could tell Joanie's test flame was extremely powerful as it literally lit the entire room but there was something in the way it was burning that made you wonder.

"Mom is very rarely wrong about these things... Joanie." Softly, you said. "We will try to change you back into a boy so dad will have his chance to show you his laboratory."

"Still... there is very little chance we will be successful." Wincing, mom said. "Please do not think poorly of us; we only want what is best for you." Mom cast a spell and Joe successfully returned to his male state. "Please escort Joe back up into the house." Serious, she said. "Your father is no doubt losing patience."

Albeit reluctantly, you escorted Joe back to the stone staircase while mom pulled out a cellphone and dialed a long number. You recognized the tone pattern as your grandmother's number; she was the head witch. You used your magic to enhance your hearing but only caught the first part of the conversation. Still, it was enough to make you worry. "Madam head witch, we have a situation." Softly, mom said. "Joe is close to becoming a male familiar; please advise me on the proper course of action."
121211142111.title: Is too powerful for your male form to hold.

1212111421112.content:
A familiar was usually a cat or owl with insane magical reserves. They could not use this magic but they could grant part or all of it to a witch they bond with. For a familiar to be a human was rare, for that human to be male was more rare still. If Joe was truly becoming a male familiar, he would literally be one in a billion. As such, he would become a very powerful witch if permanently transformed into a girl. If he were to remain a boy, mad scientist or not, every witch wanting to increase their power or worse regain it after having it taken away would be after him. You decided to wait and listen at the top of the stairs, focusing both your magic and you ears on the conversation inside mom's cavern lair. What you heard left you numb.

"There is a balance to everything, Mona." Serious, Ella said. "I deeply apologize for not telling you; for hiding this from you but I could not bear the thought of your husband discovering this."

"Discovering what?" Concerned, mom demanded. "What have you been hiding from us?"

There was a pause before Ella replied, "It concerns your daughter, Gina... she is a Female Chaotic Familiar. Her reserves of chaotic energy are literally off the known charts; it is only her powerful magic that is keeping her from transforming into a male and a powerful mad scientist."

Mom turned pale. "Gina... a female chaotic familiar?" Shocked, she asked. "How?!"

"She is the first born in this world, Mona." Sadly, Ella said. "I have no answers other than there is zero doubt she has that power within her." She sighed. "If word of Gina's hidden power got out, your husband will become protective to a nightmarish degree."

Mom was shaking at this point. "What am I to do?"

"I cannot order this, Mona." Darkly, Ella said. "However, to save Joe and Gina from becoming targets for the rest of their lives, they must be permanently transformed."

At this point, you were shaking, fearful for both Joe and yourself.
1212111421112.title: Dark Balance.

choices: You and Joe take the tour.
12121114211121.content:
Not knowing what else to do, you grabbed Joe's hand and ran out the exit and back into the kitchen where you were surprised to see dad patiently waiting. There was a smile on his face when you and Joe emerged but it turned into a deep frown of concern upon seeing your pale and panicked expression and teary eyes. "Explain what happened, Gina." Firmly, he commanded.

You began to cry, worried and frightened before blurting out, "Joe is a male familiar and grandma said I'm a chaotic familiar!"

Dad raised a single eyebrow before locking his jaw in decision. With a snap of his fingers, you and Joe found yourselves in a room overlooking a massive chamber somewhere that was buzzing with machines and robots. "I will need to run a few tests to confirm these findings, Gina." Serious, dad said. "If the head witch's theory is correct, you would be the very first of your kind in this world and a highly sought after prize." He then turned to Joe. "If you are indeed a familiar, Joe as your mother theorizes, you too would be a highly sought after prize."

Thus the tests began with dad taking a sample of blood from both you and Joe and running it through a machine inside the room. While the machine did its work, dad threw what looked like ball lightning at you! A shriek escaped your lips but you relaxed seeing that it never came near you but merely circled you and then Joe before circling you again. Seeing this, dad raised a single eyebrow again before grinning. "I was right, as usual."

"What are you doing, dad?" Startled, you asked.

Dad canceled the ball lighting that was circling us then turned to the machine before returning to us, smiling. "It is as I had suspected from the beginning." Smiling, he said. "Neither of you have anything to fear. What we have here is not a case of two familiars but an extremely rare case of distant twins."

"Distant twins?" Confused, you asked. You frowned. "I never heard of it."

"That is because it does not happen in the witching world but in our world, dear Gina." Serious, dad explained. "You and Joe were born exactly one year apart; plus or minus a few seconds."

"What does that have to do with..." Confused, you started.

"In chaotic families, extremely powerful males remain in the womb longer, incorporeal or ghost like up to a full year." Cutting you off, dad said. "In extremely rare cases, you have twins with the, and I mean no disrespect when I say this, weaker twin being born last to take in more power to form a balance." He grinned. "In Laments terms, you were supposed to be born on the same day only Joe held back a year, taking in more power."

Your jaw dropped being completely thunderstruck by the news. You and Joe were twins?! It did explain a lot as you and Joe were often mistaken as twins by your friends, Thomas Lore and Rachel Scott. A tiny smile appeared onto your face, seeing that they were more on target than they had realized. Dad nodded, smiling. "I take it that your mother came to the conclusion that Joe was a familiar by examining his test flame." You nodded to which dad chuckled. "She failed to take into account his chaotic energy which would have also been present."

"Flame reading is not my strong suit." Wincing, you said.

"Then I shall explain." Smiling, dad said. He turned to Joe. "Use the same method your mother explained to summon your spark, dear boy while Gina, you summon your flame."

You did as you were asked as did Joe. Both of you were surprised to find that they were moving in sync with each other. "What does this mean?" Worried, Joe asked.

"It is the rare but true testament of magic and chaotic twins." Kindly, dad said. "One power augments the other despite their obvious differences." He chuckled. "If you will notice, Gina, your flame is sparking with electricity while Joe's spark seems to be on fire on the inside."

"What are you trying to tell us?" Wincing, Joe asked.

Dad motioned to the flame and spark still burning in our hands. "Although one part is a flame and the other is lightning, they are both a form of fire and are thus allies." Simply, he said. He smiled, urging you both to cancel your flame and spark. "Regardless of what fate has in store for the two of you, know that you are twins; be there for each other."

Joe smiled giving you a one armed hug. "We will."

You smiled then turned to dad, concerned. "Grandma said we should both be permanently transformed; what should we do?"

Dad chuckled. "That won't do much good." Bemused, he said. "So long as your powers are even, you would not stay transformed for long." He motioned to the window overlooking his laboratory. "Are you two ready to tour my inner sanctum?"
12121114211121.title: Distant Twins.

choices: You and Joe take the tour.
121211142111213.content:
Mom appeared inside the room, looking less than happy. "When I heard the door back into the kitchen fly open, I knew that Gina had stayed back long enough to listen in on my conversation with the head witch." Irritated, she said. "May I assume she told you what she heard and you ran tests to confirm it?"

"I did indeed only key pieces of evidence were not calculated in the witching world's investigation; thus you and the head witch came to the incorrect conclusion." Smiling. dad replied. "Gina and Joe are what we chaotic scientists call distant twins."

Dad then went on to explain his own findings to which mom gave a low sigh of relief. "They are augmenting each other's powers." Softly, she said. "Only if one becomes stronger than the other the weaker twin will transform."

"Only if they were born on the same day." Calmly, dad countered. "Joe was born almost exactly one year after Gina, plus or minus a few seconds. That laps prevents the twin phenomenon from taking hold on either one of them despite the fact they are magically and chaotically linked."

"Then it is that alien link and augmentation that gives them the signature of a familiar." Worried, mom said. "If their unalike powers were to mix..."

"They are already mixed." Serious, dad said. "That is what gives them this signature." He sighed before adding, "Regardless of what happens, each of them will be ascending to the throne; it is only a matter of determining which throne each will take when this is over."

Mom sighed in return then turned to dad's laboratory.
121211142111213.title: Mom appears inside the room.

1212111421112131.content:
"You have nothing to fear, Gina." Calmly, dad said. "The laboratory does not transform or harm any unauthorized personnel, it merely teleports them away from the facility. Just as every witch specializes in a certain form of magic, every chaotic scientist specializes in a certain discipline of science; mine is machinery."

"Mom seemed very worried about us being distant twins." Uncomfortable, you said. "Is there something you are not telling us?"

Dad gave you a patient smile. "Normal witch born twins of alike or unlike power augment each other in their own ways, as you are aware." Calmly, dad explained. "In this world, a witch boy would become a literal juggernaut if allowed to reach adulthood while the witch twin would become a very powerful witch. If they were both witches, that power would increase ten fold."

"However with distant twins, its different." Guessing correctly, Joe said.

Dad nodded. "In my world, the same principle applies to normal twins but with reverse effects, the boy would become a powerful mad scientist and the girl would become the juggernaut, hence we call them Amazons." Calmly, he said. "With the rare case of distant twins both reach epic status almost immediately upon finishing puberty. One or the other would be guaranteed crowned the next head mad scientist."

"That's insane." Whispering, Joe said.

Dad gave a proud smile. "You two are an unprecedented case; no distant twins of magic and chaotic science have ever before been born. I theorize that, you will both not only be magically and chaotically powerful but also juggernauts upon reaching adulthood. With your magic and chaotic link, you are both guaranteed ascension to the throne."

Joe's jaw dropped while you frowned with deep concern. "Wouldn't such news cause a panic?" Worried, you demanded.

"All new discoveries can potentially cause a panic, dear Gina." Calmly, dad countered. "There was a panic when your mother and I were married; both powers under the control of the same family made many quite nervous." He chuckled. "The fact I listen to your grandmother eased many of those concerns."

You released a breath, relieved, causing dad to smile. "Let us begin the tour with..."
1212111421112131.title: You and Joe take the tour.

choices: The robot returned with the dmaged robot.
12121114211121311.content:
You and Joe looked about in awe at the various computers and machines with robots of all shapes and sizes scurrying between them like a hive of bees. "Every computer, and robot is a part of machinery as they are all, in their own right, machines." Calmly, he explained. "Even we humans are machines but of a bio-mechanical nature."

"Perhaps you can explain something, dad." Curious, Joe said. "I turned into a girl while riding a broomstick and managed to fly it fairly well but when making a potion..."

Dad grinned. "It blew up in your face."

"How did you know?" Wincing, Joe asked.

Dad chuckled. "The broom accepts the rider not the other way around." Bemused, dad said. "It is an enchanted object so the magic is already there. With a potion, magic must be introduced and when that magic is dormant, it causes the potion to become unstable and harmlessly blow up." He paused, smiling. "I am surprised Gina or mom did not explain this."

"We didn't know he was aware he changed." Blushing, you said.

Dad smiled. "We chaotic scientists have our own version of a broomstick only we call then anti-gravity vehicles or A.G.V.s." He motioned to what looked like a slender vacuum cleaner with a lean engine along the main body where the bag would be and thrust controls where the base would be. At the top was a pair of handle bars where the accelerator and break were mounted along with a small control panel. "This is an early model of which I designed made to keep up with your mother when I was courting her. I wanted it to look as close to a broomstick as I could."

You smiled at that. "Mom told us that you crashed into her bedroom window while trying to ride a broom." Bemused, you said. "What were you doing on it?"

"Research." Simply, dad replied. "A story for another time."

Just then, a robot came up to dad and began to speak in beeps, whines, and ticks. Dad sighed before turning to you and Joe. "One of the robots is..."

"Running into walls." Finishing, Joe said. "The little guy said a machine leaked oil onto its video sensors while he was making repairs and it is trying to get to a wash station."

"You can understand it?" Surprised, you asked.

Joe shrugged. "Can't you?"

Dad chuckled. "Joe, why don't you tell the, err, little guy to escort the robot to us so we may assess the damages."

Joe nodded then turned to the robot and spoke in a similar series of beeps, whines, and ticks. The robot nodded its head and hurried off to perform its task. Dad then turned to Gina, grinning. "It is called binary speak." Calmly, he explained. "It is similar to witch language. All chaotic scientists can speak this; I have taught Joe the language when he was very young."

In a strange way, it made sense. The wold of magic was parallel to the world of chaotic science so everything had to have some form of equivalent. Curious, you asked, "Would the same apply to a witch trying to ride an, err, A.G.V.?"

Dad smiled, motioning to the device. "Care to find out?"

You gave a nervous giggle, not knowing what to do...
12121114211121311.title: the machines.

choices: dad asks Joe to try to repair the robot.
dad asks you to try to repair the robot.
121211142111213111.content:
"I suppose I could try." Wincing, you said.

Dad smiled. "Splendid." He motioned to the device. "Like the broomstick, the power is already there so you need not add any of your own. Just will it to fly."

"I'm afraid I'm going to crash this thing." Nervous, you said.

"Do not fear it." Bemused, dad said. "It will sense it and take evasive action, thinking its rider is in jeopardy which will result in a crash."

Although uncertain, you mounted the A.G.V. which immediately responded by lifting you off the ground and taking off high above the machines and robots. You screamed in fright as the device flew at maddening speeds all around the laboratory. Dad laughed, clapping his hands; he seemed to have been enjoying the spectacle. You pulled up on the handlebars, hoping to slow the device down only it caused you to do loops at high speed, making you scream again. Finally, you managed to gain some control and bring the device to a halt back on the launch platform. Dad was still laughing as you dismounted, blushing and fuming.

"I'm glad you had a good laugh at my expense." Pouting, you complained.

Dad roughed up your hair, chuckling. "Don't be too upset." Amused, he said. "You did rather well considering it was your first attempt."

"Does this select its rider like a witch's broom?" Curious, you asked.

Dad nodded. "The A.G.V. has a limited artificial intelligence which allows it to bond with the rider and assist him in combat." Calmly, he said. "A witch's broom is similar only its 'intelligence' is magic based." He smiled, amused. Normally, this one only allows me to mount it but it seems to like you."

"It didn't turn me into a boy, did it?" Wincing, you demanded.

Dad merely shrugged in response; not the answer you were looking for. You were about to press when the robot who approached us earlier arrived with a damaged robot in tow...
121211142111213111.title: you reluctantly agree.

1212111421112131112.content:
"Why don't you try to repair the little guy, Joe." Smiling, dad suggested.

"I- I'm not sure I know how." Wincing, Joe replied. "I don't want to hurt him."

"You know more than you think." Calmly, dad said. "Just take a good look at it, err, him and tell me how you think he should be fixed."

Albeit reluctantly, Joe knelt down and examined the damaged robot. "It looks like the oil got into some kind of air intake." After a moment, he said. "It must be wracking havoc on his circuitry."

"That's a fair evaluation though only partially correct." Knelling down, dad said. "The oil that hit the robot was under a lot of pressure so it also blew out the lenses protecting the optic sensors." He paused then asked, "How do you think this one should be repaired?"

Joe thought for a moment then replied. "Well, first, the oil needs to be removed but I'm not sure how unless it can be teleported off of him."

"Very good." Smiling, dad said. "We can easily teleport all of the oil off of the robot with our chaotic science but that does not repair the damaged circuitry or the optic sensors."

"Well, replacing the lenses should not be a challenge and replacing the damaged circuits should be easy enough..." After a thought, Joe said. He gasped as the oil vanished and the robots sensors were good as new with a dull flash. "What happened?"

"You repaired the robot." Simply, dad replied. "You are a natural at machines. This explains why you were able to fly the broom and repair the robot so quickly, though you did not realize it."

"What of me?" Wincing, you asked.

Dad chuckled. "To answer your earlier question, you did not change genders while flying the A.V.G. it does not possess that power." Bemused, he said. "You merely found a way to make it obey your commands through magic, though I suspect it was more on a subconscious level like Joe's transformation into a girl while on the broomstick."

"But how?" Worried, you asked. "Two alike powers cannot mix."

"No, two alike powers cannot be used at the same time." Turning serious, dad countered. "You have chaotic energy within you so yo were able to control the A.V.G. to some point. It was only your year of experience that allowed you to do it without changing genders."

"Is it the same for chaotic scientists trying to fly a witch's broom?" Curious, Joe asked.

Dad grinned. "I flew your mother's broomstick, remember?"

You and Joe giggled at that and the tour continued with...
1212111421112131112.title: Alike powers.

12121114211121311121.content:
Dad's serums were all stored in a huge transparent room which contained shelves upon selves of viles of different colored liquids and powders. "Not all serums are in liquid form." Calmly, dad explained. "Some are stored as powder to keep them stable until needed. The various colors, although not really necessary, are so to more easily identify their purpose."

"Much like magical potions." Thoughtful, you said. "Only the ingredients for serums use different plants which are more agreeable to chaotic power."

"You are partially correct, Gina." Smiling, dad said. "For every potion, there is a serum counterpart. However, the ingredients are not as different as you might think."

"What do you mean?" Curious, Joe asked.

Dad smiled. "Serums use different plants but of the same genera used in the ingredients for making potions." Bemused, he replied. "These plants are more agreeable to chaotic energy but are of the same plant family." He chuckled. "By knowing and understanding the various species of plants, you can make any serum a potion or visa versa by simply swapping out key elements more agreeable to your root power."

"That's incredible!" Smiling, Joe said.

"Still, only a witch can make a potion and only a chaotic scientist can make a serum." Serious, you said. "the two powers are more different than alike."

Dad turned to you, amused. "Care to test that theory, my dear?" Smiling, he asked.

You rolled your eyes. "Okay, dad." Albeit reluctantly, you said. "I'll play your game."

Dad grinned before summoning a notebook to his hand. "Splendid!" Bemused, he said. "You will attempt to make a simple babbling serum while I attempt to make a simple babbling potion."

You nodded in agreement though you saw it as a waste of time. A babbling potion was used to cause the one it was splashed on to babble like a drunken idiot until a counter potion or spell was given. The ingredients listed on the notebook were nearly identical to the potion; using different plants but of the same genera. Following the directions exactly, you turned to dad for the final instructions only to have him holding up what appeared to be a finished potion!

Instinctively, you raised your magical defenses to which dad smiled more. "How did you manage to make a potion?!" Startled, you demanded. "You are not a woman or a witch!"

Dad threw his head back with a maniacal laugh before eying you with an almost sadistic grin making you feel uncomfortable. "I didn't." Amused, he said. "I only made the initial mixture. When you raised your defenses, it gave the mixture the final ingredient required to make it a potion." He grinned more before finishing, "Your magic."

"How is that possible?" Taken back, you asked.

Joe winced. "Dad, you are frightening me..." Frowning, he said.

Dad smiled more kindly. "I apologize for causing you two a fright." Calmly, he said. "You see, for any given potion or serum to have power, it only requires magic or chaotic energy to be focused upon it. Many witches and mad scientists alike have made and stored various mixtures without adding their power to avoid accidents."

Your eyes widened as you caught on to dad's reasoning. "So when I raised my defenses against the mixture you made, I inadvertently charged it with my magic, making it a potion."

Dad nodded. "Had I thrown this at you instead, your own magic would have finished the potion upon raising your defenses." Softly, he explained. "Had it hit, you would have taken its full effects and be unable to cast a single spell until another witch gave you the antidote."

Joe shuddered at the thought. "That can't be legal." Whispering, he protested.

"It's not." Turning serious, dad replied. "It's considered 'fighting dirty' by both laws. It is both reckless and dangerous especially if the one throwing the mixture has no clue what he or she had created."

"Is there a way to combat it?" Curious, you asked. "Or does this trick work an everyone?"

Dad chuckled as you held up the mixture you had made. "Once you learn to detect the absence of magic or chaotic energy in any given mixture will you learn when to and not to raise your defenses." Bemused, he said. "I learned that the hard way from your mother."

You smiled at that. "Well, she is an expert in combat magic." Calmly, you said.

Dad nodded. "If a boy were to try to charge a potion, it would harmlessly blow up in his face." Calmly, he said. "The same would occur if a girl tried to charge a serum." He then raised a finger of warning. "There is however, a 'back door' approach but it is highly frowned upon as it has often lead to disaster."

You nodded, knowing what dad was talking about. "The dormant magical power that lies within all witch boys and the dormant chaotic power that lies within all chaotic scientist girls."

"Quite right." Serious, dad said. "This back door approach can only be legally used by the Ironclads and Amazons as their dormant power had already taken root within them."

"The who?" Confused, Joe asked.
12121114211121311121.title: Dad's serums.

121211142111213111211.content:
You sighed. "Ironclads are boys born in a witch family who's magical power had taken root but are too physically powerful for that magic to break the barrier that is keeping them male." Patiently, you explained. "This resulted in the witch born boys gaining impressive physical attributes and acute senses." You frowned. "It also gave them the ability to channel their physical strength into energy for force fields and kinetic blasts for both a defense and offense. Ironclads were both feared and respected by a majority of the witch community."

"They have their own government and their own laws." Jumping in, dad said. "However, there are very few chaotic born boys who had become Ironclads due to their more superior power."

You rolled your eyes at that before Joe turned to dad. "What about the Amazons?" Curious, he asked. "Are they the same only with chaotic power?"

You tried your best not to giggle as dad gave an uncomfortable sigh. "That is correct." Reluctantly, he said. "Amazons are chaotic born girls who's power had taken root but they are too physically strong for the chaotic power to break the barrier that is keeping them female. They have the same powers as the ironclads. They are a respected group among chaotic scientists though they do make a select few fearful."

"They also have their own government and their own laws." Jumping in, you said. "Only very few magic born girls have ever become Amazons."

"Do you think I may become an Ironclad?" Wincing, Joe asked.

"I doubt it." His smile returning, dad replied. "Let's move on."
121211142111213111211.title: Ironclads and Amazons.

choices: You offer an idea of your own.
1212111421112131112113.content:
Nearly an hour later, the stairs to the second floor of your house lifted, revealing a doorway through which you and Joe entered the house. As the stairs lowered back into place, dad turned to Joe, smiling. "What did you make of the tour?"

"It was just a great as mom's tour." Smiling back, Joe replied. "I'm still trying to wrap my head around the fact Gina and I are really twins."

"As am I." Honestly, you said. "Still, it does explain a lot."

"Now that you have had both tours, which do you think you will lean toward?" Entering the room, mom asked. After a pause, she added, "Just curious."

Joe smiled. "You know I can't play favorites, mom."

You tried not to grin at the irony as mom and dad alike had used the very same line on you both as well as the twins. Mom and dad both grinned, bemused before dad said, "You must choose one or the other."

"I choose to walk in both of your footsteps." Smiling, Joe replied. "Care to know how I intend to pull this off?"

You raised a single eyebrow in surprise as mom and dad turned to each other, genuinely surprised which was very rare. "Do tell us of your ambitious plan, Joe." With an air of caution, dad said. "I am curious how you intend to walk on both worlds."

Joe's smile grew, reminding you of dad's smile after winning an argument with mom. "As you told us, I am basically an Ironclad with the powers of a mad scientist." Confident, Joe said. "With that in mind, my powers of magic had taken root only my powers of chaotic science make me too strong to break the barrier that is keeping me male."

"A rather crude assessment but, by definition... correct." Calmly, dad said. "Please continue."

"As I basically have both magic and chaotic powers with in me, I can follow in dad's footsteps while also following in mom's as the power of an Ironclad is basically magic."

"So you have chosen to become the heir to the mad science throne." Frowning, mom said.

"Do I detect a hint of disapproval?" Grinning, dad teased.

Now it was mom's turn to grin only she did not add any remark which you were grateful for as Joe then turned to you. "Since you are basically an Amazon with magical powers, it might be wise if you are trained in the powers and laws of chaotic science."

You frowned at that as dad chuckled. "He does have a point." Bemused, he said.

Wanting support, you turned to mom, your eyes pleading only mom carried a bemused look of her own. "It will allow you to bond with dad and me to bond with Joe." Thoughtful, she said. "It's a rather twisted compromise but a logical one."

You did not like the thought of going away for another year or even six months let alone as a boy to an all boys boarding school for mad science. Mom was no help as she seemed to like Joe's idea of a compromise and judging by the way dad was smiling, he was all for it.

"Um... how about we train each other here at home?" Nervous, you offered. "That way, no one has to be away for a year." You gulped. "I just got back."

"It is workable." Smiling, dad said. "Only you will both have to live in the form of the opposite gender for the year." He chuckled. "No one should even notice; you are 'twins' after all."

"I agree." Smiling as well, mom said. "I believe walking a mile in the other's shoes will be beneficial to both of them. Once Joe is trained in magic..."

"He will then be trained in chaotic science." Grinning madly, dad finished. "I say, this was an ingenious compromise on our son's part. Science prevails once again!"

12121114211121311121133.title: Keeping it in the family.

The following morning, you woke up to the alarm clock in Joe's room to find dad waiting for you to wake up in a chair near his desk. He smiled at you as you caught his eye. "Good morning, Joe." Bemused he said. "Breakfast is ready for you downstairs."

You instinctively covered yourself with a blanket, letting out a masculine shriek. "Dad...!"

Dad chuckled. "Relax, Joe." Smiling, he said. "We are both boys here."

You moaned, remembering that dad was going to train you in the use and law of mad science. "What did you and mom do, switch our bodies?" Grumpily, you demanded.

Dad's smile turned into a grin. "No, we merely changed your genders." Bemused, he said. "You are twins, remember?" He then motioned to the washroom. "Get dressed and come down; the faster you learn, the faster you will be Gina again."

Sighing, you sulked into the washroom, trying to ignore the slight extra weight between your legs, and cleaned yourself up enough to be presentable. Most of Joe's clothing fit, though they were a bit snug. You made a mental note to ask dad why. Upon coming down to the dinning room, you found Joe, or rather, Gina wearing one of your modest skirts and blouses, grumbling under her breath as she ate a plate of pancakes. Mom smiled, seeing you enter. "Your sister, Gina is not too happy that her bust is nearly a full cup larger than yours as a girl." Bemused, she explained. "She had to borrow one of my bras; it's one of the few side effects of twins switching genders."

"As is a transformed girl gaining more muscle mass." Grinning, dad said. "There is a balance; a gain for every loss in both magic and mad science."

You and Gina turned to each other and said, in unison, "You can keep it."

Mom and dad laughed before you were lead to your seat and urged to start eating. "The best start is a hearty breakfast." Smiling, dad explained. "Like magic, mad science is very draining to use so consuming a good dose of protein is essential to quick learning."

"Sure dad." Sighing, you said.

Shortly after breakfast, dad led you to his private study where he sat you down at a small spare desk where you found a literal mountain of books. You threw dad a questioning look only to be given an almost sinister grin. "I want you to read every last page, young man." Smiling, dad said. "Knowledge is the key to power."

"You're joking, right?" Scoffing, you asked. "With the proper spell, I can memorize all of these books in a heart beat."

"Ah, but with the proper spell, all that knowledge can be just as easily erased." Amused, dad countered. "There are no shortcuts to magic or chaotic science. You must learn patience before moving on to the actual studies."

With that said, dad quietly left the room. Judging by the grin on his face, you knew he was enjoying this. You turned to the huge stack of books and sighed. Only upon opening the first book, you realized...

Upon opening the first book, you realized that you had read the entire first page by merely glancing at it and turned to the second only to learn that you had read that just as fast. To your surprise and inner delight, you had read the entire book in less than a minute. What was more surprising was that you could recite the entire book page for page as if you had read it a thousand times. As you moved from book to book, your new speed reading ability became slightly faster and you were able to literally flip through the pages and have the entire book memorized. "This is incredible!" Smiling, you said to yourself. "At this rate, I'll be done in a half hour."

You moved through the books at incredible speed and were done in forty five minutes. As you finished the last book, dad walked in, smiling. "I take it you found that you can speed read as a boy of chaotic blood." Grinning, he said.

"It was incredible." Smiling, you said. "I didn't have to recite any spell, I just had it in me."

"Witches have the same power only most choose to take the easy way out and use a memorization spell." Bemused, dad said. "Only those spells can be countered, leaving the witch or mad scientist with basically zero training and easily defeated."

You blushed at that. "I'm glad I didn't use the memorization spell while I was at Cauldron Academy like some of the other girls did." Honestly, you said. "Mom told me there were no shortcuts and I took that to heart."

Dad smiled. "I know you didn't use the memorization spell." Calmly, he said. "Mom kept me updated on your classes while I was away."

"Why are you always away?" Curious, you demanded.

Dad sighed. "There is still a certain distrust between witches and mad scientists." Frowning, he explained. "As such, I must do all of my official business away from my wife and she must do the same away from me until a more agreeable balance can be agreed upon."

"I thought witches and mad scientists were in a stable state of peace." Confused, you said.

"A stable peace, yes." Serious, dad said. "Only peace does not always include trust. This must be done slowly... no shortcuts." He managed a smile. "Shall we continue..."
1212111421112131112113311.title: No shortcuts.

"Now that you had memorized all of the books, you are ready to move on to the basics." Grinning, dad said. "The advanced classes are more, shall we say... involved."

You sighed at that. "More books...?" Softly, you asked.

"Speak with authority!" Firmly, dad snapped. "For the year you are a boy of chaotic blood, not a delicate magic rose!"

That irritated you and you snapped back, "Even roses have thorns!"

Dad scoffed. "Then show them when you speak to me." Serious, he said. "A chaotic scientist is confident in all aspects of his life." He then grinned. "A timid man is not taken seriously in this field, you must show you have confidence in all that you say."

You sighed, still irritated. "This is unknown territory to me, father." Firmly, you said. "I am at a disadvantage here."

"Magic was unknown territory to you before your training." serious, dad countered. "The only disadvantage you have is your fear to apply your knowledge to break new grounds." He gave a short, mad chuckle. "Top student... its laughable."

Now you were insulted and before you could stop yourself, you summoned your spark before activating a sphere of energy around you. "I'll show you what's laughable..." Angry, you hissed.

Dad threw his head back, laughing madly. "I knew you had potential, lad!" Grinning, he said. "All it took was for me to set a fire in your ego!"

Taken back, you blinked then let out a yelp seeing the energy sphere around you. "What?!"

"It's called a dueling sphere." smiling, dad explained. "Chaotic scientists summon this as a challenge to others in their field and to witches alike." He motioned to the books. "Volume eight, page one hundred, paragraph two, subparagraph one."

"The dueling sphere is the final warning before conflict between two parties of either chaotic science or witchcraft only witches call them warning fields." Reciting the subparagraph, you said. "Only I don't understand how I was able to summon it without supervision."

"You were called a natural at magic at Cauldron Academy." Simply, dad replied. "Apparently, that natural gift also applies to chaotic science." He then grinned again. "Fear is not to be avoided; fear is to be conquered."

A bemused smile formed upon dad's face. "I look forward to witnessing you testing that theory during your training."

Dad smiled. "Much better." Calmly, he said. "We shall move on to..."
12121114211121311121133111.title: Fear is to be conqured.

"You know how a witch casts spells." Grinning, dad said. "Event casting is somewhat different as males born of witch blood do not possess a uterus."

"Okay... you lost me." Confused, you said.

Dad gave a mad chuckle. "You forget that those of chaotic blood come from a parallel world, our physiology is a bit different." Calmly, he said. "As a male, you still have a uterus though it now gives 'birth' to chaotic energy."

You gulped. "Can males of chaotic blood..."

Dad threw his head back laughing. "No, chaotic males cannot become pregnant!" Amused, he said. He then grinned, adding, "Not that it has not been tried..."

"I don't want to know." Disturbed, you said.

Dad chuckled, he was clearly enjoying this but you were rather creeped out by it all. "The process of casting an event is very similar to casting a spell." Calmly, he explained. "The only difference is that chaotic scientists rarely use fancy words or phrases to direct the power of the event."

"How do you direct the event then?" Curious, you asked. "The books were very vague on the subject."

"You focus on the result of the event rather than the process of it." Simply, dad replied. "By casting a 'spell', you are effectively showing your work." He chuckled. "We chaotic scientists do the work in our heads."

You sighed then tried...

Dad grinned at your decision. "That was predictable." Bemused, he said. "However, changing yourself back into Gina will rob Joanie of her magic training." He chuckled. "Your mother and I agree, you can not have one without the other."

"What do you mean?" Taken back, you demanded. "I thought you said that you just switched our genders."

"We did just that." smiling, dad said. "However, we also linked your transformations so that neither can back out early in good conscience. You will not become Gina again until Joanie is willing to change back with you."

Unknown to you, mom was showing Joanie Rachel and Thomas at the front door through a crystal ball...

You sighed, seeing his pale expression. "Joe, I need to talk to you..."

"I know what you want to say and I want no part of it." Serious, Joe said. He turned to dad. "Nor do I want any part of this mad or chaotic science."
