Inside the secret room, a witch smiled. "Well done, Gina." Softly, she said. "Yes, there are clues everywhere, if you know what to look for."

"How long do they have?" Worried, mom asked.

"They have until sunrise tomorrow morning." Serious, one mad scientist said. "It's noon now."
____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Back inside the house, you and Gina began to examine your surroundings more closely. After a few moments, you and he met back at the staircase. "I found a door that opens into a hall with only one door." Calmly, Joe said. "That may be worth exploring."

"I found a tiny plaque on the first step with the Latin words, Et hoc modo primus." Motioning to the staircase, you said. "It means 'this way first'."

"That's a bit obvious." Wincing, you pointed out. "You would think the clues would be harder than that but, with this place, you never know."

"We could always go back down that first hall." Wincing, you said.

Joe shook his head. "No... something tells me that is not the right way."

"How so?" Curious, you asked.

"It was hidden but made all too easy to find it back." Serious, you said. "That practically screams trap to me."

You sighed. "Well, I say the stairs. How about you?"
122123213.title: Punishments and rewards are discovered.

1221232131.content:
"We'll try the stairs." Sighing, Joe said. "Just let me go first."

"Do you suspect something?" Curious, you asked.

Joe smiled. "Remember those old cartoon mystery shows where the staircase moves and becomes a slide?" Ruefully, he asked. You nodded and Joe pointed to the stairs. "If you look closely, the stairs are raised just slightly in random places. I'd say those are the triggers for that or some other mechanism."

You looked at the stairs more closely. Sure enough, there were small patches on every other step in different spots that were slightly raised from the stairs. "Cute..." Irritated, you muttered. You then smiled. "I believe you just used your witch sight."

"My what...?" Confused, Joe asked.

"It's sort of like a danger sense that witches have." Calmly, you explained. "Magic has many uses including a second sight, so to speak." After a pause, you added, "Come to think of it, that might be how you were able to catch me before I fell down that trap door."

Joe blushed slightly at that. "That was just quick reflexes." Lamely, you said.

You smiled, thinking, "I wonder..."

Joe lead the way while to followed right behind him, taking care not to step on the slightly raised patches in the light carpeting. Upon reaching the top, Joe looked both ways then quickly pulled you aside as the stairs suddenly became a slide. "Did we miss one?" Nervous, you asked.

Joe shook his head. "I think that was done to force us to quickly pick a direction." Motioning to the landing, he replied. "I felt the carpet moving and jumped aside. Had we hesitated..."

"We would have been right back where we started with you changing more." Sighing, you finished. Wincing, you added, "I'm sorry for this."

Joe shrugged it off. "You are in the same boat as I am." Calmly, he said. "For all we know, you are changing too, just not in a way either of us notice yet."

You found that thought disturbing but pushed it aside for the moment as Joe looked around. You and he were on a narrow circular landing surrounding the main room of the house. There were three halls branching off in a 'Y' formation with three doors, one between each hall, and a stair case heading to the third floor. Joe moaned, scratching his head. "To leave this house is the quest; to find the right way it the test." Muttering to himself, he said.

You winced, hearing him. "Joe, that almost sounded like a spell."

"You can blame mom for that." Serious, Joe replied. "She would always talk in rhyme when she was stuck on something. I sort of picked it up from her."

As if on cue, one of the doors on the narrow landing glowed slightly for a moment. You were not certain if it was Joe's chaotic power reacting to his comment or his dormant magic reacting, or if the house was messing with your minds. Joe saw the door glow for a moment as well and threw you an uncertain glance. "You said boys can't work magic, right?"

You shook your head. "Boys can't work magic but mad science is a magic that works for boys and you have that." Honestly, you said. "However, a boy's dormant magic has been known to react to a boy's emotions and work on his behalf."

"Or it could be a mind game from whoever is running this little 'fun house'." Annoyed, Joe commented. "We need to chose a direction."

After some debate, you and Joe decide to...
1221232131.title: Joe follows you up the dark staircase.

choices: Joe inspects the machine, which sucks him in
Joe finds something in the room
12212321311.content:
... try the glowing door. Joe, unwisely in your opinion, takes off his shirt and uses it to open the door. To your surprise, it easily opens without any unpleasant surprises. Relieved, Joe unwraps his shirt from his hand, but pauses the instant you told him to stop.

"Why?" Joe demanded.

"Just being cautious. I would have just let me open that door, and not undressed. Instead, you're risking putting whatever substance that was on the handle onto your skin" you said.

"You really think all the doors are trapped?" Joe asked.

"I don't know" you snapped.

"Calm down. You're not the one getting transformed" Joe huffed, as he flicked his braided hair. "Least this way, I can open all the doors."

"Some doors aren't meant to be opened" you muttered to yourself, wondering if allowing yourself to be persuaded to try this door was a mistake. You walked in, and gulped, seeing that it looked mostly like some high school science lab. The was one difference; a strange machine was at the far end. Also, on some hotplates were some beakers containing some kind of colored liquids. The door you used to enter was the only way in or out of the room. Joe turned to you and said, "What is this place?"

"I'm guessing that since this place is techno-magical, this is more of the science side of things. Just be careful, it could be a trap and send you into a direction you don't want to go" you warned.

"Like what? All I want is a pair of scissors. Even if there aren't any, wouldn't a science based thing reverse these girly changes" Joe said, ignoring your warning.
12212321311.title: Try the glowing door.

122123213113.content:
You watched as Joe looked at the machine and shook his head. "Mom and dad always told me not to meddle with anything unknown unless you are trained to deal with the unknown." He then looked at the various bottles and viles of liquids. "Do you think any of these are potions or serums, Gina?"

You shook your head. "It's hard to say without my magic." Honestly, you said. "Mom and dad told me that there are no shortcuts."

Joe nodded at that. "The door had to have glowed for a reason." Looking around, he said. "Of course, that is assuming my power, whatever it might be, had anything to do with it."

Deciding to investigate the room further, Joe found a small cabinet filled with keys. "Hey, sis!" Waving at you, he called. "I found something!"

You hurried over to your brother and saw the cabinet filled with keys but frowned seeing it was locked with a note that stated, 'One key opens all while the rest will make you fall.'

"There is one master key and the rest are dummy keys which will open a trap door like the one in the other hall." Softly, you said. "Even if we could get into the cabinet..."

Joe smiled, opening the cabinet door, surprising you. "There is a pad lock but its not holding the door closed; its just there to give that illusion."

You smiled, knowing that Joe was using his head and at least considering most of your advise through your training as a witch. "How do propose we find the right key?" Curious, you asked. "There must be at least two dozen keys in there."

"Well, the note said one key will open all, right?" Thoughtful, Joe replied. "That might include this padlock which is meant to test the keys."

"That's possible." Wincing, you said. "Still, the others will open a trap door."

"True." Frowning, Joe said. "However, once we know where the trap door is, we can avoid it and quickly find the right key." He paused then frowned. "No shortcuts..."

"Are you not going to try the keys?" Confused, you asked.

Joe looked around, scratching his head. He then pulled onto the pad lock and smiled as it easily opened for him. "That's it!" Taking the lock, he said. "This is what we were supposed to find."

"Huh?" You had no idea where Joe was going with his idea but you followed him out of the room and down the stairs to the first hall you entered. "What are you up to, bro?"

Joe did not answer at first. He pushed the lock through two metal loops on the trap door you did not notice before and sent the lock home before opening the door. The trap door clicked but the lock held it closed. "Shall we see where this door leads us?" Smiling, he asked.

____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the secret room, a witch giggled. "He is truly resourceful." Bemused, she said. "He has figured out the first puzzle in record time." She grinned. "She will make a fine witch."

"Do not gloat yet, my dear spell weaving colleague." Smiling, a mad scientist countered. "The boy is using more science than magic at this time..."

This is a serious, life changing event for a minor, not light hearted wager!" Irritated, dad snapped. "Leave your personal feelings out of this!"

"That was just a friendly exchange of opinions, Mr Mage." Calmly, the witch said. "Try to relax, this will all be over in a few hours."

____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the house, you walked through the door into the next room...
122123213113.title: Joe finds something in the room

choices: Joe insists on going out the window
Joe listens to you and goes out the door
Joe comes too close to the drawer
1221232131131.content:
"This house doesn't make any sense!" Joe complained as he stepped through the door. Instead of another hallway, you saw it was a bedroom, clearly a guest room, but it had an obvious feminine edge to it. Shuddering slightly, worried about his bare chest, Joe said, "This is a trap."

"Agreed" you said, not liking the look of the room, even though there wasn't anything threatening. You turned around, intending to go back to the lab room, but to your shock, the door had disappeared, leaving only a bare wall. Joe wasn't happy when you told him.

"You're joking?" he snapped, as he started feeling the wall. After a minute of searching the wall, he moved aside, and let you look, but you was as successful as him. "Guessing the magic seeled this place off. Only way back is through a trapdoor.

"Not going to happen" Joe snapped. "I've looked around the room, and saw that there is a dresser by the bed. "Gina, I want you to hold closed the dresser while I dash for that open window. I think it leads to the garden."

"Not going to happen" you protested.

"I'm sure clothes are going to come flying out of that thing. It won't affect you, but it'll dress me. This room is girly. I already have these stupid braids" Joe said.

"I agree, but we're not going out that way. I prefer that open door, since it does lead to another hall" you said.

"You want to stay in this house of horrors?" Joe said, surprised.

"I fear the garden" you admitted. "I don't know if it's the witch version of camp stories, but I don't want to become part of that garden. Even if I'm wrong, what's stopping it from being another trapdoor wanting to punish someone that wants the easy path?"
1221232131131.title: The next room

12212321311313.content:
You winced, seeing Joe walk to the window to look out at the garden. At first, you thought he was going to jump out but instead, he just looked around. "There is no way around the building through the garden, its all sealed off with high fences." Disappointed, he said. "Its a dead end."

Just as Joe turned away from the window, one of the drawers of the dresser opened on its own and a white lace bra flew out. You gave a yell of warning just before the bra forced itself onto Joe, causing his chest to literally explode into a pair of high B cup breasts which filled the bra nicely. You winced hearing Joe scream at the sight of his new bust.

"What's the big deal?!" Angry, Joe demanded. "Get off me!"

"You should have been more careful." Sighing, you said.

"You should have held the drawers closed like I asked you!" Annoyed, Joe fired back.

You cringed as Joe slammed his fists onto the top of the dresser. Part of you expected the clothes in the dresser to immediately respond by completely dressing Joe up as a girl. Only, to your surprise, almost horror, the force of Joe's fists sent the dresser crashing through the floor and into what appeared to be the basement of the house.

____________________________________________________________________________ ___
Inside the secret room, the witches and mad scientist working the controls were just as shocked as you were by Joe's display of anger and strength.

"He has a temper." Frowning, the first witch commented.

"Vile, simply vile." Shaking her head, the second witch agreed.

"It is the first sign of the power of an Ironclad." Frowning as well, the first mad scientist said.

"This was expected." Calmly, the second mad scientist said. "When anyone feels cornered or threatened, they will either run or fight. Joe Mage is a fighter."

____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the bedroom, you looked through the hole in the floor to find the dresser smashed to pieces from both Joe's blow and the fall with a number of girlish pieces of clothing scattered about, still and silent. "What did you do that for?" Softly, you demanded. "Certainly you know that will only make the magic target you more."

"The wardrobe was malfunctioning." Your voice an octave higher, you replied. "It attacked me and I countered; end of story."

You sighed. Joe was not the type who took gruff from anyone. He was kind. polite, and patient but there were certain lines you just did not cross unless you wanted a fight. Joe would only allow anyone to strike him once. He would give them a warning then. Strike him twice and there would be a fight. The dresser was the second strike against him.

"Where to now?" Changing the subject, you asked. "The garden is obviously out."

"Well, we have the door and the hole in the floor." Tugging on his bra, Joe replied. "However, I would appreciate some help getting this thing off of me."

"Taking it off won't change the partial transformation." Serious, you said. "It's best to leave it on so your 'girls' don't weigh you down too much."

"Very funny." Frowning, Joe said.

"I'm serious." Firmly, you countered. "Once we get out of here, assuming you are not fully changed into a girl, I'll do all I can to change you back."

Joe sighed, obviously not liking his situation in the least. "Fine..."
12212321311313.title: Wardrobe malfunction.

122123213113131.content:
You were about to walk through the door with Joe following when you both heard a girl scream coming from the hole in the floor. After exchanging a startled glance, you both ran back to the hole to find a young girl with an older girl slowly backing away from what appeared to have been a humanoid robot. "Your time has expired." Flatly, the robot stated. "You must be taken out."

"Hey, metal mouth!" Angrily, Joe yelled out. "Pick on someone your own size!"

Before you could stop him, Joe leaped down through the hole and attacked the robot! With a weary sigh, you followed to find that Joe had the robot on the run. Both of Joe's fists were glowing with energy as he delivered blow after blow, sending it running through a secret door. You turned to your brother to find that he had gain some muscle but he had not lost his bust. "Are you two okay?" Turning to the young girls, Joe asked. "It seems as if you're stuck in this crazy house maze too."

Both girls sadly nodded. The first girl was about your height with shoulder length forest brown hair and green eyes. The other was a few inches shorter with mid-back blond hair and blue eyes. "Thank you for the rescue." Relieved, the first girl said. "I am Mia Hank and this is my brother, well now sister Cire. We woke up here about tow days ago and have been trying to find a way out ever since."

"Those robots have been chasing us for hours." Shaken, Cire added. "We just want to get out."

____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the secret room, the first mad scientists frowned. "Those two should have been teleported out hours ago!" Frustrated, he snapped. "Now we have an unfortunate situation!"

"Your robots are not having much luck either." Coldly, the first witch fired back. "Their experience has caused their magic to shield them from outside magical influence."

"Enough!" Sternly, dad ordered. "My son and daughter should not have been introduced to the house environment until the entire maze had been cleared! This is a failure and, as the head mad scientist, it is my duty to report this to the Failure Oversight Department!"

"My mother, the head witch will hear of this laps of judgement!" Angrily, mom added. "You have a double booked test! Do you have any idea how quickly this could become corrupted?!"

"All is yet not lost." Nervous, the second mad scientist stated. "We merely have to modify the test, rewarding the first pair for their ability to resist removal with added time."

"We can also adapt, offering extra rewards for your daughter and son if they make it out of the house in time with the first group before time runs out."

Dad turned to mom who gave a worried sigh then made a decision. "Very well but know this; if any harm comes to those being tested, you will all be held accountable."

____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the house, you and Joe, along with Mia and Cire planned your next move...
122123213113131.title: A complication.

choices: a room fitted out as a gym
a trapdoor, causing joe to disappear
1221232131131311.content:
"So what's your story?" Joe asked, hoping to get as much information as he could get.

Mia turned to Cire, who gave a slight nod. "Cire and I were shopping at the local mall, when we noticed a new store that had gone in overnight. We walked in, and straight away, we found ourselves in the front hall of this house. After seeing that the front door was locked, we went upstairs. After exploring maybe two dozen rooms, Cire suddenly felt tired, and went into the only bedroom we had discovered. You can see what happened next" Mia explained.

Joe turned to you. "Least I know one more thing to avoid." Turning to Mia and Cire, he said, "Sorry about what happened to you. Hoping for something to reverse your transformation?"

"Yes, though I also want to get out of this crazy house. There is worse things than getting turned into a four year old girl" Cire said.

"True" you agreed. "So what now?"

"This place seems to want to toy with me slowly. We found this room that had a science theme. Maybe it could fix things..." Joe offered. You wasn't too impressed. After hearing your protests, Joe hastily added, "Then again, it could make things worse, though I disagree. More science type stuff, more aggressive things I do, more I see a positive change."

"So you want this science?" you asked, not quite comfortable with the idea. Joe shook his head.

"No. I don't want either science or magic, and I do not want to be turned into a girl by this creepy, messed up house!" Joe snapped.

"Just be careful. Muscles doesn't necessarily mean no gender switch" Mia warned as both she and you watched Joe open another door, which lead to...
1221232131131311.title: Inside information

12212321311313112.content:
The door opened into another bedroom, one which Cire refused to enter. "That's the room where I got sleepy and took a nap." Nervous, she said.

You were about to pull Joe back from the door when he jumped back himself. "Do you hear that?" Whispering, he demanded. He paused to listen then slammed the door. "Gas! Everyone, up the stairs, now!"

You took Cire's hand as Mia followed with Joe taking the rear, urging us to up the stairs back to the first floor. Once we were back in the main room, Joe scowled at the various doors. "You did not get sleepy by chance." Angry, Joe said. "You were hit with sleeping gas. This whole house is rigged to make those enter fail!"

"Are we going to die?" Horrified, Cire asked.

"None of us will die." Serious, you said. "I have heard of this house while training at Cauldron Academy; those who entered here never spoke of what had happened to them other than being changed for life."

"It's forcing a choice." Through gritted teeth, Joe said. "We ended up here the very next day after I told dad I wanted nothing to do mad science..." He then eyed you. "...Or magic."

"I had nothing to do with this." Honestly, you protested.

Joe sighed. "I know you didn't." His face softening, he said. "You could never lie without your left eye twitching at least once."

You blushed slightly at that. Lying was something you hated to do and when forced to lie, your eye twitched as a form of wincing at the deed. "Did you deny magic and mad science before coming here, Cire?" Turning to the small girl, you asked.

"I... I told mom and dad I couldn't decide between making one or the other proud." Tearing up, she replied. "I didn't want to make one or the other disappointed in me."

"It's a bad position to place any boy in a family of witches and mad scientists." Frowning, you said. "This house is even worse, if this is its intended purpose."

"Our parents must be involved in this in some form!" Enraged, Joe snapped. "What right do they have to force a life changing decision upon someone who just discovered the powers they have to chose from?!"

"You have a point." Frowning, you said. "This crosses the line on many ethical and legal grounds for both powers." After a thought, you added, "Unless it is to protect one from other issues."

"What do you mean?" Curious, Cire asked.

"There are covens for witches and collectives for mad scientists, groups who gather to push for laws that will protect their interests." Darkly, you explained. "Their recruiters can be very aggressive. If mom and dad knew or suspected that such groups were eyeing Joe, they may find it necessary to force a choice."

"It still does not give them any right." Annoyed, Joe insisted. He then yelled out into the house, "I know you can hear me, mom and dad! Show and explain yourself if you have the decency or audacity to do so!"

____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the secret room, both mom and dad winced. Only the two witches and mad scientists seemed unfazed. "Other boys and girls have said far worse when they discovered or suspected the truth." Calmly, the first mad scientist said. "It is at this point, the target begins to make a choice of powers on a conscious or unconscious level."

"To answer your son's challenge would only to play into his hands, giving him all the power in this situation." Firmly but kindly, the first witch added. "This exercise is legal as you are his legal guardians and have the right to test which power he desires the most, given it is in a safe and controlled environment."

"The elder sister is there to serve as a guide and protector in case something goes wrong." Firmly, the second mad scientist stated. "The suppression field can be turned off with the flip of a switch in cases of emergency."

"In case you might ask, the boy was introduced to sleeping gas because we sensed that his powers of magic and chaotic magic were beginning to mix." Serious, the second witch said. "That can lead to the boy to becoming seriously injured or worse. Our first priority is to the safety of those who are being tested."
____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the main room, Joe huffed when no answer came. "We will return home eventually." Frustrated, he muttered. "You will face me then."

"Easy, Joe." Serious, you warned. "Strong emotions augment both powers."

"Tell that to those who are getting me riled." Annoyed, Joe countered.

"All I am saying is to use your head." Patiently, you advised. "You are expert on mysteries; we need to solve this one quickly and get out before Cire ends up a girl for life along with you."

Joe turned to you, a deep scowl on his face. For a moment, you thought he was going to explode as his patience had been pushed to its near limit. Fortunately, he sighed and his face softened slightly. "You are right, sis." Calmly, he said. "I can't think straight when I'm all worked up like this."

He took a number of breaths then looked around, as if searching for something then turned to Cire and Mia. "You two have been in this house longer than us." Firmly but kindly, he said. "Does it seem as if everything moves in a circle?"

Both Mia and Cire nodded. "Every time we follow a long hall, it leads us back here." Honestly, Mia replied. "It's as if this house doesn't want us to find a way out."

Joe thought for a moment them smiled. "No... this house is a circle!"

"What do you mean?" Curious, you asked.

"Think about it!" Serious, Joe said. "We never saw this house from the outside so we assumed it was just like any other house. Only this one is designed to confuse its visitors, literally leading them in circles!"

"So the way out is..." Curious, Mia asked.

"The center of the house." Smiling, Joe replied.

"What makes you say that?" Confused, you asked.

"It's the perfect place to put the drive way." As if inspired, Joe explained. "The circle continues on the second and third floor but a section on the first floor opens for the garage."

____________________________________________________________________________ ___

The first witch giggled inside the secret room. "The boy's witch sight has surfaced once again." Showing pride, she commented. "This house is indeed a circle with a path for a driveway to the center." She turned to mom. "You should be proud, Mrs Mage."

"He is showing the intelligence of a true mad scientist." Beaming, the first mad scientist countered. "There is no other explanation."

"No... he is a true detective." Smiling, mom said. "Its a gift he has."

"I must agree." Smiling as well, dad replied. "However, his true power remains a mystery."

"Perhaps he will solve that for himself as well." thoughtful the second witch stated.

"Indeed." Agreed the second mad scientist said. "Let us see if his revelation will lead them out in time or if a choice will be made for them."
____________________________________________________________________________ ___

Inside the house, you followed as Joe lead the way towards the center of the house with unknown obstacles awaiting you.
12212321311313112.title: Joe solves part of the mystery.

choices: you notice something in the room.
the girls manage to open the door with unfortunate results
122123213113131121.content:
As Joe stared down a long hallway, with more doors, he turned to Cire and Mia. "Do you have any idea where this passage leads to?"

"No idea. This completely new" Cire said sourly.

"What? How? I thought you'd recognise this area since you knew the bedroom..."

"It's possible that the house shifts, Joe. I think this is a hall that was closed the last time we was here" Mia said.

"I agree" you said, biting your lip slightly. "Still, we know we need to go into the center so I'm guessing the far door is the right one. All the others seem to head backwards."

Joe nodded. "That seems logical. Gina, why is this house doing all this stuff to me? I would think this 'mad science' is more logical based, yet this place seems to want to give you a sister. Plus, I want to be an athlete..."

"How would I know?" you said. "Maybe we can get those answers once we get out of here."

Joe sighed, and opened the door. Instantly, his faced twisted with disgust. "What's wrong?" Cire asked, almost timidly.

"Someone is toying with me! This is a gym" Joe snapped. He tried to pull the door shut, but to his horror, he was pulled into the gym. Biting you lip even more, you wondered if you should follow, but after a few seconds of hesitation, you followed him. The instant you was through the door, it slammed closed, separating you from Cire and Mia.

"Gina, why did you close the door?" Joe demanded.

"It closed on it's own" you said.

Joe frowned even more. "Guess this is for me alone. See if there is any way out of here. I don't trust any of these things."

"What things?" you asked.

"Who is going to be stupid enough to drink out of a water bottle that is labelled 'drink me'? As for that locker, you know what happened last time..."

"What? Afraid of getting some panties to go with that bra?" you teased.

"Not funny" Joe snapped.
122123213113131121.title: Shifting rooms

1221232131131311211.content:
As soon as Joe snapped against you, his jeans and shoes started shimmer. "What did you do?" Joe snapped, his voice clearly alarmed and angry.

"Nothing" you gasped, as you watched his lower clothes shift. Within a couple of seconds, his jeans had transformed into a plaid skirt and his socks had grown to become knee high. The only clothes that he still had that he walked into this place were his shoes and the shirt that he had wrapped around his hands.

"Doesn't look like 'nothing'. Just shut up! You and your teasing. What are you trying to do to me, turn me into a girl? I know mom wants to do exactly that, but least she is overt about it" Joe angrily said as he glared between you and his new attire.

"I don't, and I haven't done anything...." you protested, but Joe was far too worked up.

"Yeah? Then why is this damn house doing it's best to change me? Just stay here, Gina. I don't need you" Joe snapped.

"Calm down Joe. This place is toying with you, and it will get worse if you go alone" you warned.

"And how do you know that?" Joe said coldly. "I'm done."

You sighed. "Joe, I am a witch, but I am also your sister. I don't want to see you get hurt, and I don't want to see you get pushed onto a path you do not want to follow. but its clear to me that this house sees that you had a massive magic potential.."
1221232131131311211.title: A clothing change and a mad brother

12212321311313112111.content:
"I already said I don't want anything to do with magic or that chaotic science!" Tearfully, Joe yelled. "I will not be forced to chose between mom and dad!"

"Easy, Joe." Serious, you warned, strong emotions augment magic. "You need to think before you act; especially when you are under pressure like this."

"It's not fair that I have to choose right off the bat or worse, have someone choose for me!" Looking at you, Joe thundered. "I'm sure you, Ina and Tia had a choice! Why can't I?!"

Frustrated and near his limit, Joe punched the wall. Unknown to him or you, he hit just the right spot to open a hidden door that lead to another hall. Joe stopped yelling and looked down the hall with rising curiosity. "A hidden door?"

"It could be another trap." Wincing, you said.

"Maybe." Softly, Joe agreed.

He slowly walked down the hall with you reluctantly following to find a dead end. You were about to suggest walking back when Joe began feeling the walls for an indent. Upon finding one, he punched it and another door opened. "Let's see where this leads."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------------------

Inside the control room, the first witch gave a bemused smile. "It looks like Miss Mage has stumbled upon the maintenance halls." Grinning, she said. "If she pushes all the right buttons, they will be out of the maze within minutes and a new powerful witch will be born."

"Do not gloat just yet, my spell casting acquaintance." Smiling, the first mad scientist countered. "Mr Mage is not fully transformed yet. He may just make it out as the next heir to the chaotic science throne."

"Just ensure that no physical harm comes to them." Serious, dad warned. "Are there traps to protect those halls?"

"None." Serious, the second witch replied. "However, hitting the wrong switch could lead them right back to where they started in the maze."

"It is not the maze that decides your child's gender." Serious, the second mad scientist added. "It is his, or her, choices as they search for the way out."
---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------------------

Inside the maintenance halls, you and Joe hit another switch and enter...
12212321311313112111.title: Joe's anger reveals another maze.

122123213113131121113.content:
Everyone in the control room froze as the door opened revealing you and Joe. A gasp escaped your lips before you tried to back up the way you came only it was too late. Joe entered and froze as he spotted mom and dad. "I knew you two were behind this!" Furious, he snapped. "What's the big idea forcing Gina and I through that crazy maze?!"

"You needed to make a choice but refused to do so." Bluntly, dad replied.

"It wasn't personal, Joe." Softly, mom added.

You were at a loss for words. All you could say was, "I had no knowledge of this..."

Joe slowly shook his head before running off, crying and screaming in both anger and sadness. Mom called your name but winced as a crash had been heard. "He ran through anther secret door as if it were made of paper." Frowning, the first mad scientist said. "I fear him discovering you two, Mr and Mrs Mage had sparked a final decision."

"He's become an Ironclad." Frowning, the first witch said. "As a boy of witch blood, his magic has taken root only his physical strength due to his chaotic blood makes him too strong to break the barrier, keeping him male."

"All is not yet lost." Serious, the second mad scientist said. "He can still be persuaded to become a witch or a mad scientist but you must do so before the Ironclads come to recruit him."

You sighed, hearing that then turned to mom and dad, frowning. "Is this what you two wanted?!" Angrily, you demanded. "To drive away your only son?!"

Without hearing their explanation, you turned to the first witch. "If the test is over, I demanded to leave; now!"
122123213113131121113.title: An Ironclad ending to a test.

122123213113131121114.content:
An audible sigh of relief escaped your lips as you and Joe stepped out into the light; the sun was just beginning to rise. "We made it out of the house." Softly, you said. "How do you feel?"

Joe moaned, immediately causing your smile to vanish. He, or rather, she was now fully female and wearing a simple white dress, white stockings, and mary janes. "I guess I'll live." Tearfully, she replied. "I can always be a female athlete."

Joe began to sob, causing you to wince. The test had taken its toll on her and on you as well; all you could do was pull her into a one armed hug and lead her away from the house. Not far behind you, Mia and Cire, both fully female, were stepping out of what appeared to be a garage door.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------------------------

"Half a minute." Frowning deeply, dad said. "They failed by a mere thirty seconds."

"On the contrary, they all passed with flying colors." Calmly, the first mad scientist said. "Do not forget, we allowed extra time for Mia and Cire and we gave rewards to Joe and Gina to compensate for the inadvertently double booked test."

"Exactly where are you going with this?" Worried, mom demanded.

"It's simple, really." Serious, the first witch replied. "You must show your daughter magic and, if she likes it, she will remain female for the rest of her life."

"However, if she finds she does not like it, she will revert to his male state where you, Mr Mage must show him chaotic science.." Serious, the second mad scientist added. "If he likes it, he will remain male and the heir to the throne as he is destined to be."

"If, by chance, he rejects both due to his experience, he will become an Ironclad." Frowning, the second witch said. "So to answer your question, Mrs Mage, this is now a test for you and your husband as your children had won their right to choose... Welcome to the gauntlet."

Hours later, back at home...
122123213113131121114.title: A magical end to a test.

1221232131131311211143.content:
You met mom in the hall as she was walking to Joe's bedroom; the door was closed. With her was a small girl no older than twelve with long blond hair and blue eyes, wearing a simple dress and mary janes. "Gina, this is Raven Falcon." Introducing the girl, she said. "She will be both yours and Jenna's councilor for a few days."

"Already giving Joe a new name, I see." Ice in your voice, you said. "Good luck getting anywhere with her or me. Jenna is working on her acceptance letters to the colleges who gave her scholarship offers to get away... form mom and dad." You Frowned, adding, "I'm working on a request to teach at Cauldron Academy full time."

"Your anger and resentment is justified, though misplaced, Gina." Calmly, Raven said. "The Gauntlet is the third most cruelest test of the witching world. However, the test is not over yet."

"What do you mean?" Taken back, you demanded. "We're back home!"

"The gauntlet is a two part test." Serious, Raven explained. "The first tests the actions of the witch or witch boy in question in an increasingly stressful environment with a councilor to help the one tested after they pass or fail which is where I come in."

"What of the second part?" Eyeing mom, you asked.

Mom sighed. "The second part tests the actions of your father and I." Softly, mom explained. "I have forty-eight hours to entice Jenna into liking magic and thus wanting to remain a girl and a witch for life. If I fail, dad will have his forty-eight hours to entice Joe into liking chaotic science and accepting the heir to the throne of all mad scientists."

"Neither are allowed to interfere with the other nor are they allowed to force anything upon the child in question." Serious, Raven added. "If they both fail, Joe will become an Ironclad, the middle ground so to speak, and join their ranks."

"Are you allowed to interfere?" Annoyed, you demanded.

"I am here only to council Jenna so she understands that this is was never personal and that the choice was and will always be his or hers to make. Once I am finished counseling her, your mother's time starts ticking while I move on to council you."

With that said, mom escorted Raven to Joe's room and cautiously opened the door. You stood outside in the hall to watch and listen. "Jenna, dear." Softly, mom said. "This is Raven Falcon; she is your post test councilor. Please talk to her; she is here to help you."

"I hope you weren't paid in advance." Coolly, Jenna replied. "I just want to be left alone."

"I understand your anger, Joe." Entering the room, Raven said. "Would it help if I talked to you alone; without an audience?"

Jenna turned to Raven as she used her real name then to mom and then to you. Finally, she sighed and said...
1221232131131311211143.title: Enter Raven Falcon, councilor.

12212321311313112111434.content:
Jenna's silent response seemed to speak volumes for Raven and she cautiously entered, motioning you to follow. She then motioned mom to stay where she was at the doorway. "The test you were forced to endure is not given lightly." Softly, she began. "It can bring great rewards if done right and bring grave consequences if done wrong."

"I don't see too many rewards." Almost whispering, Jenna said.

"That is because the test is only half over." Serious, Raven said. "It is now your parents' turn to be tested only they must tread more lightly."

Jenna turned to Raven, a genuine look of concern of her face. "What...?"

Raven nodded. "At the end of the first phase of the test, it is required for the boy or girl in question to receive counseling." Calmly, she said. "The reason for this is to help you understand that none of this is personal; that the choice was and still is yours and yours alone."

"Then why am I a girl?" Pouting, Jenna demanded.

"The little house maze you and Gina went through determined, through your actions, who gets the first turn in the second phase of the test." Serious, Raven explained. "You leaned more towards magic which means your mother goes first." She frowned. "However, due to certain complications, the stakes are higher."

"You mean the other two who were in the maze." Flatly, Jenna said.

Raven nodded. "Only two people are allowed in the maze at once or the test could become corrupted, leaving those being tested unfairly judged." Softly, she said. "That was a failure on the test committee's part who I can assure you are being investigated."

"What does that have to do with Gina or I?" Irritated, Jenna demanded. "What will happen to Cire and Mia?"

"Both Cire and Mia are receiving counseling just as you are now." Calmly, Raven replied. "As to your other question, you and Gina were the first to pass the test which means that you are also the first to reach the second phase."

"So those who fail don't get a choice." Frowning, Jenna said. "I see..."

"Those who fail fall to the power their actions, their choices, leaned more towards." Patiently, Raven corrected. "However, as you had passed, your actions determined who goes first to convince you to try their power of choice." She smiled slightly. "That is why you are a girl at the moment; your actions leaned more towards magic so your mother goes first."

"How is she tested?" Wincing, Jenna asked.

"Through her actions in trying to persuade you." Simply, Raven replied. "Her time starts when I am done counseling you. The reason the stakes are higher is because your mother only has once chance to convince you to accept magic. The same applies to your father."

"A tug of war." Softly, Jenna said. "Just what I wanted to avoid."
12212321311313112111434.title: nothing.

122123213113131121114341.content:
"It's not a tug of war as your parents each only get one chance to persuade you." Calmly, Raven explained. "If your mother succeeds, you become a girl and a witch for life. You father will not be able to approach you unless you approach him on the matter."

"If mom fails?" Wincing, Jenna asked.

"Then your father gets his turn." Simply, Raven replied. "Your mother will not be able to try to persuade you further unless you approach her on the matter. If he fails, you become an Ironclad."

"A what...?" Confused, Jenna asked.

"An Ironclad is a witch born boy whose magic had taken root but his physical strength is too great for the magic to shatter the forces keeping him male." Frowning, you explained. "You would gain almost insane strength and resistance to magic."

"But before you smile, know this." Serious, Raven said. "Ironclads do not live as long as witches or mad scientists as they do not have the power to alter their age and their resistance keeps someone else doing it for them."

Jenna sighed. "What are my options?" Tearfully, she asked.

"Just listen to mom and hear what she has to say and see what she wishes to show you." Calmly, Raven said. "Once she is done, allow your father the same courtesy. After they are both done, make your decision."

Nearly an hour later, you were escorted out of Jenna's room by Raven who then took you to your bedroom and asked you to sit down. You reluctantly did so as Raven took a seat of her own. "How do you plan to start my counseling?" Frowning, you demanded.

"The gauntlet is just as hard on the chosen guide as it is on the one being tested." Calmly, Raven explained. "It the guide's actions and decisions that influence the actions and decisions of the target and the guide must live with the results."

"So the guide is also being tested, am I right?" Crossly, you asked.

"Indirectly but yes, you are correct." Softly, Raven replied. "That is why the guide receives the same level of counseling after the first phase of the test."

"Why was Joe and I thrown into the gauntlet in the first place?!" Becoming angry, you demanded. "He had just learned magic and chaotic science were real the day before!"

Raven sighed, opening a folder. "Joe, or rather, Jenna had been showing signs of both powers coming to the surface for weeks before the decision was made." To your shock, she explained. "This is a very rare and unfortunate condition known as 'a power race'. This scenario has only two possible outcomes if extreme measures are not made to bring about a choice."

You turned pale, remembering a lesson on the rare condition Raven spoke of while at Cauldron Academy. "Either the two powers will tear him apart or..." You could not finish.

"Or your bother will become a familiar." Serious, Raven said. "Normally, a familiar is an animal such as a bird or cat with nearly endless reserves of magical or chaotic energy. They cannot use this power but they can give it to a witch or mad scientist, depending upon their affiliation." She pause then added, "This would have made Joe heavily sought after. The gauntlet was necessary to avoid that scenario."

"I understand..." Tears falling, you said. "It still doesn't make it right or fair."

"Unfortunately, there is very little about life that is right or fair, Gina." Calmly, Raven replied. "I know this from experience." She then smiled. "It is up to us to make what goes wrong right and what is unfairly done fairly corrected."
122123213113131121114341.title: counseling continues.

choices: young witches confront you at school.
You are called to witch school.
1221232131131311211143413.content:
After several hours of talking with Raven, you walked out of your bedroom with her following; both of you were tired but far less stressed. "I'm glad this was not a spur of the moment decision as I had earlier feared." Calmly, you said. "I honestly did not know mad scientists were so strict when it came to the mistakes they made."

"They are excessively strict, Gina." Serious, Raven said. "As such, they do not make any such decisions lightly. You really have nothing to fear as both witches and mad scientists alike always keep a back up plan at the ready."

You paused, hearing Joe's bedroom door open and sighed seeing mom step out beaming with pride and, you suspected a sense of victory. "Everyone, Jenna has decided to become a witch and attend Cauldron Academy this year." Cheerfully, she announced. "Please say hello to the future head witch, Jenna Mage."

You smiled seeing Jenna walk out with a happy smile on her face, wearing the Cauldron Academy uniform while displaying a test flame in her left hand. "Mom pretty much raised me on her own all my life; it was her teachings that helped me navigate the maze." Softly, she said. "As the first transformed boy to become head witch in over a thousand years, i consider it a great honor and privilege."

Dad sighed, looking highly disappointed and opened his mouth to speak only he quickly paused as Jenna then turned to him. "Father, your sister's son, Henry Mage would be a far better pick for head mad scientist as she had kept her maiden name." She grinned. "Both key positions will be kept within the family."

Dad thought about Jenna's words for a moment then threw his head back in a maddening laugh. "Your words ring true, my dear daughter!" Showing a hint of pride, he said. "The irony of it all is sweet to the taste; we are all victorious this day!"

Although you were happy all seemed to end well with the Gauntlet test, you were troubled by the possible ramifications of a mad science family taking over both forces. Seeing your worry, Raven sadly nodded. "The test is over, Jenna made her choice." Softly, she said. "How the witching and mad science communities take the news is another matter."

Mom smiled, turning to Jenna. "I know you will make me and the witching world proud." Softly, she said. "You leave for Cauldron Academy first thing tomorrow morning."

The following morning...
1221232131131311211143413.title: keeping everything in the family.

12212321311313112111434132.content:
Your aunt Abra Mage was rather bemused to hear that her son, Henry was to become the next head mad scientist. He had a lot of potential and showed fine leadership qualities only he was not a fan of 'unnecessary' social affairs; a waste of valuable time in his opinion. You had no doubt that Jenna would make a fine head witch as she showed far more promise as a leader only you were not sure how other witches would react to it. You saw her off just before going to school that day where you were almost immediately confronted by Lydia Rune. She was tall and slender with shoulder length brown hair and blue eyes. She had a reputation of misleading people without breaking any rules of conduct. Lydia and you were rivals even before you went to Cauldron Academy as you ran against her for student body president. You had won but going to witch school allowed her to win due to your 'temporary transfer'.

"We need to talk, Mage." Serious, she whispered. "You let us down."

You sighed, rolling your eyes. "I had no say or power over Jenna's decision to become a girl and a witch for life." Annoyed, you whispered back. "Even then, her transformation was willing so her fate as head witch is a matter of choice and not destiny. If she decides not to be head witch, it falls onto my shoulders." You then leaned in close and added. "If that becomes the case, I think you'd want to stay on my good side."

"If that cocky Henry Mage becomes head mad scientist, we lose the advantage, Gina." Bluntly, Lydia argued. "With Joe as head mad scientist, you can manipulate him, control him, giving the witching community an edge it has not had since mad science infected our world."

"You make them sound like a disease." Wincing, you said.

Lydia huffed, shaking her head. "If you do not do something to fix this soon, someone else will."

"Like you?" Eyes narrowing, you demanded.

Lydia nodded. "We have a plan but we need you to make it work." To your shock, they said. "It is for the benefit of us all, Gina. Please hear us out."

You could not believe what you were hearing; it made you fearful for your new sister who was now at Cauldron Academy learning magic. You bit your lip, wondering what to do.
12212321311313112111434132.title: young witches confront you at school.

choices: You talk Lydia out of her plan.
You wait and see what happens.
122123213113131121114341323.content:
"I'm not going to do anything that may harm my little sister." Annoyed, you replied. "Whatever plan you and your small coven may have in mind you will have to execute it on your own."

"I take it you will report us, then?" Frowning, Lydia demanded.

"I don't have to." Pointing up, you said.

Lydia frowned, taking notice of one of the hallway security cameras. "You will thank us when this is done, Gina." Through gritted teeth, she said.

"Time will tell." Shrugging, you countered. "If you will excuse me, I have to get to class."

You then walked away, making note to inform mom of your encounter. You got the chance during lunch but was surprised to learn that mom already knew. "Lydia had made her disapproval of Jenna becoming the next head witch very clear even before the Gauntlet test." Calmly, she said. "I can assure you though, she is among a very small minority."

"I fear she may try to pull Jenna out of Cauldron Academy." Wincing, you said.

Mom giggled. "She is free to try." Bemused, she replied. "Even if she succeeds in removing the initial safeguards that would make her a student upon trespassing on the grounds, she still has to deal with the safeguards of each individual hall and classroom. Then there is the matter of getting Jenna, willing or not, away from the school."

"There are that many safeguards?" Surprised, you asked.

"Well, we are dealing with mad scientists, Gina." Serious, mom said. "They have the power to break through the initial safeguards with powers of their own so extra security precautions were required to combat this."

"Is there any chance Lydia and her coven will succeed in their crazy plan?" Worried, you asked.

"There is always a chance, Gina." Wearily, mom said. "Leave it to the Soothsayers; don't get involved in this."

Mom then ended the call, leaving you wondering what to do. At the end of the school day...
122123213113131121114341323.title: continue.

choices: Dad appeared in front of you.
1221232131131311211143413232.content:
You decided to heed mom's advice and allow the Soothsayers, or magic police, take care of Lydia if she and her coven decide to act. Upon returning home you found mom having a tense conversation with your grandmother, the head witch, Elle Mist. You held back to listen in.

"Is it really necessary to get Gina involved in this test, mother?" Worried, mom demanded. "It will be complicated as it is with just Jenna as an unwilling and unaware participant."

"I am afraid that it is very necessary, my dear." Serious, Elle replied. "As the heir to the throne of the witching world, she must be able to make difficult decisions for the better of her people." She smiled slightly. "Believe me when I tell you that it is for the best that Jenna does not know her decision was magically swayed."

Mom sighed. "Her ascension to the throne will only become a reality if it is what she truly desires." Softly, she said. "The test is..."

"There are several people being tested at once, Mona." Serious, Elle said. "Each step we take must be painstakingly planned and extremely carefully executed." She sighed. "There is so much that can go wrong; we cannot afford to make any mistakes."

You turned pale, hearing this. The gauntlet test was just the beginning of a more complex and sinister test upon the entire family. You began to sneak away to try to make sense of it all when...
1221232131131311211143413232.title: A sinister test is revealed.

choices: You tell them you know of the test.
12212321311313112111434132323.content:
You jumped seeing dad suddenly appear in front of you. There was a rare look of kindness on his face as he raised a single finger to his lips, indicating silence. In the next breath, you found yourself inside a vast room the size of an aircraft hangar. It was filled with various computers and machines of complexity beyond your comprehension. "Welcome to my laboratory, Gina." Kindly, dad said. "Please do not touch anything without my supervision."

"Why did you bring me here?" Curious, you asked.

"You need to understand the event that has been put into motion by your mother and grandmother and how you play a pivotal role."

"I heard that Jenna's decision was magically swayed." Worried, you said. "I thought no one is allowed to sway her decision one way or another."

"That is correct." Serious, dad said. "That is the test both you and your sibling now face."

"Why tell me?" Wincing, you demanded. "Would that not corrupt the test?"

"The test is already corrupted because you have stumbled upon part of it." Serious, dad said. "We can not give the throne to just anyone and the one who takes it must be willing to accept all the power and responsibility that goes with it."

"So why make Jenna heir to the throne of the witching world?" Confused, you asked.

"Because I had very little to do with his upbringing." Frowning, dad replied. "I was following the same path as my father whom allowed my mother to raise me; she was an Amazon."

"Were you trained to be a witch?" Surprised, you asked.

Dad smiled. "I was trained to be an Amazon."

You nodded though you were a bit surprised. Amazons were girls born of chaotic blood whose power had taken root but were too physically strong to break the barrier keeping them female. These girls possessed incredible attributes as well as limited power over one or more of the four elements as the power of a chaotic scientist was believed to be elemental in nature. "What is Jenna's test?" Morbidly curious, you demanded. "What is my test?"

Dad sighed. "There are several people being tested but it is not my place to state who." Softly, he replied. "Jenna must decide if her heart truly is in taking the throne of the witching world or if it is the throne of chaotic science his heart longs for."

"How will studying at Cauldron Academy show her this?" Worried, you asked.

"Jenna decision was magically swayed but the effect of the spell will wear off by this time tomorrow morning." Darkly, dad said. "I calculate that she will be furious due to the deception and demand to be released. However, merely demanding to be released is not enough to sway the powers that be."

"She could demand the witch court." Serious, you said.

Dad nodded. "She could but she could also take the training and deny the throne upon graduation as her decision was magically swayed, making you the heir by default and him the heir to the chaotic throne and a student at Elite Sententia."

"What about Henry Mage?" Wincing, you asked. "Would he not challenge this?"

Dad nodded. "Another part of the test, my dear."

"Well, since you are revealing all of this, what is my test?" Worried, you asked.

Dad face turned grim. "Knowing what you know, will you intervene for the best of the witching world or allow the chips to fall where they may and accept the fate of those involved?"

With that, you found yourself back in the house just as mom and Elle turned your way...
12212321311313112111434132323.title: Dad appeared in front of you.

choices: you wake up to a change.
122123213113131121114341323233.content:
"How much of that did you hear, Gina?" Softly, mom demanded.

"Enough." Frowning, you replied. "Plus dad intervened but I cannot confirm what he told me, yet."

Mom sighed. "Like the Gauntlet, this test is not ordered lightly." Firmly but kindly, she explained. "Normally, this demands we test all of the siblings at once but we had decided to test each of you individually as we went along for safety reasons."

"It is dangerous to test several people at once, Gina." Serious, Elle said. "Too many things can go wrong and, with this test, it may result in an entirely new witch council coming to power."

"Jenna's decision being magically swayed." Softly, you said. "Why take such a risk?"

"To ensure the one who takes either throne will rule wisely." Serious, mom said. "Jenna, or Joe will make a fine leader but there was an issue with disappointing one parent or the other."

"Simply put, your sibling felt torn and would have eventually denied both thrones." Frowning, Elle said. "This test will determine, if any, which throne is best suited for him or her."

"What if she decides to call the witch court?" Gulping, you demanded.

"The Soothsayers and witch court were made aware of the test well in advance." Calmly, mom replied. "As were the Correction officers and the chaotic tribunal."

"I can assure you that they are all watching this test very carefully." Serious, Elle added. "Your new sister will be furious when the spell wears off but the test is to see how she reacts to the situation and, of course, how you will react as she will likely call you first."

"I see..." Frowning, you said. "My reaction is that this was mishandled from the very beginning. By simply giving Joe a tour of both schools, he could have made a decision on his own. Instead, you force a decision through a highly stressful test right into another one!"

Mom opened her mouth to speak but you were not finished ranting. "Another thing, what gives any of you the right to force a choice when Joe won't be taking the throne until he reaches adulthood?! For that matter, why did you not force the same choice on me?! I could have just as easily become the next heir to the chaotic throne as Joe!"

Mom and Elle turned to each other then, to your surprise, smiled. "Congratulations, Gina." Bemused, Elle said. "You have passed your test."

You took a step back, stunned. "What?!"

"The passing of the torch test takes years to play out, dear." Turning serious, mom said. "The gauntlet as the opening of the test and this is merely the second phase."

"Your bother, or rather sister must be able to make decisions under highly stressful situations as the head witch or head mad scientist will face these sort of situations." Smiling, Elle explained. "The same goes for you, my dear." She gave a light chuckle. "You passed by facing us despite the fact we are your superiors and laid down the law. Courage is another important factor."

"We can't give the throne to just anyone." Muttering, you said. "That's what dad told me."

"He is quite correct." Calmly, Elle said. "It is a position of great power and heavy responsibility to which we must be certain is held by the one most qualified."

"so, Henry Mage will not be the next head mad scientist?" Wincing, you asked.

Mom shook her head. "He doesn't want it." Bemused, mom said. "We simply used him for the test; I can assure you, though, he is freaking out over this."

You sighed, shaking your head. "You two are kicking the hornets nest." Serious, you said. "I can only hope none of you get stung."

Early the next morning...
122123213113131121114341323233.title: Mom speaks first.

choices: demanding to talk to her parents.
1221232131131311211143413232331.content:
You sighed hearing your cellphone ring and answered to hear Jenna crying on the other line. "Gina, I really need your help!" Frantic, she cried. "Mom tricked me into wanting to be head witch with some kind of crazy spell!" She sobbed before adding, "What can I do?!"

"You need to listen to me very carefully, Jenna; we likely don't have much time before they interrupt this call." Serious, you said. "You have to make a choice. Either demand the witch court or deny the throne on grounds the decision was magically influenced."

"Can you get me out of here, Gina?" Panicked, Jenna demanded.

"Only the witch courts can do that through an official order on grounds of abuse of power." Firmly, you replied. "Only that carries consequences. By denying the throne, you will still have to stay there until graduation but you can still claim the chaotic throne if that is what you want. The choice has to be yours, Jenna. I will support you either way. Good luck."

Upon saying that, the line suddenly went dead telling you the call had been interrupted by someone at the school. This made you both worried for Jenna and angry at those forcing the test, regardless of the reasons behind it. Making a decision, you called the school and got the head of Administrations and recruitment, Miss Dust.

"The call to your cellphone was not authorized, Miss Mage." Patiently, Miss Dust said.

"I authorized it, Miss Dust!" Forcefully, you countered. "As the true heir to the throne of the magic world, you have a lot of nerve to end my call prematurely!"

You could hear Miss Dust gulp on the other line. "I will return Jenna to the phone immediately." More politely, she said.

"My conversation is now with you, Miss Dust." Firmly, you said. "I have solid evidence and a confession that Jenna's decision to accept the title of heir to the throne to the magic world was magically influenced which makes her place at Cauldron Academy a forced recruitment."

"I had no knowledge of this, Miss Mage." Clearly nervous, Miss Dust said.

"I do not hold you responsible, Miss Dust." More kindly, you said. "However, we need to focus on damage control. Not only have laws been broken across the board, we have a very angry and frightened student with incredible power at the school."

"I am open to suggestions, Miss Mage." Still nervous, Miss Dust said.

"Although it is within Jenna's rights to demand the witch court, we cannot risk the repercussions of that action." After a thought, you said. "By doing so, she will most likely be crowned head witch, something she has made clear she does not desire."

"How do you propose to convince her not to take legal action?" Curious, Miss Dust asked.

"By showing her that knowledge is power." Serious, you replied. "By knowing the power and laws of magic, he can better negotiate a lasting peace between the two powers as head mad scientist... if that is what he truly desires."

"I will do my best to convince him, Miss Mage." Serious, Miss Dust said. "I doubt it will be easy, though with the anger and mistrust he is likely holding."

"That is why I will be the one to convince him." Firmly but kindly, you said. "We are both heirs to the throne on opposite sides of the coin. Expect my arrival within the hour."

"As you wish it, Miss mage." Courtly, Miss Dust said.

With that, you ended the call and prepared for your trip to Cauldron Academy. "No doubt, there will be obstacles in this test." Frowning, you said. "I need to prepare myself for anything."

After leaving a note for mom to find, you teleported to Cauldron Academy where you were allowed entry to find Jenna...
1221232131131311211143413232331.title: You lay down the law.

12212321311313112111434132323313.content:

"You should have called them then instead of your sister." Serious, Grace countered.

"That would not have helped her in the least." Startling the three, you said. "We are dealing with a complex test that is dangerously close to becoming corrupted."

"A test?" Startled, Grace asked. "How do you know this?"

"What is this test?" Worried, Miss Dust demanded.

"We cannot allow either throne to fall into the hands of just anyone." Cryptically, you said. "The one chosen must be willing to take the power and responsibilities seriously." You turned to Jenna. "I told you what your options were." Scolding, you told her. "Freaking out like you did will not solve anything!"

"You told me I can summon the witch court." Frowning, Jenna said. "Only that would have consequences and I'm guessing it involves mom and dad losing their powers."

You nodded. "If they are lucky." Darkly, you said. "The laws of both powers are very strict for good reasons; we must remain hidden from the normal world."

"What would I gain from staying here, even if I don't want the magic throne?" Pouting, Jenna demanded. "Other than knowing the use and law..." She stopped and sighed. "They want me to understand magic so I can better lead as head mad scientist."

You smiled. "I knew you were smart... for a transformed boy."

Jenna grunted, insulted. "What about Henry Mage?" Gruffly, she asked. "Would he not challenge me for the throne?"

"Your knowledge of the usage and laws of magic would trump him in your bid for the throne; if that is what you really want." Serious, you said. "However, there are more people being tested here other than our family."

"I want to be an athlete." Sighing, Jenna said.

"You still can." Gently, you replied. "Dad has a lot of years left before he must step down so there is plenty of time for you to pursue your dreams."

Jenna pouted, though more slightly than before. "Okay... I'll play it your way, for now." Grumpily, he said. "Just don't be surprised if I work to graduate early."

You giggled at that. "I would be surprised if you didn't" Bemused, you said. "You and i usually excel in all we do."

Jenna grinned at that then turned to Grace. "I am ready to return to class." Softly, he said. "Just don't expect any apology. I worked well within my rights."

Grace exchanged a knowing grin with you. "Apology accepted, young lady." Bemused, she said.

After Jenna was back in her class, you sighed. "That's one mess cleaned up for the moment." Irritated, you said. "On to the next."

Dad smiled before summoning a notebook to his hand. "Splendid." Bemused, he said. "You will be attempting to make a simple babbling serum while I attempt to make a simple babbling potion."

Following the directions exactly, you turned to dad for the final instructions only to have him holding up what appeared to be a finished potion!"

Instinctively, you raised your magical defenses to which dad smiled more. "How did you manage to make a potion?!" Startled, you demanded. "You are not a woman or a witch!"

Dad threw his head back with a maniacal laugh before eying you with an almost sadistic grin making you feel uncomfortable. "I didn't." Amused, he said. "I only made the initial mixture. When you raised your defenses, it gave the mixture the final ingredient required to make it a potion." He grinned more before finishing, "Your magic."

"How is that possible?" Taken back, you asked. "Dad, you are frightening me..."

Dad smiled more kindly. "I apologize for causing you a fright, dear." Calmly, he said. "You see, for any potion or serum to have power, it only requires magic or chaotic energy to be focused upon it. Your eyes widened as you caught on to dad's reasoning. "So when I raised my defenses against the mixture you made, I inadvertently charged it with my magic, making it a potion."

Dad nodded. "Had I thrown this at you instead, your own magic would have finished the potion upon raising your defenses." Softly, he explained. "Had it hit, you would have taken its full effects and be unable to cast a single spell until another witch gave you the antidote."

Dad chuckled as you held up the mixture you had made. "Once you learn to detect the absence of magic or chaotic energy in any given mixture will you learn when to and not to raise your defenses." Bemused, he said. "I learned that the hard way from your mother."

You smiled at that. "Well, she is an expert in combat magic." Calmly, you said. "Only you mentioned that once you understand the principals of potions and serums..."

"By knowing and understanding the ingredients, you can make any serum a potion or visa versa by simply swapping out key elements more agreeable to your root power."

12212321311313112113.title: A test becomes a game of cat and mouse.
