Your last energy blast sent Joe literally flying off his feet. You gasped as he was slammed into the wall, leaving a dent. He fell to the floor, surprisingly inside the ring, unmoving. You moved to see if he was okay but Miss Flora motioned you stay where you were. She cautiously walked up to where Joe was lying but paused as he slowly pulled himself up.

"Are you able to continue with the exam, Mr Mage?" Calmly, Miss Flora asked.

Joe coughed as he unsteadily rose to his feet. You winced seeing that he had a bloody lip and a cracked forehead. He wiped the small splatter of blood from his lip. "Okay, sis..." Hissing, he said. "If you really want to play it that way..."

"Please answer my question, Mr Mage." Firmly but kindly, Miss Flora insisted. "Are you able to continue with the exam?"

Joe turned to Miss Flora, his knees shaking slightly from the hit he took and replied...
1311133113.title: You go too far, Joe gets hurt.

13111331133.content:
Joe turned to Miss Flora, his knees shaking slightly from the hit he took and replied by running straight for you at full speed! You gasped seeing him coming but you, nor Miss Flora had time to react as he wrapped one arm around your neck and, to your surprise, began to ruffle your hair!

"Whose the Nuggie head?!" Smirking, Joe demanded. "Who is the Nuggie head?!"

At first, you and everyone watching had thought Joe had lost his mind. Then you remembered a long conversation mom had with you when you were seven years old. She told you that it was in your best interest to be close to your brother and not to form any kind of rifts. You did not understand the reasons behind it then but you had later made a pact with Joe not to get into any fist fights and the one who started one was a 'nuggie head'.

Returning your mind to the present, you giggled. "I am the nuggie head!" Smiling, you yelled.

Joe let you go, still smirking. "You tried to start a fight for what?" Scolding, he demanded. "A boy breaking one of your records? There are better things to fight for."

You blushed at that. "I have to admit, I was afraid that you would beat my record so I kind of went over the top." Softly, you said. "I'm sorry."

Joe turned to Miss Flora. "What was my time?"

Miss Flora was trying not to laugh at the brief altercation. "You scored at two minutes and forty five seconds; five seconds below your sister's highest score."

Joe smiled. "Not bad for a boy, huh?"

Miss Flora giggled. "Not bad at all."
13111331133.title: Saved by a childhood promise.

choices: Wait and form a plan first.
133.content:
You decided to talk to the mad scientist recruiter, Josh Gary first. You knew first hand how aggressive he could be when trying to convince anyone, boy or girl to sign up for Eliete Scientiam all boys mad science academy. If it were not for the Soothsayers or witch police, you feared you might have been dragged to the school against your will for a tour. You knew where he kept his office and teleported yourself there where you found him at his desk, working through a small stack of papers in front of him.

"Ah, princess Gina Mage." Nodding at you, he said. "I will be with you momentarily."

He continued to work on the papers for what seemed like an eternity before slowly rising from his chair ans cricking his back. "I see you have graduated from Cauldron Academy, judging from your magical aura." Bluntly, he said. "I take it you wish to protest my actions in attempting to recruit your younger brother."

"He will not be of age for another week, Gary!" Annoyed, you spat. "You had no right to approach him before he was aware of either power!"

Josh shook his head. "Joe is the perfect age and I acted well within chaotic law otherwise the Correction Officers from the Failure Oversight Department would have been pounding upon my door for an explanation." Firmly, he countered. "As for your bother being unaware, that is your family's oversight, not mine."

"You nearly dragged me to your mad science school." Angry, you argued. "What stopped you from doing the same to Joe?"

"I did not drag you anywhere, princess." Irritation in his voice, Josh replied. "I merely attempted to show you the better path. It was your choice to refuse. I merely overstepped my time limit to attempt to convince you." He sighed. "I gave your brother literature on my Alma Matter and asked him to consider the school." He then walked back to his desk and sat back down. "If you excuse me, I have much work to do so good day to you."

With that, you found yourself back inside the sitting room where mom was anxiously waiting. "Did you get any answers out of Josh Gary?" Wincing, she asked.

"Just the usual legal claim of no wrong doing." Sighing, you replied. "I'm guessing I will get the same answer out of Lydia Rune."

"What do you plan to do?" Softly, mom asked.

You sighed. "I'm not sure."
133.title: talk to Josh Gary.

choices: You find Joe studying with Rachel.
14.content:
Mom winced before replying, "Joe is next door, studying with Rachel Scott. He... doesn't know about any of this yet."

"He doesn't know...?" Surprised, you asked. "Might I ask why?"

"You were not told until your flame first appeared, young lady." Frowning, mom countered. "It is my right to choose when to reveal the secret."

"It's dad's right too." Serious, you reminded.

Mom nodded. "True. However, it is against both laws to discuss any of it when one is in the presence of the normals; those who do not possess either power."

"So what are you planning to do?" Curious, you asked. "You know that dad will take full advantage of any alone time he has with Joe to talk to him about his mad science."

Mom sighed. "I was hoping you could talk to him about it." Hopeful, she said. "Joe and I get along very well but..." She blushed slightly. "Its easier to talk about magic with girls than boys."

You rolled your eyes. "Seriously...?" Unimpressed, you demanded. "You are an expert in combat magic but you are shy about talking about magic to your own son?"

"I'm not shy about talking about magic." Honestly, mom replied. "It's the prerequisite of becoming a girl I am not sure how to sell him." She sighed. "Joe has his heart set on becoming an Olympic athlete; its his one dream. If he thinks, even for a minute, that I'm trying to take that away..."

You shrugged, a sigh escaping your lips. "Fine. I'll go talk to him."

"Just make certain you talk to him away from any normal." Serious, mom said.

You nodded and walked next door to talk to Joe...
14.title: Mom asks you to talk to Joe.

choices: about your year at Cauldron Academy.
141.content:
As luck would have it, you spotted Joe walking home as you were approaching Rachel's house; judging from his smile, he was in a good mood. He spotted you a moment later and waved before you met him half way. "Hey, sis; long time no see." Kindly, he said. "How was that exchange student program experience?"

"It was a lot of fun." Smiling, you replied. "I learned a lot and it really changed my life."

"I can't wait to hear about it." Smiling back, Joe said. "Did you take pictures?"

You were pleased and relieved that mom used an exchange student program to explain your one year absence. It kept Joe from worrying and, better still, from searching for you. "I took tons of pictures, bro." Happily, you said. "Only, I left them at the house. I just came looking for you so you'd know I had come back." You grinned. "I know how much you worry about me."

Joe blushed slightly. "Well, it's kind of my job." Smiling, he said. "Being a brother to three girls is not always easy." He sighed, his smile faltering. "Especially since dad is always away on business trips to who knows where."

"That's kind of rough on everyone." Wincing, you said. "Speaking of which, I was hoping I could talk to you alone somewhere about all of that."

"You mean you found out where dad has been going all this time?" Surprised, Joe asked.

"Well, sort of." Frowning, you replied. "I had to do a little digging..."

"You sly little fox." Grinning, Joe said. "I know a place but I want to hear everything; don't hold back, okay?"

You winced at that. "You might not like what you hear." Sighing, you said.

"It's better than not knowing at all, sis." Honestly, Joe said. "I need to know the good and the bad so I can deal with it."

"Okay." Shrugging, you said. "Lead the way."

Joe took you to a private wooded area just outside of town. It had belonged to your mom's family for generations. There, on top of a hill was a lone tree in a small clearing that looked over the small town in the near distance. "I always come up here when I feel the need to clear my head or to figure things out." Softly, Joe said. "It's very peaceful here."

"I remember coming here myself at times." Honestly, you said. "Just one more thing you and I have in common."

Joe chuckled at that. "Okay, what did you learn about dad?" Softly, he demanded. "Also, I want to hear all about your year at this Cauldron Academy."

"Which do you want to hear first?" Sighing, you asked.

Joe paused to think then said, "Tell me...
141.title: You meet Joe halfway.

1412.content:
"Well, I went to Cauldron Academy to learn how to control my magic powers." Surprising Joe, you explained. "You see, I am a witch. Mom is a witch too as are the twins."

Joe chuckled. "Aw, come on sis." Grinning, he said. "The next thing you're going to tell me is that you can make me 'one of the girls' for a day."

"Actually, I can." Grinning back, you countered. "However, there are laws surrounding that but you opened the door, so to speak. That makes you fair game"

Joe, still grinning, shook his head. "Okay, I'll play along." Obviously not believing you, he said. "Change me into one of the girls for a day; I think we can all use a good laugh."

"Even if the joke is at your expense?" Bemused, you asked.

Joe nodded. "I can take a joke but magic?... I'm not that gullible."

You giggled, wondering how Joe could possibly make this any easier for you. "Okay, Joe." Amused, you said. "Just keep in mind, you asked for this."

You waved your hand, casting the proper spell in your head. Joe changed quickly and painlessly which explained why he did not notice at first. Only upon realizing what he had become a shrill of a scream echoed from his, or rather, her mouth. "What did you do to me?!"

"I did exactly what you asked for... sis." Smiling, you replied. "Do you believe me now?"

Joe nodded, though she did not seem happy at all. "I believe you, sis." Shaking, she squeaked. "Only did you really have to make me..."
1412.title: Joe asks for it.

choices: He wants to be changed back.
He agrees to explore a girl's world.
He agrees but has some demands.
14121.content:
You giggled. "You look so cute when you pout." Teasing, you said. Seeing Joe's face harden, you sighed before turning serious. "Teenage girls go through a lot more than you might think; I'm being kind making you young."

"How long do I have to stay like this?" Wincing, Joe asked.

"That's up to you." Honestly, you replied. "I can change you back right now, if you really want."

"I'm sensing a 'however'." Frowning, Joe said.

"I could show you a small piece of my world." Grinning, you said. "The world of a girl."

Joe pouted again. "Ina and Tia will want to give me a makeover." Whining, he protested. "That and they'll want me to join in their dress up games."

"You know their makeup washes off." Bemused, you countered. "It's not the first time they convinced you to let them give you one." Smiling, you added, "As for dress up, no one outside of the family will know its you unless you tell them and even then, they likely will not believe you."

Joe moaned, pouting at you. "You're not being fair, sis."

"I'm giving you the choice." Simply, you said. "It's not my fault you find it a difficult one."

Joe grunted, pouting further. You could tell he was curious but he had some reservations about exploring a girl's world too deeply. It was the same fear you had when you were transformed into a boy for a week during your training. Finally, Joe sighed and made his decision.
14121.title: a seven year old girl.

choices: I want to pick out my own clothes.
141213.content:
"If I agree to this, there will have to be a few ground rules." Serious, Joe said. "If any of these rules are broken for any reason, the deal is off."

"What rules did you have in mind?" Patiently, you asked.

"One, Ina and Tia can't use magic on me." Frowning, Joe explained. "They are only seven and I'm guessing have little to no training in this magic."

You nodded. "The twins are not allowed to use magic, though they have the ability." Serious, you said. "Still, I'll make certain mom knows of your demands."

"Two, I do not want to be sent to school as a little girl." Pouting, Joe said. "It's going to hard enough dealing with this at home to have to go through that."

"That will be tricky." Wincing, you said. "Staying a little girl for a few days is less risky than changing back and forth every few days." You sighed. "The longer you are effected by magic, the stronger your resistance to it will become."

"We'll see." Frowning, Joe said. "Three, when I ask to be changed back, I don't want any arguments or offers to stay a girl longer; just change me back."

You nodded. "Anything else?"

Joe nodded. "Just one more thing." Blushing, he said.
141213.title: He agrees but has some demands.

choices: dad is the head mad scientist.
1412132.content:
You smiled hearing Joe's final demand. "Aren't you worried about picking out your own clothes?"

"I can deal with wearing girl's clothing so long as no one knows it's really me inside." Blushing, Joe replied. "My room, however, is my personal domain." She threw you a stern look before adding, "Everything I own is in there and it took me years to get it just the way I like it!"

"Okay, okay!" Giggling, you said. "We won't touch your bedroom." You then grinned, saying, "Still, we may have you stay inside the guest bedroom as some of your 'personal domain' is not suited for a seven year old girl."

"Ha Ha." Pouting, Joe said. "If that happens, no one is allowed in my room until I'm back to normal; it's my room."

"Fair enough." lightly, you said. "Still, mom may contest your demand about not going to school like you are right now. You know education is high on her must have list."

"Maybe..." uncomfortable, Joe said. "We'll see if mom and I can strike a deal or something."

You giggled at that. "Are you ready to go home so mom can see the temporary new you?"

Joe crossed her arms. "Aren't you forgetting something?" Crossly, she demanded. "You were about to tell me where dad has been and what he's been up to." She sighed, a look of worry on her face. "Do I even want to know right now?"

You sighed, looking at Joe. You had barely managed to convince her to live the life of a little girl for a while; you did not want to push your luck. Finally, you said, "Well..."
1412132.title: Personal Domain.

choices: I'll watch her until you come back.
14121322.content:
"That's up to you, sis." Honestly, you replied. "If you really want to know, I'll tell you." You then sighed, adding, "It's a lot to take in though."

Joe pouted, a low moan escaping her lips. "I guess I can wait then." Reluctantly, she said. "Just don't forget my rules."

"Are you ready then?" Smiling, you asked.

Joe sighed. "I'm ready."

You giggled. "Hang on then; teleportation can be a bit disorienting at first." Bemused, you said.

"Teleportation?" Taken back, Joe asked.

You cast the proper spell then smiled seeing Joe stumble slightly before righting herself with mom watching with a bemused look of her own. "I see you found Joe." Smiling, she said. "Did, um, she agree to her new form?"

"She agreed to try being a little girl for a while but has a few demands." Smiling back, you said.

You went on to explain Joe's demands to which mom gave an amused smile. "I'm surprised she did not demand more." Calmly, she said. "Interesting..."

"Do you want me to demand more?" Frowning, Joe demanded.

Mom chuckled. "I expect more demands will come with time." Bemused, she said. She then turned serious. "Ina and Tia have already been informed that they are not to use magic without mine or Gina's strict supervision."

"If they do, they will be in trouble." Serious, you added.

Mom nodded then smiled again. "As for your room, I believe we can bunk you in the spare bedroom during your experience to ensure it remains the same for your return to boyhood."

"What about school?" Wincing, Joe asked. "I don't really want to go to school like this."

Mom smiled patiently. "You would not be treated any differently than any other young girl at school, Joelle." Giggling at her pick for Joe's new name, she said. "Also, it will give you a better perspective of what Ina and Tia put up with every day compared to your own life as a teenage boy."

Joe rolled her eyes at mom's pick for a girl's name. "Fine but my other rule still stands." Firmly, she demanded. "When I ask to be changed back, just please do it."

"I will change you back when you ask." patiently, mom replied. "However, you must ask at an appropriate time and in the appropriate manner."

"What does that mean?" Taken back, Joe asked.

"Well, I obviously can't change you back while we are in a public place." Serious, mom explained. "Also, you need to work on your feminine mannerisms, young lady."She then gave her a bemused smile. A proper little girl asks for what she wants politely if she wants the response she desires."

You held back a giggle, knowing mom expected Joe to behave as a proper young lady when she asks to be changed back. Joe moaned at that then reluctantly nodded in agreement. Mom then kindly smiled before turning to you. "It's time to pick up Ina and Tia from ballet." Calmly, she said. "Do you think we should take Joelle with us?"

You grinned at that then replied.
14121322.title: that's up to you.

141213221.content:
Joe shrank back, nervous. "The twins are going to find out eventually, anyway." Shrugging, you said. "Besides, they are not allowed to use magic in public places."

Joe sighed. "I'm more worried about getting volunteered for ballet." Sourly, she said. "If that happens, I will not be able to demand to change back at any time."

Mom smiled. "I had a feeling you would have more demands as time went on." Bemused, she said. "I do not force anyone to enter any extra-curricular activities they are not comfortable with." She then giggled slightly. "However, ballet is a good way to strengthen your legs and upper body."

"So is gymnastics." Serious, Joe countered.

"Will it hurt you to see your sisters practice?" Smiling, you asked. "We're not asking you to join them, just to keep an open mind."

Joe sighed. "I'll watch but don't give them or anyone else any ideas." Frowning, she said.

Ten minutes later, mom lead you and Joe into the Little Angels Ballet school where the instructor, Miss Franz working with a number of little girls in their dance costumes. She was tall and slender with long red hair in a neat bun and green eyes, wearing a similar dance costume. They were nothing more than one-piece swimsuits with a short skirt attached with leggings and ballet flats. You and Joe watched as the girls danced gracefully across the floor, practicing a number for an up coming recital. Seeing mom enter with you and Joe, she smiled and clapped her hands, motioning the girls to stop dancing.

"That is all for today, my little angels." Kindly, she said. "You have come a long way; I am proud of you all. Please remember to return here tomorrow for final rehearsals for the recital."

The girls were dismissed and they hurried off to the changing rooms while Miss Franz walked up to mom, Joe, and you. "It's always a pleasure to see you again, Mona." Smiling, she said. She motioned to you. "Who is this little angel you brought with you?"

Joe blushed, causing you to giggle slightly as mom smiled. "This is my niece, Joelle." Bemused, mom replied. "She's the biggest tomboy you will ever meet."

Miss Franz giggled before sighing. "The recital will go on as planned but the girls will not be able to compete in the international ballet competitions this year."

"Oh dear." Wincing, mom said. "What happened?"

Miss Franz sighed. "One of the girls pulled out due to illness." Sadly, she said. "She will not be well enough in time." Again, she sighed. "The girls were so looking forward to it as they would be the youngest ballerinas to ever enter the competition."

"I've been set up." Frowning, Joe whispered.

Hearing her, you knelt down. "We did not know this until just now." Whispering, you explained. "Magic can't be used for this, no matter how much we want it to."

"I'm sorry, dear." Seeing Joe frowning, Miss Franz said. "Did you wish to say something?"

Joe moaned before sighing. "I know ballet." Softly, she said. "I like gymnastics better though."

Miss Franz looked at Joe with hope in her eyes. "You know ballet?" Slowly smiling, she asked. "Would you be willing to help our ballerinas enter the competition?"

Joe turned to mom, a sour look on her face. You knew that she was not liking any of this and felt as if she had been set up to join ballet. Still, Joe knew how hard Ina, Tia, and their ballet class worked to earn the chance to compete against older ballerinas. Sure it was only an exhibition match but it was still considered an honor for a young ballerina just to be there. You smiled, proud of your temporary new cousin as she muttered, "Why not?"

"Splendid!" Obviously pleased, Miss Franz chirped. "I will get the paperwork ready straight away and let the girls know that their trip has not been canceled!" She gave Joe a light kiss on the forehead. "Thank you, my little angel; you made a lot of little girls happy today."

After Miss Franz had run off, mom giggled. "You did not have to do that." Bemused, she said. "Still, I am proud of you for agreeing to help Ina and Tia's class."

"You did the right thing... Joelle." Kindly, you added. "You have a good heart."

"Yeah, well just make sure I don't get stuck this way." Near tears, Joe said. "I want to be an Olympian gymnast, not a ballerina."

"You will be your male self again once this is over, Joe." Smiling, mom said. "So long as nothing happens to cause a permanent change.

"What's that supposed to mean?" Taken back, Joe demanded.

Mom never got to answer as a chorus of happy screams were heard as a group of little girls, still in their ballet costumes, rushed out towards Joe with Ina and Tia leading the way. You noticed Joe wince as you both saw Ina carrying a ballet costume in Joe's size.
141213221.title: Why not?

choices: a little girl in a ballerina costume.
1412132211.content:
Ina and Tia froze upon seeing you and mom with a little girl. Only upon putting two and two together, they smiled at Joe. It was not a wicked smile but it made her nervous none the less. "How did you get her to agree to this?" Giggling, Ina asked. "I thought she would never..."

"Your cousin, Joelle heard of your troubles and agreed to help." Calmly, mom replied. "Mind you, she is only doing this so you can go to the competition. She has made no promises beyond that so... girls, do not pressure her."

"Thank you for signing up to help... Joelle." Smiling, Tia said. "We were going to have a sleepover after class today why don't you join us?"

Joe blushed at that and turned to mom and you with pleading eyes. In a way, you felt sorry for your transformed brother but you also knew that no harm would come to 'her' going to sleepover other than some embarrassment. "Try to remember that Joelle as a tomboy, Tia." Smiling, you said. "She's really not into such things."

"It wouldn't be right if she didn't go." Speaking up, another girl said. "Besides, other than Ina and Tia, we're all tomboys here." She smiled at Joe. "I'm Ron or Rina Dove and this is Chris or Christina Verse, Jessie or Jessica Marble and Frank or Frankie Smith."

The girls all nodded as they were introduced. Ron or Rina was about Ina's height with blond hair, blue eyes. Chris or Christina was a few inches shorter with brown hair, brown eyes. Jessie or Jessica was about Joe's height with black hair and blue eyes. Frank or Frankie had blond hair and green eyes. All of them had doll like features and their hair done up in a bun on the top of their heads. Joe turned from one to the other, confused.

"You have a boy and a girl's name?" Taken back, she asked.

"We know that's you, Joe." Smiling, Ina said. "Tia and I had to get special permission to join this ballet team." She giggled, handing Joe the ballerina costume. "Tell her, mommy."

"Tell me what?" Nervous, Joe asked. "Do I have to change into this now?"

You were confused as well and turned to mom who giggled. "Gina, Joe, this is a ballet school exclusively for transformed boys."

Joe's eyes widened. "It's what?!"

"None of us are forced to join." Smiling, Rina said. "Only, until the semester ends, we have to take on our girl names and live as little girls at home."

"Its better than going through magic resistance training." Wincing, Christina added. "Here, we are treated just like any other little girl and it is forbidden to push our resistance at home while in this program, learning ballet."

"All of these... girls are of witch blood." Serious, mom explained. "Learning ballet will give them added strength, balance, and dexterity so to dodge spells when they graduate this school and are changed back to their male selves."

"So, you want to join us at the slumber party?" Smiling, Frankie asked.

Just then, Miss Franz stepped in, smiling with the necessary paperwork for mom to sign, which she did, then turned to Joe. "Welcome to Tomboy ballet school, Joelle." Smiling, she said. "We are very happy to have you with us."

"Do I have to put this on?" Wincing, Joe asked.

Miss Franz giggled. "Only if you want to do some late practicing with me tonight." Bemused, she replied. "We still have a few more days so we can get you caught up starting tomorrow." She then clapped her hands. "Okay, my little angels; get back into your regular clothing. Your parents are waiting to take you all to the slumber party."

The girls cheered as they ran for the changing rooms, leaving Joe and you blushing slightly. "Maybe I should go with her as a chaperone; you know, to keep an eye on her." Whispering, you said. "Ina and Tia might have some mischief in mind."

Mom smiled. "That's a fine idea, Gina."

With that, you felt something changing. Upon looking down, you huffed. "Really mom?!"

Mom giggled. "You look cute as a..."
1412132211.title: Not your typical ballet class.

14121322111.content:
Mom giggled. "You look cute as a little girl in a ballerina costume." Bemused, she said. She then turned serious. "Direct or indirect intimidation is strictly prohibited in this program. All chaperones will be disguised as girls their age or younger."

"Thanks for telling me in advance." Pouting, you said. "Also, what's with the ballet costume?"

Mom waved her hand and you found yourself in wearing a summer dress to fit your disguised age. You guessed you were around seven, the same age as Ina and Tia. "You didn't ask, you just volunteered." Smiling, she replied. "As for the costume, I just wanted to see your reaction."

"Ha. Ha." Frowning, you said. "Seriously, do all those transformed boys feel so intimidated by their witch families that their chaperones have to be disguised as kids?"

Mom sighed. "All of the boys in that class were victims of either a magical prank or test that fell out of hand." Softly, she explained. "Ina and Tia have good hearts, they have been helping the boys turned girls see the fun side of magic."

"So you are hoping they will do the same for me?" Wincing, Joe asked.

"As I said, no one asked you to volunteer, Joelle." Calmly, mom said. "Also, I will change you back when you ask at the appropriate time and in the appropriate manner."she then turned to you. "You too volunteered so I expect you to follow through to the end."
14121322111.title: Magical therapy.

141213221111.content:
The sleepover, held at the house of Miss Franz, was much like any other you had gone to when you were younger. There were snacks, drinks, and games all set up for the girls to enjoy and cots lined up in the spacious party room for everyone to sleep. Joe was obviously feeling out of place but knowing that she was not the only transformed boy there gave her some comfort. "Girls, have some patience for Joelle." Firmly but kindly, Miss Franz said. "All of you, minus Ina and Tia, know what it is like to be transformed."

"It's not all that bad." Smiling, Rina said. "It just takes some getting used to."

"That and you're treated like anyone else." Calmly, Jessica added. "No one will stress your girl's name or force fashion choices upon you."

"There are reasons behind the treatment transformed boys go through during magical resistance training." Serious, Miss Franz said. "However, this method has a higher success rate and is far easier on the transformed boy." She smiled, turning to Joe. "Just be yourself and you will be fine."

Joe smiled slightly at that though she still seemed nervous. "Um... what do we do first?" Curious, she asked. "I really don't know what girls do at a sleepover."

Miss Franz giggled. "What would you like to do?"

Joe's growling stomach answered for her, causing even you to giggle. "i think you have your answer." Bemused, you said.

Joe blushed as Miss Franz gave an amused smile. "We can have dinner first, if you are all hungry." Kindly, she said. She turned to the others. "Who wants pizza?"

All of the girls cheered.
141213221111.title: The sleepover.

1412132211112.content:
The sleepover was a resounding success. Joe got into the spirit of the games fairly quickly and was playing just like any other girl within the first hour. There were other girls there, all chaperones, who mingled among the small crowd of little girls. One of them walked up to you with a patient smile.

"I'm Rae; Jess or Jessica is my little transformed brother." Softly, she said. "We started him on resistance training only it got out of hand." She sighed, a twinge of guilt on her face. "The 'fun' lasted a bit longer than expected and it nearly locked her form."

"What convinced her to join this class?" Curious, you asked.

Rae smiled. "Your little sisters, Ina and Tia." Kindly, she replied. "They convinced Jess to join the ballet class telling them that being a girl was not bad so long as they were treated like girls..."

Hours later, back in your teenage form, mom picked up you, Joe, and the twins. "Who knew our little terrors were actually angels?" Whispering, you said.

Mom giggled. "Oh, they can be little terrors when they want to be." Bemused, she said. "Still, their hearts are in the right place."

"Are we going to keep Joelle in the ballet program?" Worried, you asked.

"That is up to Joelle." Honestly, mom replied. "I'm certain Ina and Tia will try to convince her but I will not force it one way or the other."

"Because of dad." Wincing, you said.

Mom sighed. "Yes, because of your father."

You knew dad was a mad scientist and would frown upon Joe having any lengthy encounters of the feminine kind. "So what now?"

Mom smiled. "Now, we take Joelle shopping." Cheerfully, she said. "She is going to be around for a while so a small wardrobe will have to be purchased." She threw you a wink. "It should be interesting to see what kind of fashion sense she has."

You were smiling as you lead Joe into the girl's clothing department at the local mall. "What are we doing here?" Wincing, she asked.

"You are going to be little girl for a while so you're going to need a small wardrobe to wear until you change back to normal." Calmly, you said. "You know your sizes, go find a few outfits you think you would like to wear."

Joe sighed and began to walk towards the boys department but mom stopped her while Ina and Tia suppressed their urge to giggle. "It has to be girls clothing, dear." Firmly but kindly, mom said. "I'm certain there a few outfits you will like in there."

With a heavy sigh, Joe began to look through the racks of girls clothing. "This is embarrassing." Grumbling, she complained.

"There is nothing to be embarrassed about, sweetie." Cooing, mom said. "It's just clothing and only you will be picking them out."

"We can help you, if you want." Smiling, Ina chimed in.

"Only you have to ask for it." Smiling as well, Tia added.

"We can all help you, if you want, Joe." Kindly, you said. "This is just so you can have your own style until you are back to your old self."

Joe sighed before biting his lip as he always did when she was nervous. Finally, he squeaked out... "I think..."
1412132211112.title: The next morning.

choices: skip to Joe's first ballet class.
Joe goes back to grade school.
14121322111121.content:
You smiled hearing that. "Do you want all of us to help you?" kindly, you asked.

Joe sighed, holding back tears. "I don't want to be laughed at if I end up going to school like this." Quietly, she said.

Tia reached for one of the racks and pulled out a modest blue skirt. "This is called a skort, Joe." Calmly, she said. "It's a skirt with shorts sewed in to better protect a girl's modesty, something you might like to wear."

Ina reached for another rack and pulled out a black pair of leggings. "Leggings are also used to protect a girl's modesty." Smiling, she said. "You won't be able to wear skorts all the time and they are very comfortable."

Getting into the spirit, mom pulled out a denim skirt. "This is made out of the same material as your jeans." Kindly, she said. "Also, they are long enough so not boy will be able to peak."

Joe blushed terribly at that as he had caught a few boys trying to sneak a peek under a girl's skirt. "Can I wear jeans?" Hopeful, she asked.

"Not with a uniform policy at school and mom's no tomboy rule at home." Patiently, you said. "There are reasons behind that rule."

Joe moaned but reluctantly added a few skorts, skirts and leggings to the cart. "Any other suggestions?" Wincing, he asked. "I'm out of my comfort zone here..."

Ina and Tia giggled, though not meanly. "Just avoid anything that shows too much or draws too much attention to yourself." Smiling, Ina said. "Light solid colors would be your best bet."

"Don't worry about the panties, no one is going to see them but you." Smiling as well, Ina added. "Also, you might want to look into swimsuits."

Joe blushed further. "Swimsuits...?"

"Well, it is summer." Gently, mom said. "You may wish to go swimming later."

"A one piece swimsuit would be best for you, I think." Gently, you said.

Joe nodded, feeling nervous but Ina gave her a quick hug. "We helped all of those girls in our ballet class and we'll help you too." Kindly, she said.

"If you wear a boy's shirt, the other girls will think you have a boyfriend." Smiling, Tia added. She blushed herself. "We made that mistake ourselves."

"Do all girls have their own secret code for everything?" Wincing, Joe asked.

Ina and Tia giggled. "Yup!"
14121322111121.title: I need some help.

141213221111212.content:
Upon returning home, Joe was blushing but not pouting which made mom happy and you relieved. "Ina and Tia continue to surprise me." Softly, you said. "They really helped Joe see that its just clothes and that no one will tease him for being a transformed boy."

"I have to admit, I was skeptical at first myself." Smiling, mom said. "Those two have a soft spot for those having a rough time and do all they can to make them feel better about themselves."

You followed Joe to his bedroom and smiled seeing her placing the outfits she had picked out into her closet while pushing his now oversized clothes aside. "It's just until the recital." Seeing you, Joe said. "Still... it doesn't hurt to have a small wardrobe in case you or someone else decides to use mischief magic."

"How do you know about mischief magic?" Curious, you asked.

"Ina and Tia told me about it." Blushing, Joe replied. "Most of the girls in their ballet class were effected by mischief magic that turned into resistance training or a test that went completely out of hand." She sighed. "No one meant for their plight to happen but it did."

"Are you afraid it might happen here?" Softly, you asked.

Joe shrugged. "It might happen here but worrying about it won't help." Honestly, she said. "Being prepared for it, however, will."

"Which is why we brought you a few extra things to try later on." Approaching the door, Ina said. "It's nothing required for the ballet class but something you may become curious about later."

You and Joe looked to see Ina carrying a small makeup kit, some pierced earrings and a few perfume bottles. "It all washes off easily." Standing behind her sister, Tia added. "Also, no one is going to pressure you to use any of it but." She giggled. "Still, just in case you might get curious later."

Joe shrugged. "I guess it will be okay." Calmly, she said. "I might never use it though."

"That will be your choice." kindly, you said.

"Our next ballet class is tomorrow after school." Smiling, Ina said. "But don't worry, no one is allowed to tease you. They are required to treat you like any other regular girl."

"So, just be yourself and you will be fine." Smiling as well, Tia said. "But remember that you are a little girl, they will expect you to act like one."

"What do you mean?" Wincing, Joe asked.

"Well, if you show off your teenage knowledge, the school staff might advance you into higher grades." Calmly, mom replied. "If you show yourself as too much of a tomboy, other girls might try to get you 'out of your shell', so to speak."

"Being shy and not talkative will raise concerns as well." serious, you said. "Your best bet is to try to blend in as our tomboy cousin from out of town."
141213221111212.title: returning home.

15.content:
Mom winced before replying, "I don't know; he hasn't come home from school yet."

"What?!" Gasping, you demanded. "Have you gone looking for him?!"

"Your father is out looking for him now and I have been calling the few places he usually goes after school to unwind." Looking worried, mom replied. "So far, neither of us have had any luck."

"Did you try the mall or the new gym across town?" Concerned, you asked.

Mom sighed. "I tried everywhere I could think of, sweetie." Tearing up, mom said. "I'm hoping you might know somewhere he might go or someone who might know who I don't."

You thought furiously. If dad was looking for him, you knew it was possible that he had found him and was just stalling for time to talk to Joe about his science. Then again, he might have run into one of the recruiters for magic or mad science. You knew of two people who showed interest in Joe before you left for Cauldron Academy. There was Lydia Rune; a strong witch and the student body principal of your school. She was tall and slender with shoulder length brown hair and blue eyes. She had a reputation of misleading people without breaking any rules of conduct. Then there was the mad science recruiter whom had approached you last year. His name was Josh Gary; average height with crew cut black hair and brown eyes. He was always professionally dressed, making him stand out like a soar thumb. You wondered if Joe had run into either one of them or if something worse had happened.

Finally, you gave mom a warm hug. "Don't worry, mom." Firmly, you said. "We'll find him."

After a moment pondering over where to search first, you decided to...
15.title: Missing brother.

choices: running from a group of boys.
151.content:
You knew that you could summon dad in an emergency with a special bracelet he had given you before leaving for Cauldron Academy. It had a sensor which you only had to press with your thumb to send a signal that you needed him. If it were ever ripped off, it would send a signal to both him and your mother that you were in danger. You pressed the sensor and dad appeared in front of you with a concerned look on his face. He was tall and muscular with short black hair and reddish eyes which often gave you the creeps. "My search for your brother has, thus far, been unsuccessful." Stress in his voice, he said. "All of the tracking devices I have given him do not seem to be functioning and he is not answering his cellphone."

"There is a spot he may have gone but I can't go there alone." Wincing, you said. "Mom doesn't like him going there."

"Name the location." Serious, dad said.

"The junkyard just outside of town." Frowning, you replied. "He often goes there to work out when he needs to clear his head."

"That is a dead zone." Frowning, dad said. "Cellphones and tracking devices do not work there. Joe is foolish to go there because of that very reason; he cannot call for help if he falls into trouble or danger."

"I'm going with you." Serious, you said. "He's my brother."

"There is no time to argue over the issue, Gina." Darkly, dad said. "Come if you wish but do not leave my side for any reason. The junkyard is a playground for young collectives."

You gulped at that. Young collectives or groups of teenage mad scientists could bring anyone trouble; especially if they were feeling mischievous. You nodded and dad raised a hand held device before pressing a single button. In a flash you were both in the middle of the junkyard where you found Joe...
151.title: find dad.

choices: Dad takes you and joe home.
Dad demands the girls explain themselves.
1512.content:
You froze, fearful for your brother as you saw him running from a group of five boys. All of them were wearing school uniforms you did not recognize and were shouting threatening phrases such as "Get him!" and "Don't let him get away!"

You turned to dad, hoping he would jump in but found that he was not making a move though there was a look of disapproval on his face. Joe eventually spotted you with dad and sprinted in your direction with the boys in pursuit. Dad allowed Joe to run passed before pulling you behind him.

"I shall deal with this, young lady." Darkly, he said. "See to it that Joe is unharmed."

You nodded then hurried over to Joe who seemed to have been catching his second wind. "I was working out when five girls came running after me, asking for my help." Irritated, he said. "Then these five lunatics arrived and tried to drag me into a van!" He shivered off a certain chill. "The two groups then got into a fight using things that I had only seen in an Anime. I was trying to get away from both of them when you showed up with dad."

"Are you hurt?" Wincing, you asked.

Joe shook his head. "Just mad and confused, that's all." Huffing, he replied. "Do you have any idea what's going on?"

"That's enough, gentlemen." Gravely, dad commanded. "Explain yourselves."

The five boys froze in their tracks, their faces ghostly pale upon seeing dad standing before them with his hands firmly onto his hips. You had never seen anyone so completely panicked in the face of your father, it was unnerving. "Lord head mad scientist!" Gasping, the first boy exclaimed. He bowed respectively. "We are honored by your presence!"

"We received word that a teenage coven was planning to tempt your son into joining their ranks." Quivering, the second boy explained. "We had only the most pure and honorable of intentions."

"We were successful in driving off the coven." Also bowing, the third boy said. "We were only trying to persuade your son to pause long enough to hear us out."

"Yet, in your haste, you completely forgotten the gentleman code." His eyes narrowing, dad scolded. "Leave my son to me and approach him no longer or risk his, or worse, my wrath."

The boys nodded, defeat clear on their faces and walked away. He then turned to you and Joe and sighed spotting a small group of teenage girls in the distance.
1512.title: running from a group of boys.

152.content:
You decided to stick to who you knew better and returned to your school to talk to Lydia Rune. Fortunately, she was just leaving a student body meeting when you arrived. She saw you approach and frowned before walking the other way. "We need to talk, Rune." Flatly, you said.

"I'm busy." Rudely, Lydia replied.

"Joe is missing!" Sternly, you shouted. "I know he went to school today!"

Lydia froze and turned to you, stunned. "Are you suggesting I might have had a hand in his apparent vanishing?" Insulted, she demanded.

"I am suggesting you might know what happened or know someone who saw something." More softly, you countered. You then walked up close and whispered, "Or would you rather the soothsayers question you on the subject?"

Lydia's face turned slightly pale. The soothsayers were the witching world's version of the police force who witches referred to as the D.D.M.C. or the Department of Dark Magic Control. "Joe did come to school." Quietly, she confirmed. "However, he seemed out of sorts."

"In what way?" Worried, you asked.

Lydia shrugged. "He said that he felt ill and was excused to the nurse's office near the end of the day." Frowning, she replied. "As you just saw, I was in a student body meeting right after school so I would not know what had happened after that. I would question the nurse or see if that Josh Gary fool knows anything as he claims to know everything."

With that, Lydia excused herself and continued to walk away. You and Lydia were rivals even before you went to Cauldron Academy as you ran against her for student body president. You had won but going to witch school allowed her to win due to your 'temporary transfer'. From the way she was acting, you knew she was hiding something but then was not the time to get into it; you had to think quickly and make your next move.
152.title: talk to Lydia Rune.

1521.content:
The school nurse, Madam Isa, was a seasoned witch. She worked to offer first aid for the normals, those unaware of magic or mad science, and to give counseling to young witches and mad scientists alike who attended the school. You walked into her office to find her getting ready to leave for home. Madam Isa was an Amazon of a woman with long auburn hair, tied into a pony tail, and gentle blue eyes. She noticed you and smiled. "Good afternoon, Miss Mage." Kindly, she said. "How was your year at Cauldron Academy?"

"It went well, Madam Isa." Politely, you replied. "However, Joe has gone missing." You winced, adding, "I questioned Lydia Rune and she told me he was sent here near the end of the day."

"That he was." Serious, Isa replied. "He was experiencing symptoms of that time. I wrote him an excuse to leave school early."

You knew that Isa was referring to Joe discovering his flame or spark, depending upon which power was stronger within him. Magic would bring a harmless blue flame to his left hand and mad science would bring a spinning globe of energy. "He did not return home." Serious, you said. "Do you know if he left on his own or if someone picked him up?"

"He did not return home?" Worried, Isa asked. "Oh dear..." She reached into her bag and pulled out a copy of an excuse paper, required by her to avoid magically or chaotically forged passes. "Joe left the school about an hour before school ended." Serious, she explained. "He left..."
1521.title: You talk to the nurse.

15211.content:
"... with your father."

You could not believe your ears. "Joe left with my father?" Annoyed, you demanded. "He told mom and I he was looking for him!"

Isa sighed. "I fear that is the truth, Miss Mage." Calmly, she said. "He is one of Joe's legal guardians so I could not deny him when he arrived to take Joe home."

"Thank you, Madam Isa." Politely, you said. "I should be off."

"I hope all is well." Kindly, Isa said. "Good day."

Upon leaving the school, you called dad's cellphone and he picked up on the third ring. "Yes, Gina, I picked Joe up from school." Flatly, he said. "However, in his confused and frightened state, my confession of our abilities sparked a panic and he ran off."

"You told him about your science, I take it." Ice in your voice, you said.

"I told him about our legacy, magic and chaotic science, young lady." With equal coldness, dad countered. "You may not agree with who and what I am but a part of that is within you and will always be, like it or not."

You sighed, frustrated. Dad had the bedside manners of a barbarian; he had always spoke bluntly, never really sugar coating anything. "Have you found him?" Softly, you demanded.

"I am still searching, Gina." Calmly, dad replied. "I regret that I know little regarding his social habits or interactions." he sighed, showing a hint of frustration. "Would you know of a location he would consider safe, somewhere he could gather his thoughts with little chance of interruption?"

You thought furiously before remembering Joe mentioning a quiet place he went to when he was having a bad or very strange day. "I might know of one place." Serious, you said.

"Where might that be, Gina." Anxious, dad demanded. "I must be at his side in this delicate time of his adolescence."

You sighed then...
15211.title: with dad.

choices: You teleport Joe and yourself home.
152112.content:
Although you hated to do it, you felt that the last thing Joe needed was dad's lack of bedside manner so you ended the call. "Oops." Frowning, you muttered. "I guess we got disconnected."

Knowing dad would be annoyed, you hurried to a private spot and teleported to a lone tree in a clearing surrounded by woods. The small forest belonged to mom's family for generations. The lone tree stood on top of a high hill over looking the town. It was where Joe ran to when he felt the need to be alone. Upon arriving, you found Joe sitting at the base of the tree, looking out at the small town in the short distance.

"Do you mind if I join you?" Startling him, you asked.

Joe spun around and gave a slight smile seeing you. he then gave a short nod and you walked up, sitting down at his side. "It's peaceful up here." Softly, Joe said. "I could spend all day just watching the clouds go by and forget the madness of the world below."

"It is peaceful." Smiling, you agreed. "I missed coming up here."

"Dad told me that you, mom, and the twins are all witches." Flatly, Joe commented. "He also told me that he's some kind of super scientist." He scoffed. "As if he were a comic book superhero or something."

"You didn't believe him?" Worried, you asked.

"He showed me some proof." Frowning, Joe said. "Only he wanted me to make a decision right then and there!" He threw a fist onto the ground. "Some scientist he is! Any scientist worthy of his or her diploma knows that no one can make such a life changing decision based only upon one's word and a minor display!"

You sighed, frustrated with dad. "So you ran here to think things through."

Joe nodded. "It's a lot to take in, Gina." Shaken, he said. "Just wrapping my head around it all is going to take time, let alone decide if I want to become a girl and learn magic or stay a boy and learn this chaotic science."

"Dad should have had mom with him when he talked to you." Serious, you said. "Are you willing to talk to her, since dad already tried?"

Joe shrugged. "I don't know." Honestly, he said. "Right now, I'm not too sure about anything..."

You bit your lip, trying to decide what to do...
152112.title: Seeing Joe alone.

choices: You are asked to speak for them.
1521121.content:
You knew that dad would be monitoring your outgoing calls since you 'got disconnected' so you decided to call mom magically. "Would you like to see some magic, Joe?" Calmly, you asked. "I promise I won't do anything to you."

Joe opened his mouth to answer but remained silent. He instead gave a short nod and you summoned a small crystal ball to your hand. "What are you going to do with that?" Curious, Joe demanded. "Are you planning to read me my fortune?"

You giggled. "Crystal balls are like cellphones for witches." bemused, you explained. "We use them to contact each other, take pictures from a distance, and so on. I summoned this to call mom."

With that, you waved your hand over the crystal ball. "Mom... It's Gina." Gazing into the glowing glass, you said. "I found Joe; dad picked him up from school. He told him about us but he also tried to convince Joe to make a choice. He ran to the lone tree to think things through."

An image of mom appeared inside the crystal ball. "I feared he would try something like that." Sighing, she said. She turned to Joe. "Are you alright, dear? I know this comes as a shock."

"More like a bombshell." Frowning, Joe countered. "Dad made me feel like I was trapped in a tug of war between you and him." He teared up. "You two are not getting a divorce, are you?!"

"Oh no, honey!" Cooing Joe, mom replied. "Heavens no! I love your father for better or worse!" She then sighed. "Your father just has difficulty being anything but blunt and straight to the point; he is a scientist, a great one at that."

"He just has horrible bedside manners." Smiling slightly, you added.

"You are at the age when two great powers open themselves up to you." Ignoring your comment, mom explained. "However, you can only have one or the other." She smiled. "There is a school that teaches the usage and laws both each power. I would love to give you a tour of both schools so you can make an educated decision."

"How long do I have to decide?" Frustrated, Joe asked. "Why am I the last to know about this?"

Mom winced. "Not long, I fear." Apologetically, she replied. "In hindsight, I believe we should have brought you into the loop a lot sooner but what is done is done."

Joe sighed, tearing up. You could tell he was very frustrated and a little frightened. "I wanted to be an athlete..." Sourly, he muttered.

"You still can." Calmly, you said. "This is just part of who and what we are."

"I have information on both schools here at home, sweetie." Smiling slightly, mom said. "Let Gina teleport you here and we'll go over them together. I'll call your father..."

"Dad and I got disconnected, mom." Wincing, you said. "He might be a tad grumpy."

Mom frowned at that. "He hasn't seen grumpy yet." Flatly, she said. "When I get through with him for not informing me he had found Joe..." She sighed, seeing Joe shaking his head. "I'll be civil with him, I promise."

Joe released a sigh then turned to you. "I guess we should head home."

You smiled at mom who giggled slightly before ending the call and causing the crystal ball to vanish. "You might want to prepare yourself, bro." Bemused, you said. "Teleportation can be a bit disorienting the first few times."

"Teleportation?" Surprised, Joe asked. "You can do that?"

You giggled then teleported Joe and yourself back to the house. Joe stumbled slightly but managed to keep his balance as he shook his head. "What a rush..." Taken back, he said.

You and mom giggled. "Not bad for your first time, Joe." Smiling, mom said. "Most boys pass out the first time around."

"It's because we raised him to be strong." Appearing in the room, dad said. "He is, after all my son, my legacy, my apprentice..."

"He is also my son, Geo." Coldly, mom said. "You failed in your duty as my husband to be true to me; care to explain your actions?"

"Your take of the situation is flawed only by your heightened emotional state." Flatly, dad argued. "I was completely truthful; I merely chose my own time to tell the entire truth."

"Omission of the truth is still a falsehood." Unimpressed, mom countered.

"Something you are both guilty of when involving me!" Annoyed, Joe blurted out. "Stop arguing with each other and give me some answers, if you don't mind!"

Mom and dad looked at each other, surprised. "He has a point." Wincing, mom said.

Dad nodded. "Indeed." Sighing, he said. "We do owe him at least an explanation."
1521121.title: You call mom.

15211213.content:
You sighed, rolling your eyes as mom and dad turned to you. "Seriously...?" Unimpressed, you demanded. Frustrated, you turned to Joe. "Dad is the current reigning head mad scientist of this world and mom is the heir to the throne of the head witch."

"What does that have to do with me or why I haven't been told anything?" Annoyed, Joe asked.

"Only girls can be witches and only girls born into the royal family can become head witch." Serious, you explained. "However, if the eldest boy in the royal family is permanently transformed into a girl, 'she' automatically becomes next in line for the throne over her siblings."

Joe gulped, sweat beading upon his forehead. "So if I were to become a girl and learn magic, I become the next heir to the throne?" Unnerved, he asked. "What would happen if i stay a boy and learn this chaotic science?"

"Then you would become the heir to the chaotic throne, the next head mad scientist." With a frown, you replied. "Both positions offer a lot of power and responsibility. They also both require special training but you need to decide which power suits you best."

"I will admit that not telling you sooner was an epic miscalculation." Calmly, dad said. "However, that does not change the fact that you are destined for greatness. The power that awaits you will make your dreams of the Olympics pale by comparison."

"Smooth, dad." Inwardly moaning, you thought. "You just had to go there."

"Actually, each power will make your dreams that much closer to becoming a reality." Kindly, mom explained. "Everyone needs an outlet, even witches and mad scientists. No matter what you choose, there will be an expert team to help you make your dreams come true."

"I suggest we show our inquisitive son exactly what powers and responsibilities await him with each decision before him." Boldly, dad suggested.

Both mom and you rolled your eyes, noticing that dad stressed the male pronouns, indicating he intends to push Joe to deciding to remain male. However, mom chose to ignore it. "Which power would you like to see first, Joe?" Kindly, she asked.

Joe sighed, looking torn. Finally, he replied, "I'd like to start with..."
15211213.title: You are asked to speak for them.

152112133.content:
"You are going to take a nap now?" Puzzled, dad demanded. "Do you not realize the seriousness of the decision that faces you?"

Joe gave dad a rare cold look; one that caused you to gulp. "You are aware that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction, father." Coldly, Joe said. "The action, in this case, is you and mom waiting until the last possible minute to let me in on your little family secret."

"I admitted that was an error of judgement." Calmly, dad protested. He sighed. "What is your idea of an equal and opposite reaction?"

Joe gave dad a rather crooked smile. "The reaction is I waiting until the last possible minute to give you my answer." Calmly, he replied.

"Repeating my miscalculation will not solve the issue at hand." Frowning, dad said.

Joe turned to mom. "Is Ina and Tia aware of the family secret and of their powers?"

Mom sighed. "Yes." Softly, she replied. "But they only know because their magical power surfaced early, my hand had been forced in that regard."

"Would they not have time to decide if they wish to follow in your footsteps or to become boys and follow in dad's?" Serious, Joe demanded. "Did Gina have the same opportunity when she discovered her powers?"

"You have a valid point." Grudgingly, dad admitted. "It is true that we did not give you the same opportunities as your siblings. However, if you do not choose soon, your own inner power may make the choice for you."

"I need time to take this all in." Frustrated, Joe argued. "I need at least an hour nap to clear my head before I can even look at the literature you two are offering."

With that said, Joe walked to his bedroom and closed the door. Exactly one hour later, despite your polite protests, your parents approached Joe's bedroom to plead their case.
152112133.title: Actions and reactions.

1521121333.content:
You managed to get into Joe's room before mom or dad could act and bolted the door with a magical seal to buy some more time. Joe was already awake, looking at you with an air of irritation.

"What is all the fuss about over me having to decide so soon?" Annoyed, he demanded.

"Dad is the last of his bloodline, minus you." Serious, you explained. "If you become a witch, the leadership of the mad scientists will go to another family."

"I see..." Wincing, Joe said. "No pressure there."

"If you become a mad scientist, just about every girl who is aware of mad science and magic will be courting you to gain political power." Flatly, you explained. You then smiled. "Fortunately, you already have a crush on a girl."

Joe blushed at that, knowing you were talking about Rachel Scott.. "She's just a friend." Lamely, he said. "Though I wouldn't mind her being more... if she wants to."

You giggled. "If you become a witch, you end up in the same position, heir to the throne, only through magic." Kindly, you said.

"If the throne goes to another mad science family, what will happen to the relationship between the two powers?" Serious, Joe asked. "Also, how would the witching world react to a transformed mad scientist becoming the next head witch?"

You sighed. "Good questions." Uncertain, you thought. "No one can see into the future, Joe." Honestly, you replied. "Your guess is as good as mine."

"I think it would be best for me to assume the heir to the throne, for now." Serious, Joe said. "With mom soon to become the head witch, we can work together to better relations between the two powers." He then frowned. "However, I am not going to let any of this stop my dreams of entering the Olympics."

You sighed, inwardly wincing. You could almost see dad celebrating out in the hall as Joe decided to follow in his footsteps. "If that is your choice..." Softly, you said.

"It's not really a choice." Surprising you, Joe said. "It's a lack of options. Still, if I am going to become the heir to the throne of all mad scientists, I will have to insist upon a few things."

"Such as..." Raising an eyebrow, you asked.

"I want mom to have an equal role in the transition." Serious, he demanded. "Dad may be the king of all mad scientists but he is rarely around. I don't want to enter this position unprepared or unqualified as other families could use that as an excuse to steal the throne."

You smiled at that. "Knowing mom, she has a smug grin on her face to damper dad's little celebration." Amused, you thought. "Anything else?" You asked.
1521121333.title: You reach Joe first.

15211213332.content:
Joe sighed. "Please let mom and dad in." Softly, he said.

You nodded and released the seal on the door, allowing mom and dad to enter the room. As they came in, Joe cleared his throat. "I know nothing about the world of witches or mad scientists." Serious, he began. "Therefore, to be a qualified leader, I need to know about both worlds."

"In my humble opinion, you must study the world of mad science first." Serious, dad said. "This would serve as both a bonding experience and my opportunity to make up for all lost time due to my duties as head mad scientist." He smiled. "Also, with merely a year of training, you will be able to run circles around even the most experienced college professors."

"Your opinion is noted." Courtly, Joe said. "However, I would rather learn the basics here at home." He turned to mom. "I have the heir to the throne of the witching world and the current top student of Cauldron Academy; who better to teach me the laws and usage of magic?"

Both you and mom smiled at that, blushing slightly at his compliment. Joe then turned back to dad. "I also have the current reigning head mad scientist; I could not be in better hands to learn the ways of chaotic science." Dad smiled, pride beaming on his face.

"You indeed have very valid points, young man." Smiling, he said. "However, it is foolish to learn both powers at the same time."

"I must agree." Sighing, mom said.

"What are you going to do, bro?" Curious, you asked. "Learn magic first or mad science?"

Joe sighed before smiling as an idea hit him. "I believe I will..."
15211213332.title: The making of a leader.

152112133321.content:
"..Learn about magic first" Joe announced.

You was surprised by Joe's choice, though you hoped that nobody could see your shock. Dad was openly surprised and looked slightly angry, whereas mom could barely hide her joy. Gulping, you said, "You do realize..."

Joe interrupted. "I haven't finished. I will learn magic first, but on my own terms."

"Go on" mom said, her enthusiasm dampened. You knew she must had been daydreaming about girlifying Joe as part of the whole magic deal. While you secretly wanted the same, it had to come from your new sister.

"I will learn magic, but with one important condition. Any violation will end my interest. No gender spells on me" Joe said.

The reactions were mixed. Dad started to cackle as mom spat out, "What?" You also looked surprised, something Joe noticed.

"I'm not stupid, Gina. I know what you and mom will want to do. Besides, I assume all three of you want any sort of training to be discrete."

"But the term is unreasonable. Magic is inherently feminine" mom protested, flustered and clearly not enjoying the sudden role reversal of having dad half smirking at Joe's choices.

"True, but can it be done? To teach magic with my conditions?" Joe pressed.

"It can, but with serious limitations" mom admitted.
152112133321.title: Learning magic the hard way

choices: Tina and Tia meet the new you.
1521121333213.content:
"Allow me to explain." Turning to Joe, you said. "As a boy, you can't work magic although it lies dormant within you. That said, you will not be able to defend yourself against spells or potions." You sighed. "True, we can teach you how to mix the potions and recite the spells but without magic, potions are just bad tasting drinks and spells are just poetry on a page."

"Also, magic is an exact art." Softly, mom added. "Too little magic and the spell or potion has little to no effect. Too much magic and the effects of the spell or potion carry more power than a witch might intend."

"I see..." Frustrated, Joe said. "I do not want to be ultra girlified just to learn how magic works."

Mom was visually disappointed through you sensed she understood Joe's stand on the subject. "Why not a compromise?" Taking a chance, she suggested. "Gina and I will agree only to make you a girl during the training sessions and return you to normal once the lesson is over."

"That sounds a bit risky." Wincing, Joe said.

"Switching back and forth from male to female day to day does have its risks." Honestly, you agreed. "You could end up trapped as a girl for life if magic takes root. However, that risk is minimized if the boy is made a young girl twenty four, seven for say a week on then a week off, learning the basics of magic."

"What are you suggesting?" Worried, Joe demanded.

"A compromise." Simply, you said. "You agree to be a girl for a week to learn magic and we agree to keep it professional; no turning you into our little princess."

"While you are in your male form, you could learn the wonders of mad science." Jumping in, dad offered. "A week of male bonding would take your mind off the embarrassing experience of teenage womanhood."

You rolled your eyes at that. "You are not helping, father..." Annoyed, you thought.

"All work and no play, dad..." Frowning, Joe countered.

"Oh, there will be plenty of fun, I assure you." Beaming, dad said. "However, I am merely making a humble suggestion to my only male offspring."

Joe rolled his eyes at that then turned to you. "How long does it take to learn magic?"

"That all depends upon how much you want to learn." Serious, you replied. "I took a year of training and I am still learning."

Joe sighed and bit his lip, thinking. "Okay, I'll try the week on and week off being a girl to learn the basics of magic." Reluctantly, he said. "However, any attempt to overly girlify me or to make me your little princess and the deal is off!" He then turned to dad. "As for learning mad science during the off week, it will depend upon how tired I am after the magic lessons." He paused, turning from mom and dad, holding out both hands. "Do we have an agreement, or not?"

Mom was clearly overjoyed as dad grumbled under his breath, forcing a smile. However, they both took Joe's hand and shook. A reluctant compromise had been made...
1521121333213.title: A reluctant compromise.

15211213332131.content:
Shortly after the agreement had been made, you lead Joe to your room before closing the door and turning to your closet. "When a boy is magically transformed into a girl, they usually become well endowed as a sort of compensation." Seriously, you explained. "I'm guessing your bust will be close to my size once you become female."

"Okay..." Nervous, Joe said. "Do I need to drink a potion or..."

You giggled. "The right potion will transform you." Smiling, you said. "Only, I think a simple spell will suffice for your first time." You sighed. "You are going to feel strange for the first few days but that's normal so don't panic."

With that said, you recited the spell in your mind while focusing on Joe. He immediately began to change by first shrinking a few inches followed by his shoulders rounding out. He winced feeling his crotch go flat along with two orbs forming upon his, or rather, her chest. Within a single minute, Joe had become a teenage girl. She had lost a considerable amount of muscle but she was still visibly strong for her age. Her light brown hair had turned forest blond, like your own, and grew just past her shoulders. It greatly complimented her deep green eyes. As you suspected, her bust was near your own size and with her flattering curves, she turned out to be a very beautiful teenage girl.

"It's a pleasure to meet you, Joeanna." Grinning, you said. "How do you feel?"

"I feel weird." Wincing, Joe replied. "Why are you calling me Joeanna?"

"That way we can call you Joe for short." Simply, you replied. "It'll make things less complicated for you and easier for the twins to remember."

Joe frowned at that. The twins, Ina and Tia, were a mischievous pair. They seemed to always find delight in playing pranks on her. To make matters worse, they were obsessed with princess themed everything. They were always trying to get Joe to play princess games with them; you knew it was going to be a challenge to keep them from irritating their new sister too much.

"The twins know about magic." Calmly, you said. "Don't worry, though. Mom and I will keep them under control; we promised to keep this professional."

"That's fine, I guess." Shifting uncomfortably, Joe said. "I suppose you want to help me get dressed now."

You giggled. "You're old enough to dress yourself... sis." Bemused, you said. "I'm just going to help you with your first bra. After that, I'll leave you to pick out something to wear." You then winked. "Just try to pick out something fashionable. I doubt you want to embarrass yourself and force mom or I to choose what you wear each day."

Joe groaned that the thought as you helped her into her first bra, telling how to do it. Once the bra was on and she had put on a pair of panties, you left your room to allow her to get dressed.

"How did it go?" Softly, mom demanded.

You sighed. "Joeanna is a bit uncomfortable but that's to be expected." Serious, you explained. "She is worried about the twins causing her misery." She then giggled. "She did turn out to be a really cute sister, though."

Mom giggled then turned to her watch. "It's time to pick the girls up from ballet." Calmly, she said. "It's your turn, Geo."

Dad sighed. "As you wish." Flatly, he said. "Just promise me there will be no bending the conditions of the agreement."

Mom smiled. "Only so long as you promise the same."

Dad frowned at that and quietly left the house. Once he was gone, mom giggled. "Now that its just us girls here, lets see how Joeanna is doing." Smiling, she said.

She quietly opened the door and you peeked in with her to find Joe wearing...
15211213332131.title: Meeting your new sister.

152112133321312.content:
You were very surprised to see Joe wearing one of your casual dresses. It was white with short lace pattern sleeves, a modest V-shaped neckline that showed a hint of her bust, an ivory sash, and lace trimmings on the skirt which stopped just above her knees. You turned to mom; she was clearly surprised but the smile on her face showed how overjoyed she was that your new sister had picked out something feminine.

"Joe, you look stunning in that dress!" Gushing, mom said.

Joe jumped, whipping around, and stared at you and mom in shock. "Dress?!" Startled, she demanded. "I thought this was one of Gina's oversized shirts!"

You giggled, realizing that Joe had not intentionally reached for a dress. "You still look very flattering in it, sis." Kindly, you said. "It's a fine choice."

"I don't get to change my mind?" Gulping, Joe asked.

"I can't have you trying on everything in my closet, sis." Serious, you said. "Besides, it does not break any of the conditions you had set. Plenty of tomboys I know all wear dresses like this."

With that said, you zipped the dress up in the back and tied the sash, sealing Joe in the dress she had picked out, even though wearing a dress was not her true intention. "Cheer up, honey." Seeing Joe pout, mom said. "We can take you shopping for some other clothes later on today."

"Shopping?" Uncertain, Joe asked.

"It's going to be a week on and a week off, Joe." Serious, you said. "You are going to need a small wardrobe for the weeks you are a girl."

Joe moaned at that as you handed her a pair of flats, which she reluctantly put on. "Now that you are dressed, we can move on to the next step." Smiling, mom said.

"What's the next step?" Nervous, Joe asked.

Mom smiled, looking at you. This caused you to smile as well, making Joe visibly uncomfortable. "The next step is to make you feel comfortable in your new form." Smiling, you said. "Magic is easier to learn when the girl, that's you, is relaxed."

With that, you reached for...
152112133321312.title: a simple but flattering dress.

choices: Tina and Ina see the new you.
Mom gets Joe and you in the car.
Ina and Tia go shopping too.
1521121333213122.content:
With that, you reached for your purse. "The sooner we start building your wardrobe, the sooner you can pick your own style." Smiling, you said.

"I thought I was going to be learning magic." Pouting, Joe protested.

"You will be, I promise." Smiling, mom said. "However, I think you will agree that you need more than just a pretty dress to wear." She giggled. "That and wearing Gina's clothing all the time will get noticed by your two closest friends."

You nodded, thinking of Rachel Scott and Thomas Lore. It was easy enough to get them to see Joe as always being Joeanna but going any further a week on and a week off carried risks of something going wrong. Rachel and Thomas could forget all about Joe and only know Joeanna; you and mom both knew you had to be careful.

Joe sighed, not liking the idea. "No short skirts or frilly dresses." Defiant, she warned. "I'd prefer to wear shorts or jeans."

"I'm fine with you wearing the longer skirts and more simple dresses." Smiling, mom said. "However, I am afraid that I can't bend the rules on jeans and shorts. I have my reasons for it but trust me, I'm doing you a favor by not allowing that."

"Care to explain?" Pouting, Joe asked.

"It's similar to dad's rule regarding jeans and tight shorts." Calmly, you explained. "It's very important that you are able to freely move your legs."

Joe moaned at that but followed you and mom out to the car just as dad pulled up with his own vehicle with Ina and Tina in the back seat. They both looked out, wide-eyed at Joe before they began to smile mischievously. Dad carried a telltale grin on his face; he had told the twins about Joe's agreement to learn magic or at least his version of it. Joe winced as dad took them out of the car just as mom took your hand...
1521121333213122.title: your purse, shopping trip.

15211213332131221.content:
"Don't get in the car just yet." Firmly, mom said. "I want to make certain the twins understand the conditions of Joeanna's magic training."

You nodded and urged Joe stand beside you as Ina and Tia ran up to Joe and looked at him with huge grins on their faces. "You look cute, Joe!" Giggling, Tia said. "No makeup, though."

"We can help you with that." Excited, Ina offered. "We practice all the time!"

"Gina and I are handling Joeanna's training, girls." Patiently, mom explained. "You may help but only when we instruct you to."

Ina and Tia both pouted, clearly not liking what they were told. "But mommy! Daddy said..."

Mom turned to dad who cleared his throat. "I informed them that everything Joe, or rather, Joeanna does is of her own choosing." Grinning, he said. "If the twins wish to help her, they must convince her to allow it." He then smiled at you like a python would a rat. "The conditions of the agreement did not specifically state who would have claim to the lessons; whether in magic or the life of a teenage girl."

"True." Frowning, you said. "However, the twins are not qualified in either respect." You sighed, eying the twins. "Still, we can't single them out, I guess."

Joe looked as if she was going to be sick only you quickly stated, "Mom and I will be supervising anything they try to teach you. It's just so they feel like they are helping."

Joe sighed, clearly not liking the idea then slowly nodded as mom urged her into the car. "We will be back in a few hours." Calmly, mom said. "We will be starting Joeanna's magic lessons later today."

"That's fine." Smiling, dad said. "I will prepare our evening meal while you are gone."

Soon, you and mom were off, taking Joe to the mall. As mom drove, she shook her head, looking frustrated. "Your father is going to do everything he can to make Joe's magic lessons as difficult as he can." Annoyed, she said. "Try to be ready for any mischief."

You sighed then nodded, worried about your new little sister.
15211213332131221.title: Tina and Ina see the new you.

152112133321312212.content:
Mom abruptly turned down a road before reaching the mall to a small shopping plaza where she parked in front of a salon. Joe gasped seeing this and began to panic only mom spoke out before she could utter a word. "We are not here to turn you into our little princess, Joe." Serious, she said. "We are here to show you one of the ways we girls like to unwind."

"How is getting your hair done relaxing?" Wincing, Joe demanded.

Mom winked. "Only one way to find out, isn't there?"

You giggled at that. "Come along, Joe." Smiling, you said. "This is not going to hurt a bit and I promise you will be more relaxed when its done."

Albeit reluctant, Joe followed you out of the car and mom lead you both in where you were greeted by one of the hairstylists. She was of average height and build with long strawberry blond hair and blue eyes. "Welcome back, Gina." Kindly, she said. "It's good to see you again, Mrs Mage; I take it you want the usual treatments?"

"Yes, thank you, Miss Eve." Smiling, you said. "We would also like to introduce you to our new sister, Joeanna." You giggled. "She's a bit of a tomboy."

Miss Eve giggled, making Joe blush slightly. "Would she like the same treatment?" she asked.

"Define treatment." Pouting, Joe demanded.

You, mom, and Miss Eve giggled. "She is a tomboy." Amused, Miss Eve said. She turned to Joe. "I'll walk you through the steps as we take your worries away."

"Okay... I guess." Hesitant, Joe said.

Miss Eve beamed. "Wonderful! Let's get started."
